headline1: 1920:Religious Dementia : IN OUR PAGES:100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
headline2: 1920:Religious Dementia : IN OUR PAGES:100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
snippet: HALLE, Saxony - It is learned that the little town of Falkenberg has become afflicted by collective and contagious religious dementia of the sort that so frequently broke out in various parts of Europe in the Middle Ages and following the Napoleon...
lead_paragraph: HALLE, Saxony - It is learned that the little town of Falkenberg has become afflicted by collective and contagious religious dementia of the sort that so frequently broke out in various parts of Europe in the Middle Ages and following the Napoleonic wars. Men and women in the town have formed a sect, the members of which believe themselves to be in direct communication with the Holy Ghost.

headline1: Friends, Romans, Police Greet Seles for Return
headline2: TENNIS; Friends, Romans, Police Greet Seles for Return
lead_paragraph: Finally, on the eve of Seles versus Navratilova, the exhibition match that has taken on all the dimension and dementia of a soap opera, the mystery player showed up in the flesh today, proof positive that tennis history can happen in the strangest of spots, even a hot spot like this gaudy boardwalk.

headline1: ENDPAPER;PJ Day
headline2: ENDPAPER;PJ Day
lead_paragraph: It started with Vincent (the Chin). For about a year now, I have been reading that Vincent (the Chin) Gigante, the reported boss of the Genovese crime family, walks around his neighborhood, Greenwich Village, wearing only his pajamas. (Mr. Gigante, it seems, may be feigning dementia in order to avoid standing trial in Federal court.) Then I came across the book "Duplex Planet," a collection of interviews of nursing-home residents, one of whom attests, "If you are an old man, and you go into a bar in pajamas, people will buy you drinks."

headline1: THEATER REVIEW;A Monarch's Slide Into Dementia
headline2: THEATER REVIEW;A Monarch's Slide Into Dementia
lead_paragraph: It is kindest, perhaps, to think of it as merely another bead on the abacus: No. 30 out of 36 in the continuing marathon of the complete plays of William Shakespeare from the New York Shakespeare Festival. It's the most difficult one to get right, anyway: practically impossible. And now at least, for the record, it has been done.

headline1: THEATER REVIEW;Delving Into the Dementia of Richard III
headline2: THEATER REVIEW;Delving Into the Dementia of Richard III
lead_paragraph: EVEN with all those radical interpretive variations of "Richard III" for modern times, one of Shakespeare's most overexposed villains has suffered no categorical alteration. The "poisonous bunch-back'd toad" -- in the guise of Denzel Washington or Ian McKellen, Al Pacino or Richard Thomas -- has remained the instigator of a tragical or historical play. Or, to follow Polonius-like couplings, tragical-historical or historical-tragical.

headline1: New Nursing Home Rising in Westchester
headline2: New Nursing Home Rising in Westchester
snippet: New Hebrew Hospital Home of Westchester, now under construction in Greenburgh, will offer residents maximum freedom of movement within sheltered grounds; drawing (S)s
lead_paragraph: Residents with Alzheimer's dementia will have the freedom of walking safely around their own landscaped garden when the new two-story Hebrew Hospital Home of Westchester is completed on a 30-acre site along Grasslands Road in the Town of Greenburgh by the summer of 1998.

headline1: Nordic Study Links Dementia To Drivers in Fatal Crashes
headline2: Nordic Study Links Dementia To Drivers in Fatal Crashes
snippet: Study of brains of elderly drivers killed in automobile accidents in Sweden and Finland has found that unusually high percentage, as many as half, showed signs of early Alzheimer's disease; scientists say condition had not been diagnosed before th...
lead_paragraph: A study of the brains of elderly drivers killed in automobile accidents in Sweden and Finland has found that an unusually high percentage, as many as half, showed signs of early Alzheimer's disease, researchers said today. But the condition had not been diagnosed before their deaths, which led the scientists to suggest that even in its preliminary stages, Alzheimer's can cause enough mental impairment to make driving dangerous.

headline1: Federal Doctors' Report Appears to Say Gigante May Be Mentally Ill
headline2: Federal Doctors' Report Appears to Say Gigante May Be Mentally Ill
snippet: Federal mental health specialists issue report that finds Vincent Gigante, recently convicted of crimes as Mafia boss, to be possibly suffering from dementia, but also to have shown them signs of faking symptoms of mental illness (M)
lead_paragraph: In a report that his lawyer said seemed schizophrenic, Vincent Gigante, recently convicted of crimes as a Mafia boss, was said by Government mental-health experts to be possibly suffering from dementia, but also to have shown them signs of faking symptoms of mental illness.

headline1: Trying Again, Gigante Team Offers Case for Incompetency
headline2: Trying Again, Gigante Team Offers Case for Incompetency

headline1: IS IT ART?
headline2: IS IT ART?
snippet: Museum of Modern Art will exhibit works of Willem de Kooning executed while artist was in advanced stages of Alzheimer's disease; pictures have been panned by some critics, but many artists have done memorable work with handicaps (S)
lead_paragraph: 1. This week the Museum of Modern Art opens ''Willem de Kooning: The Late Paintings, the 1980's,'' work executed while the artist was in the advanced stages of what is believed to be Alzheimer's disease. 2. The pictures were panned in San Francisco; one critic said they consist of ''big loopy ga-ga strokes.'' 3. Maybe so, but plenty of artists have done just fine with handicaps. Monet painted the water lily series at a time when cataracts and eye surgery affected his vision. 4. 'Style,' neurologically, is the deepest part of one's being,'' Oliver Sacks has written, ''and may be preserved, almost to the last, in a dementia.'' 5. Now 92, de Kooning is under round-the-clock supervision at his Long Island home. Visitors say he no longer recognizes anyone and seldom speaks.

headline1: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILBERSTEIN, SYLVIA
headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILBERSTEIN, SYLVIA
lead_paragraph: SILBERSTEIN-Sylvia, philanthropist, talented artist, and dedicated wife, mother, grandmother and friend, passed away Thursday, Dec. 17, 1998. Born in Hammond, Indiana on December 2, 1915, to Samuel & Jennie Kleinberg Levin, Sylvia was an alumni of Indiana University where she met her husband and fellow alumni William Silberstein. They subsequently married in 1937, and lived in Hammond until 1950. She and her family moved to Scarsdale in 1950 and to Rye, New York in 1968. Sylvia will be most remembered for her great sense of humor, buoyant spirit and constant smile. Her charm was contagious and she was adored by her many friends. Sylvia was noted for her culinary expertise, her love of classical music, the theater, tennis & was often consulted for her vast knowledge of travel due to her extensive world travel. Sylvia was a longstanding member of the Quaker Ridge Golf Club since 1955. She possessed sound business acumen and helped her husband found Sealectro Corporation in Mamaroneck, New York. She was also very active in the creation of various philanthropic programs. In 1984, Sylvia and her husband established the first fully endowed athletic scholarship at Indiana University and thereafter two additonal endowed athletic scholarships. Their other philanthropic endeavors include the William & Sylvia Silberstein Aging and Dementia Research Center at New York University Medical Center, the William & Sylvia Silberstein Cardiac Center at White Plains Hospital Center, and most recently, the William and Sylvia Silberstein Pavilion at White Plains Hospital Center. Sylvia supported many other charities including Cystic Fibrosis and U.J.A. amongst others. Her generous philosophy was apparent during World War II when she was President of Hammond, Indiana chapter of B'nai B'rith and she established a welcoming committee for all servicemen's trains providing food and other nourishment to them. Sylvia is survived by her husand, William of Rye, New York, her daughter Betsy Levinson of Stamford, Connecticut; her son Bruce and his wife, Carolyn, of New York City; her son, Sigmund of Boca Raton, Florida, and six loving grandchildren, Beth, Lori and Debra, Jill, Michael and Matthew; and a sister, Arlene Pascal of Highland Park, Illinois. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Silberstein Cardiac Center at White Plains Hospital Center, or The Silberstein Aging and Dementia Center at New York University Medical Center. A service will be held at 12:00 Noon on Friday, December 18th, at the Congregation Emanu-el, 2125 Westchester Avenue East, Rye, New York.

headline1: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARR, DOROTHY HEALEY
headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARR, DOROTHY HEALEY
lead_paragraph: CARR-Dorothy Healey, born on July 17, 1917, loving wife of Peter, & mother of Kevin, Brian, Michael, Kelly Anne & Colin, passed away peacefully June 25, 2000 at the San Diego Hospice. Dorothy suffered with CHF, COPD, HTN, Dementia of Alzheimer's Type. Following a family service at the Church of Nativity, Rancho Santa Fe, CA, her ashes were scattered at sea. After graduating Cum Laude from Trinity College, Washington D.C., Dorothy served in the last class of The Women's Auxiliary Service Pilots (WASPS) in World War II. Dorothy & Peter Carr were married January 23, 1954 at St. Patrick's Cathedral, NY where they resided until they moved to Greenwich, CT. in 1957. In 1983, the Carrs moved to Rancho Santa Fe, CA. In addition to her husband, Peter, Dorothy is survived by four of their five children. Michael passed away in 1995. Kevin, wife Randa & daughter Caroline reside in Simsbury, CT. Brian, his wife Nancy & their children Ryan, Victoria & Daniel are living in Cos Cob, CT. Kelly Anne, husband Neil Winterbottom & two girls, Caitlin & Jennifer live in San Mateo, CA. Colin currently resides in Terrebonne, OR. Those wishing to honor the memory of Dorothy Carr may make donations to the San Diego Hospice, 4311 Third Avenue, San Diego, CA. 92103.

headline1: The Way We Live Now: 2-6-00; Incompetence Is Bliss
headline2: The Way We Live Now: 2-6-00; Incompetence Is Bliss
snippet: David Rakoff article on study that found few of subjects tested on skill levels in number of areas had any idea how incompetent they were; notes study found those who scored lowest on objective tests scored highest in own self-evaluation, while hi...
lead_paragraph: Eighteen years ago, I worked as a researcher on a psychiatric ward. One of the central diagnostic indices used to determine the severity of patients' illnesses was to assess their ''insight.'' Did they understand how and the degree to which they were not well? They usually did not. But over the course of their treatment, the cure was frequently more painful than the affliction, never more so than when patients first became aware of their past behavior, their dementia-fueled outbursts against loved ones, staff and themselves. They now found themselves stranded in a no-man's land between delusion and clarity -- often sad, occasionally humorous. One psychiatrist picked up the phone one day to a panicked, unidentified voice warning of an impending attack at a certain foreign embassy.

headline1: Drop in Chronic Ills May Help Medicare
headline2: Drop in Chronic Ills May Help Medicare
lead_paragraph: The chances that elderly Americans will suffer chronic disabilities like stroke and dementia have declined sharply, the National Academy of Sciences said. If the trend continues, researchers said, spending on Medicare could actually stop increasing. Some economists questioned whether the trends would continue in the long run and whether the high cost of dying would simply be postponed, but not reduced.

headline1: May 6-12; Elderly Blooming With Health
headline2: May 6-12; Elderly Blooming With Health
lead_paragraph: Does an aging nation mean more debilitating illnesses? Quite the contrary, as it turns out. While the over-85 population is soaring, stroke, dementia and other chronic maladies are down sharply, and the number of nursing-home residents is falling, says the National Academy of Sciences. Why? For one thing, more Americans are getting the message about diet, exercise, and not smoking. And better drugs and medical technology also play a key role. All of which, naturally, is good news for Medicare costs. Hubert B. Herring

headline1: April 8-14; Setback in '63 Bombing Trial
headline2: April 8-14; Setback in '63 Bombing Trial
lead_paragraph: After escaping prosecution for 38 years, two men were indicted last May for their involvement in the 1963 bombing of the 16th Street Baptist Church in Birmingham, Ala., which killed four young black girls and galvanized sympathy for the civil rights cause. But one, Bobby Frank Cherry, 71, won a reprieve after he was found to suffer from dementia. Prosecutors plan to seek another evaluation of Mr. Cherry. Mr. Cherry's co-defendant, Thomas E. Blanton Jr., 62, will be tried on schedule. Jury selection begins tomorrow. Kevin Sack

headline1: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDHOFF, ARNOLD, J.
headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDHOFF, ARNOLD, J.
lead_paragraph: FRIEDHOFF-Arnold, J. The Silberstein Aging and Dementia Research and Treatment Center of the New York University School of Medicine mourns with profound sorrow the death of Professor Arnold Friedhoff. For more than a quarter of a century, Dr. Friedhoff was the Director of the Millhauser Laboratories at NYU Medical School. He was a wonderful inspiration for us. His vast knowledge and wisdom were always available to the many researchers who sought his assistance. He worked unstintingly to advance the understanding and treatment of mental illness. We send our deepest respects & sympathies to his family.

headline1: Paid Notice: Deaths  MULLIN, DR. MARGARET M.
headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  MULLIN, DR. MARGARET M.
lead_paragraph: MULLIN-Dr. Margaret M. On February 1, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Matthew Kabriski who preceded her in death January 1, 2000. Dr. Mullin was born August 12, 1910, in NYC. She enjoyed a long career of teaching and guidance, influencing the lives of thousands of students for nearly 50 years. She began her work as a teacher of high school mathematics and then as Dean at Fort Hamilton High School. She was a faculty member of the School of Education of NYU and did post-doctoral study in Europe. She was a member of the Founding Faculty of Bronx Community College. Teachers inevitably have the opportunity to influence the lives of their students. This is a privilege which Dr. Mullin sensed instinctively and with sensitivity throughout her entire professional and post-professional life. Her work was deeply appreciated by her family and her many students and colleagues. Friends may call at the Lloyd Funeral Home, 214-43 39th Ave., Bayside, NY, Monday, February 5, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass at 9:30 AM, Tuesday, February 6, at St. Michael's Church, 136-58 41st Ave., Flushing. In lieu of flowers, please consider donations to the William and Sylvia Silberstein Aging and Dementia Research Center of the NYU Medical Center; 212-263-5700.

headline1: Hints of an Alzheimer's Aid In Anti-Inflammatory Drugs
headline2: Hints of an Alzheimer's Aid In Anti-Inflammatory Drugs
snippet: Dutch study finds that middle-aged and elderly people taking anti-inflammatory drugs, such as ibuprofen or naproxen, for at least two years are apparently protected from Alzheimer's disease; group's likelihood of getting Alzheimer's was one-sixth ...
lead_paragraph: Middle-age and elderly people who took anti-inflammatory drugs like ibuprofen or naproxen for at least two years were apparently protected from Alzheimer's disease, according to a new study by scientists in the Netherlands. Their likelihood of getting Alzheimer's dementia was one-sixth that of people who did not take the drugs.

headline1: National Briefing | South: Alabama: Hospital For Ex-Klansman
headline2: National Briefing | South: Alabama: Hospital For Ex-Klansman
snippet: Judge James Garrett of Birmingham, Ala, orders former Ku Klux Klansman Bobby Frank Cherry committed to state psychiatric hospital or further evaluation three weeks after declaring him mentally incompetent to stand trial in 1963 bombing of church w...
lead_paragraph: Three weeks after declaring that a former Ku Klux Klansman was mentally incompetent to stand trial in the 1963 bombing of the 16th Street Baptist Church, a judge in Birmingham ordered the former Klansman, Bobby Frank Cherry, committed to a state psychiatric hospital for further evaluation. At a brief hearing, the judge, James Garrett of Jefferson County Circuit Court, left, sent Mr. Cherry, 72, to a hospital in Tuscaloosa. Mr. Cherry, who has been found to have vascular dementia, is one of four men originally suspected in the bombing, which killed four black girls. Judge Garrett asked for a report in 91 days. Kevin Sack (NYT)

headline1: The Therapeutic Listener
headline2: MY JOB; The Therapeutic Listener
snippet: As the only psychologist for 880 patients, I've been warmly received by staff and residents. Not long ago, I asked a middle-aged AIDS patient with a history of sporadic violent outbursts whether he got depressed. His reply was: ''The food
lead_paragraph: As the only psychologist for 880 patients, I've been warmly received by staff and residents. Not long ago, I asked a middle-aged AIDS patient with a history of sporadic violent outbursts whether he got depressed. His reply was: ''The food in the crazy house is better than here.'' His confusion resulted from psychosis and AIDS-related dementia. He had a perpetually sad expression that reflected how overwhelmed he was from three catastrophic illnesses.

headline1: 'Full Monty' Composer's Tony Anxiety Is Pell-Mel
headline2: PUBLIC LIVES; 'Full Monty' Composer's Tony Anxiety Is Pell-Mel

lead_paragraph: ALL this Tony Awards dementia is frittering away at the composer David Yazbek's carefully cultivated -- we're talking eight years of spirituality lessons and cross-legged meditation! -- Zen frame of mind. Unable to escape his obsession with beating his ex-idol Mel Brooks (''The Producers'') for the best score award for ''The Full Monty,'' the underdog show about underdog men who sing in their underwear, he's become a real-life clone of the blabbering, blubbering character who forgets his mantra in ''Annie Hall.''

He began to suffer from dementia. Eventually he was confined to bed, lying awake in torment. Then he died.

headline1: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHATMAN, BENJAMIN H., M.D.
headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHATMAN, BENJAMIN H., M.D.
lead_paragraph: SCHATMAN-Benjamin H., M.D. On Jan. 31, 2002 of Palm Beach Gardens, FL. Formerly of Short Hills, NJ. Died of complications of Pics Dementia. Beloved husband of Beth, loving father of Jill and (Bill) Manny, Michael and (Roz) Schatman, Karen & (Fred) Benton, adored grandfather of Peter Manny, Hannah Benton and Joshua Schatman. Dr. Schatman was formerly Chief of Colon and Rectal Surgery at St. Barnabas Medical Center in Livingston, NJ. Funeral services will be held at Menorah Chapels, 2950 Vauxhall Rd, Millburn, NJ, Sunday, Feb. 3 at 1 PM. Contributions can be made to Alzheimer's Alliance at Alpert Jewish Family and Childrens Services, 4605 Community Drive, West Palm Beach, Florida, or the Hospice of Palm Beach.

headline1: World Briefing | Americas: Chile: Pinochet Quits Senate
headline2: World Briefing | Americas: Chile: Pinochet Quits Senate
snippet: Gen Augusto Pinochet, increasingly ill, resigns from lifetime seat in Chilean Senate he established for himself when his 17-year dictatorship ended in 1990; photo (S)
lead_paragraph: Gen. Augusto Pinochet, 86 and increasingly ill, has resigned from the lifetime seat in the Senate that he established for himself when his 17-year dictatorship ended in 1990. His action came just days after the Supreme Court ruled that he was suffering from a state of dementia so severe that he is unable to stand trial for human rights abuses that occurred while he was in power. During the long legal battle that preceded the ruling General Pinochet's opponents argued that if he was incapable of facing a trial he was also unfit to hold public office. Larry Rohter (NYT)

headline1: World Briefing | Europe: Austria: Doctor's Medal To Be Revoked
headline2: World Briefing | Europe: Austria: Doctor's Medal To Be Revoked
snippet: Austria to strip Dr Heinrich Gross, 86, who worked at Vienna clinic where nearly 800 mentally and physically handicapped children were experimented upon and put to death during Nazi era, of state medal given to him years after war; he made career ...
lead_paragraph: A doctor who worked at a Vienna clinic where nearly 800 mentally and physically handicapped children were experimented upon and put to death during the Nazi period will be stripped of a state medal given to him years after the war, the government announced. Heinrich Gross, 86, made a postwar career as a neurologist, for which he was given the award, using the brains of the dead children. It was only in 1997, after journalists described the source of his medical library, that Dr. Gross was charged with multiple infanticide. Last year he was declared unfit to stand trial because of dementia.

headline1: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Two Plead Not Guilty To Corruption
headline2: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Two Plead Not Guilty To Corruption
snippet: Former Asbury Park, NJ, council member James Condos and developer Philip Konvitz plead not guilty to corruption charges; they are accused in bribery and extortion scheme involving former city manager Terrance D Weldon, who pleaded guilty to charge...
lead_paragraph: A former Asbury Park council member and a developer pleaded not guilty yesterday to corruption charges involving development in that city, an impoverished seaside community. The council member, James Condos, 47, and the developer, Philip Konvitz, 92, have been accused of a bribery and extortion scheme involving a former city manager, Terrance D. Weldon, who pleaded guilty last month to charges of extorting cash from developers. Prosecutors said they had recorded hundreds of conversations involving the defendants. A lawyer for Mr. Konvitz says his client suffers from dementia and Alzheimer's disease and is incompetent to stand trial. Prosecutors say they will hire and expert to decide whether he is fit for trial. Andrew Jacobs (NYT)

headline1: Getting Dad Off the Road
headline2: SOAPBOX; Getting Dad Off the Road
snippet: Josh Max essay on problems he, his mother and siblings are trying to deal with in persuading his 77-year-old father, who has mild dementia and has had numerous crashes in recent years, to stop driving; drawing (M)
lead_paragraph: WE all knew the next car crash was coming, and could only hope my father wouldn't injure someone's daughter, son, parent or friend when it happened. Short of handcuffing my 77-year-old father to a bedpost, there seemed no way to discourage him from getting behind the wheel of his increasingly battered, smashed and scraped Nissan. He had had at least five crashes in recent years, all involving his inability to stay awake or otherwise focus his attention on the busy highway beyond the driveway of my parents' house in northern Westchester. Miraculously, he had never been hurt save for a black eye and the occasional sore rib.

When you think about it, nice and easy does it every time.

headline1: Maternal Woe
headline2: THE WAY WE LIVE NOW: 2-03-02: THE ETHICIST; Maternal Woe
snippet: Randy Cohen column answers three questions on ethics: what to tell one's mother about her fast-failing memory if she has vowed to commit suicide before entering a nursing home, whether one should allow merchants to give little gift's to one's chil...
lead_paragraph: My 82-year-old mother vows to commit suicide rather than ever go into a nursing home. She is happy, enthusiastic and pain-free. She is also rapidly losing her memory. Claudia Lewis, Berkeley, Calif.

headline1: Checkmating Alzheimer's
headline2: Checkmating Alzheimer's
snippet: Editorial on study that found participation in mentally demanding leisure activities late in life seems to provide protection against Alzheimer's disease and other forms of dementia
lead_paragraph: Can regular games of bridge or chess or playing a musical instrument ward off the onset of Alzheimer's disease and other forms of dementia? That is the provocative implication of a study published in the prestigious New England Journal of Medicine last week. If the findings hold up in more rigorous follow-up inquiries, the day may yet come when doctors will routinely recommend regular mental activity to ward off dementia just as they recommend regular physical exercise to ward off obesity and heart disease.

lead_paragraph: Of all the infirmities people dread in old age, dementia may be the scariest. Many people in their 90's fear declining mental faculties more than they fear death, researchers at the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn., have observed.

headline1: Paid Notice: Deaths   THEISE, LEE
headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths   THEISE, LEE
lead_paragraph: THEISE--Lee (nee Weiss). On October 9, 2003. Widow of Henry. Beloved mother of Joyce Jonas and Richard Theise, grandmother of Jillian Jonas, Stephanie Jonas Stone and Peter Theise, great - grandmother of Charles Kamuti Stone, sister of Stanley Weiss, mother-inlaw of Marti Theise and Gilbert Jonas. Lee was born in Poland and her family left for Palestine in 1933. In 1938 she went to New York City with her father for the World's Fair and was joined by the balance of the family shortly thereafter. She was a member of the Standard Club and the Ahavath Achim Congregation in Atlanta until her husband Henry's death in 1979 and of Temple Emanuel in West Palm Beach for the remainder of her life. She was an active supporter of the Simon Wiesenthal Foundation, ORT, the Jabotinsky Library in Tel Aviv and of several other charities. Lee was an extraordinary woman and will be remembered by all who knew her. The funeral will take place in Atlanta on Tuesday, October 14. In lieu of flowers donations may be sent to the Institute for Brain Aging and Dementia.

headline1: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Accused Will Not Be Tried In Deadly Fire
headline2: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Accused Will Not Be Tried In Deadly Fire
snippet: Judge Elliot Solomon rules that Leslie Andino, 23, is mentally incompetent to stand trial for starting fire in Hartford nursing home that killed 16 residents; Andino will receive psychiatric evalutation and will be evaluated in two months (S)
lead_paragraph: A woman accused of setting a nursing-home fire that led to the deaths of 16 residents, many of them severely disabled, is incompetent to stand trial, a judge ruled yesterday. A Hartford Superior Court judge, Elliot Solomon, ruled that the woman, Leslie Andino, 23, suffers from dementia and depression. After a psychiatric evaluation, Ms. Andino is to undergo further treatment at Connecticut Valley Hospital and will be evaluated again in two months. Ms. Andino told the police that she might have accidentally started the February fire at the Greenwood Health Center while playing with a cigarette lighter. But an investigation later determined that a lighter would have had to be held under sheets for at least 30 seconds to start a fire. Marc Santora (NYT)

headline1: GUILTY PLEA IN ASBURY PARK
headline2: BRIEFS: GOVERNMENT; GUILTY PLEA IN ASBURY PARK
snippet: Former councilman James Condos pleads guilty to federal mail fraud charges in connection with extensive bribery and corruption investigation in Asbury Park and Ocean Township, NJ; says he accepted $25,000 liquor license and nearly $15,000 in cash ...
lead_paragraph: James Condos, a former Asbury Park councilman, pleaded guilty last Monday to two federal counts of mail fraud in connection with an extensive bribery and corruption investigation in Asbury Park and Ocean Township. Mr. Condos said he had accepted a $25,000 liquor license and nearly $15,000 in cash from a developer in exchange for voting the way the developer wanted on several issues. Sentencing was set for Oct. 31. Two other men have pleaded guilty in the investigation, and yet two others are awaiting trial. The developer, Philip Konvitz, 93, has been judged unfit for trial because of Alzheimer's disease and dementia. Karen DeMasters

headline1: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERG, SEYMOUR, M.D.
headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERG, SEYMOUR, M.D.
lead_paragraph: BERG-Seymour, M.D. 4/3/2110/12/02. Seymour Berg, M.D. died on October 12, 2002 at Grosvenor Park Nursing Home in Salem, MA, after a long illness. He was born on April 3, 1921 in the Bronx, to Gustave Berg and Anna Levine Berg. He graduated in 1937 from DeWitt Clinton High School in the Bronx, received a B.A. from N.Y.U. College of Arts and Science in 1941, and obtained a medical degree from N.Y.U. School of Medicine in 1945. After an internship at City Hospital on Welfare Island, he served as 1st Lieutenant and then Captain in the Army Medical Corps AUS, at the V.A. Hospital in Sheridan, WY, where he met his future wife of 33 years, Margaret Irene (Peggy) Walden. Dr. Berg did his residency in psychiatry at Bellevue Psychiatric Hospital, and remained on staff there for over 30 years, ultimately serving as Psychiatric Unit Chief of Ward No. 6 for many years. During that time, he also taught at the N.Y.U. School of Medicine and Hunter College-Bellevue School of Nursing, and maintained a part-time private practice. Dr. Berg served as Honorary Surgeon in Psychiatry to the New York City Police Department and Consulting Psychiatrist to the Triboro Bridge & Tunnel Authority and The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. Dr. Berg was a member of the American, New York and Massachusetts Medical Associations, a member and Fellow of the American Psychiatric Association, a member of the Association for Research in Nervous and Mental Disease and the Society of Biological Psychiatry, and a Diplomate Member and Member of the Council of the Section on Psychiatry & Neurology of the Pan American Medical Association. He also served on the editorial board of the medical journal ''Behavioral Neuropsychiatry''. Dr. Berg was most proud of his teaching and his early research on electroshock therapy. Dr. Berg and his wife Peggy raised their four children in Lake Success, New York, where they lived for 28 years. Peggy predeceased him in 1981; he was later married for several years to Florence Preschel. He was an avid power boater, and was active for many years in the Sands Point Yacht Club (serving as Commodore in 1975), and the Bayshore Power Squadron. Dr. Berg is survived by his daughters Deborah Berg of Seattle, WA, Sherry Berg of Newburyport, MA, Mary Moreau of Waterbury, CT, his son G. David Walden-Berg of Oakland, CA, his brother Sheldon (Buddy) Berg of Northvale, NJ, grandchildren Tyler Fey, Cooper Neal, Hannah Moreau and Esther Moreau, nieces Eileen Berg and nephews Gary Berg, Gerald Berg and Jeffrey Berg. A private service was held and, at his request, his ashes will be strewn in the Long Island Sound. The family requests that any memorial donations be made to the N.Y.U. School of Medicine Office of Development, specifying that the funds be used for research relating to strokes or dementia.

headline2: As More Live Past a Century, 100 Isn't What It Used to Be

headline1: Are You My Mother?
headline2: LIVES; Are You My Mother?
snippet: Floyd Skloot Lives column on trying to cope with his 93-year-old mother's dementia; notes that as she lost memory of all details of her life, even of her son, songs seemed to be last thing to go (M)
lead_paragraph: As recently as eight months ago, though she no longer recognized me, my mother and I could ''talk'' by trading lyrics from the old standards. I would sit beside her, hand on her forearm, and tell her that my father's name was Harry, and she would sing the main phrase from Eubie Blake's ''I'm Just Wild About Harry'' in her still-strong contralto. Saying that it was a beautiful morning elicited a vast smile and the second line of that song's chorus, ''oh, what a beautiful day.'' After almost six decades of her tirades, these light exchanges were a gift.

headline1: Paid Notice: Deaths   SILBERSTEIN, WILLIAM
headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths   SILBERSTEIN, WILLIAM
snippet: SILBERSTEIN--William. The William and Sylvia Silberstein Institute for Aging and Dementia of the New York University School of Medicine mourns the loss of its founder, friend and major benefactor, Mr. William Silberstein. Mr. Silberstein was a hum...
lead_paragraph: SILBERSTEIN--William. The William and Sylvia Silberstein Institute for Aging and Dementia of the New York University School of Medicine mourns the loss of its founder, friend and major benefactor, Mr. William Silberstein. Mr. Silberstein was a humanitarian who contributed to the alleviation of the burden of persons with Alzheimer's disease and their caregivers. He contributed with his personal time, his wisdom and his considerable organizational skills, as well as his resources. As a result of his contributions, there are today improved treatments for and an increased knowledge of this prevalent and devastating condition. Because of his vision, his legacy will include continued progress in the treatment and prevention of brain aging related conditions.

headline1: Metro Briefing | New York: Yonkers: 2 Nurses Accused Of Covering Up Neglect
headline2: Metro Briefing | New York: Yonkers: 2 Nurses Accused Of Covering Up Neglect
snippet: Annamma Thomas and Lynn Mathison, nurses at Guild Home for Aged Blind in Yonkers, are arrested on charges of attempting to cover up accident in which demented patient spilled hot soup on herself and was neglected by Thomas for a hour (S)
lead_paragraph: Two nurses at the Guild Home for the Aged Blind have been arrested on charges of falsifying records in an attempt to cover up the purported neglect of a patient who was burned by hot soup on June 14, Attorney General Eliot Spitzer announced yesterday. After noticing the spilled soup on the patient's lap, Mr. Spitzer contended, a nurse, Annamma Thomas, 59, of Yonkers, pushed the patient, an 84-year-old woman who uses a wheelchair and who suffers from dementia, into a hallway and left her there for an hour. She and another nurse, Lynn Mathison, 53, of Bronxville, allegedly documented that Ms. Thomas had immediately treated the patient, Mr. Spitzer said. The women surrendered to the Yonkers police on Oct. 8 and, according to Ms. Thomas's lawyer, Bruce E. Menken, pleaded not guilty. Kirk Semple (NYT)

headline1: Mrs. Mitchell on Line 3, Something About Watergate
headline2: THEATER REVIEW; Mrs. Mitchell on Line 3, Something About Watergate
snippet: Ben Brantley reviews Public Theater production of John Jeter play Dirty Tricks, directed by Margaret Whitton and starring Judith Ivey; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: Distinguishing between blazing energy and plain old desperation isn't always easy. Look at Martha Mitchell, who teetered so spectacularly between high spirits and dementia as the wife of Attorney General John Mitchell during the Watergate era. Now, in John Jeter's "Dirty Tricks," the redoubtable Judith Ivey has taken on the woman whose eagerness to share secrets and fears with the American people helped bring down the presidency of Richard M. Nixon.

headline1: Life in the Age of Old, Old Age
headline2: Life in the Age of Old, Old Age
snippet: Lee Rosenbaum letter on Feb 22 article on centenarians and their caregivers
lead_paragraph: The ''happy aberration'' of the Blaylock sisters was a breath of fresh air (Susan Dominus, Feb. 22). I could almost hear the sisters laughing and teasing one another. My own sister (whom I've been bossing around only since the Eisenhower administration) and I had our first good laugh since our mother died several months ago at age 92. She was vigorous until age 88 without medical intervention and then joined the 50 percent of the very elderly who suffer from dementia. The last two years of her life were spent in a nursing home, where despite good intentions and daily attention from us, her quality of life declined rapidly. The larger story here, and the sadder one, is how to promote a good quality of life for those in old, old age who arrive there with physical and mental disabilities. Thanks for a thoughtful article.

headline2: Cholesterol Drugs Show No Effect on Dementia Risk
snippet: Those who believe that taking cholesterol-lowering drugs will reduce their risk for Alzheimer's disease may want to reconsider. A large study published yesterday in Archives of Neurology found no proof that the drugs affected the risk of developin...
lead_paragraph: Those who believe that taking cholesterol-lowering drugs will reduce their risk for Alzheimer's disease may want to reconsider. A large study published yesterday in Archives of Neurology found no proof that the drugs affected the risk of developing dementia from any cause -- Alzheimer's, vascular dementia or the two combined.

headline1: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: Rosa Parks's Medical Records
headline2: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: Rosa Parks's Medical Records
snippet: Gregory Reed, lawyer for Rosa Parks, says dementia she has suffered for several years should have no bearing on two suits filed in her name; statement comes day after some of her medical records are released; some of Parks's relatives claim she do...
lead_paragraph: A day after a federal judge made public some medical records of Rosa Parks, the civil rights figure, a lawyer for her said that the dementia she has suffered for several years should have no bearing on two lawsuits filed in her name. The records say that Ms. Parks, who will turn 92 next month, was suffering from progressive dementia in October 2002. On Wednesday, in response to a request by The Detroit Free Press, a federal judge in Detroit released the six pages of medical information. Gregory Reed, the lawyer who filed two lawsuits on Ms. Parks's behalf contending that members of the music industry had used her name in a song without permission, said her medical records should not affect the two related lawsuits, filed in 1999 and 2004. The suits, which named Ms. Parks as the plaintiff, accused the rap group OutKast, BMG and several record companies and music distributors of defamation. But some relatives of Ms. Parks have since expressed doubt that she understood the lawsuits and have said they think she was exploited. Gretchen Reuthling (NYT)

headline1: World Briefing | Americas: Chile: Pinochet Hospitalized
headline2: World Briefing | Americas: Chile: Pinochet Hospitalized
snippet: Gen. Augusto Pinochet, the former dictator, was briefly hospitalized for tests after his family said he might have had a small stroke. General Pinochet, 89, has in the past been declared incompetent to face trial on charges of rights abuses becaus...
lead_paragraph: Gen. Augusto Pinochet, the former dictator, was briefly hospitalized for tests after his family said he might have had a small stroke. General Pinochet, 89, has in the past been declared incompetent to face trial on charges of rights abuses because he suffers from senile dementia stemming from such previous attacks. An appeals court is currently weighing a ruling that would strip him of his legal immunity from trial in connection with $17 million he is said to have illegally obtained and deposited at Riggs Banks and other financial institutions in the United States. Larry Rohter (NYT)

headline1: World Briefing | Americas: Chile: Court Upholds Pinochet Indictment
headline2: World Briefing | Americas: Chile: Court Upholds Pinochet Indictment
snippet: The Supreme Court upheld a judge's ruling last month that Chile's former dictator, Gen. Augusto Pinochet, is competent to stand trial on charges of murder and kidnapping stemming from his role in Operation Condor, a joint campaign set up by South ...
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court upheld a judge's ruling last month that Chile's former dictator, Gen. Augusto Pinochet, is competent to stand trial on charges of murder and kidnapping stemming from his role in Operation Condor, a joint campaign set up by South America's right-wing military dictatorships in the 1970's. In 2001, General Pinochet, 89, was charged in connection with another case of human rights abuses but escaped a trial when his lawyers maintained he was mentally and physically unfit and the Supreme Court upheld that argument after doctors determined he was suffering from what they called "mild dementia," or senility. Larry Rohter (NYT)

headline1: Paid Notice: Deaths   HALPERIN, THEODORE PHILIP
headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths   HALPERIN, THEODORE PHILIP
snippet: HALPERIN--Theodore Philip, in Hanover, NH, from Lewy Body Dementia. Devoted father to Amy Halperin Wood (Denver) and Jonathan Joseph Halperin (Washington, DC). Adoring ''Wampa'' to four grandchildren, Joseph and Max in Denver and Aidan and Isabel ...
lead_paragraph: HALPERIN--Theodore Philip, in Hanover, NH, from Lewy Body Dementia. Devoted father to Amy Halperin Wood (Denver) and Jonathan Joseph Halperin (Washington, DC). Adoring "Wampa" to four grandchildren, Joseph and Max in Denver and Aidan and Isabel in Washington; caring brother to Eliot Jules Halperin; loving husband to the late Betty Ann Joseph Halperin. A lawyer committed to community service, his smile and quiet warmth, his high standards, and his enduring dignity will be missed by many. A family funeral service in New Hampshire immediately followed his death. An open Service of Remebrance will take place on Sunday, February 20, at the Mark Hotel, 27 East 77th Street, at 11 o'clock in the morning. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his name can be sent to the Riverdale Mental Health Association, Jewish Family Service of Colorado, and the Study Circles Resource Center (Pomfret, CT).

headline1: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALCINDOR, FERDINAND L.
headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALCINDOR, FERDINAND L.
snippet: ALCINDOR -- Ferdinand L. Father of NBA legend and Hall of Famer Kareem Abdul Jabbar, died on December 9 at 3:00 P.M. EST at Coney Island Hospital in Coney Island, NY, from organ failure after a long bout with senile dementia. He was 86. A decorate...
lead_paragraph: ALCINDOR -- Ferdinand L. Father of NBA legend and Hall of Famer Kareem Abdul Jabbar, died on December 9 at 3:00 P.M. EST at Coney Island Hospital in Coney Island, NY, from organ failure after a long bout with senile dementia. He was 86. A decorated member of the NYPD and veteran of the United States Armed Forces from 1941-1945, Mr. Alcindor received three commendations for outstanding police work as a patrolman in 1961 and then as a lieutenant in 1966 and 1978. In addition, he was awarded a medal at City Hall by New York City Mayor Abraham D. Beame. An avid musician, Mr. Alcindor brought his talents on the trombone to the New York Transit Authority Police Band, even playing at the 1962 Democratic National Convention. His musical talents also led to his involvement in one of the most famous events in U.S. history, as Mr. Alcindor was in attendance as a band member when Marilyn Monroe serenaded President John F. Kennedy with "Happy Birthday" at Madison Square Garden on May 19, 1962, an event, according to his son, he never forgot. Born in Brooklyn, NY, Mr. Alcindor attended Franklin K. Lane High School where he teamed with legendary Knicks coach Red Holzman on the school's handball team that captured the city championship. He followed that up by attending the Juilliard School to pursue his career ambitions of becoming a musician. Hopeful of one day playing with the Count Basie Band, Mr. Alcindor enjoyed working with some of the musical giants of his time, including Dizzy Gillespie, Art Blakey, Kenny Durham, Al Gray and Tito Puente. He also had a stint playing with the Benny Carter Band in the late 70's and early 80's. Married for 53 years, Mr. Alcindor's wife, Cora, passed away eight years ago. He is survived by his son, Kareem; and five grandchildren.

headline1: Paperback Row
headline2: Paperback Row
snippet: DRESS YOUR FAMILY IN CORDUROY AND DENIM, by David Sedaris. (Back Bay/Little, Brown, $14.95.) Sedaris's latest collection of essays revives the themes that have made him one of America's pre-eminent humorists: his family's gentle dementia; his year...
lead_paragraph: DRESS YOUR FAMILY IN CORDUROY AND DENIM, by David Sedaris. (Back Bay/Little, Brown, $14.95.) Sedaris's latest collection of essays revives the themes that have made him one of America's pre-eminent humorists: his family's gentle dementia; his years spent wandering in obscurity; his life in France with his boyfriend. This volume, like "Naked" (1997) and "Me Talk Pretty One Day" (2000), is often hilarious -- but it is also more introspective. In one essay, "Repeat After Me," Sedaris agonizes over using his family for raw material; he imagines training his sister's parrot to say: "Forgive me. Forgive me. Forgive me."

headline1: A Shadowy Realm Ill-Met by Moonlight
headline2: CABARET REVIEW; A Shadowy Realm Ill-Met by Moonlight
snippet: Stephen Holden reviews cabaret performance by singer Ute Lemper at Cafe Carlyle; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: No sooner has the German cabaret singer Ute Lemper begun her "Moon Medley," the centerpiece of her new show, "Blood and Feathers" at the Cafe Carlyle, than it is apparent that the lunar glow that has floated so wistfully through American popular music for decades may not look so benign from the other side of the Atlantic. In the medley, the fearless theatrical diva reinvents familiar songs by vocally emphasizing the associations of moonlight with vampirism and dementia, rather than Junes and spoons.

headline1: Nonfiction Chronicle
headline2: NONFICTION CHRONICLE
snippet: EARLY BIRD. By Rodney Rothman. (Simon & Schuster, $23.) Here's hoping that Rothman has overcome his nasty fabrication habit, because if the stories and people in his new book, ''Early Bird,'' are real, he has produced a warm, wry bit of reportage....
lead_paragraph: EARLY BIRD. By Rodney Rothman. (Simon & Schuster, $23.) Here's hoping that Rothman has overcome his nasty fabrication habit, because if the stories and people in his new book, "Early Bird," are real, he has produced a warm, wry bit of reportage. Rothman earned some ignominy in 2000 when an article he wrote for The New Yorker turned out to have fictions mixed in with its facts, causing the magazine to run an apology. That article involved his posing as an employee at a dot-com company, and in "Early Bird" Rodman poses again, in a way: he retires to Florida, in his late 20's, moving into a Century Village senior citizens' complex. Rothman manages to be both an observer of these strange beings about three times his age and a sad-sack newcomer trying to blend in with them. He is working a bit of a stereotype, but his descriptions of the loneliness, the cliquishness, the slow-motion desperation of the place ring true and bittersweet. Most surprising is that his tales contain not an ounce of mean-spiritedness -- this from someone who once wrote for David Letterman. "Young people often think old people all look the same," he writes in a passage typical of his tone, "but that misconception works both ways. To elderly people, young people merge into one tender pink blob. Elderly people always seem to think I am 18 or 19, which is flattering until I remember that their eyesight is failing and that a certain percentage of them suffer from dementia." Can't wait for the sitcom, which is already in the pilot stage.

headline2: FILM REVIEW; So Easy to Forget Murder, Unless You Write It Down
snippet: Manohla Dargis reviews movie The Memory of a Killer, directed by Erik Van Looy and starring Koen De Bouw, Jan Decleir and Werner De Smedt; photos (M)
lead_paragraph: In that pretzel twist of a thriller "Memento" there's an irresistible scene in which the amnesiac hero played by Guy Pearce runs at breakneck speed. First, the amnesiac wonders what he is doing and then he decides he's chasing another man, only to realize -- just before the other guy squeezes off a round in his direction -- that he is being chased in turn. In the rather less twisty, if nicely kinked Belgian thriller "The Memory of a Killer," the title character faces his own dangerous adversary, except that here the enemy hot on his heels is dementia.

headline1: Staying in the Ring
headline2: THE LIVES THEY LIVED; Staying in the Ring: MIKE QUARRY b. 1951
snippet: Jonathan Mahler article pays tribute to Mike Quarry, brother of heavyweight boxer Jerry Quarry and light-heavyweight himself, who died of dementia in 2006 at age 55; photo (L)
lead_paragraph: Jack Quarry laced his third son, Mike, into boxing gloves when he was scarcely out of diapers, just as he had Mike's two older brothers, Jimmy and Jerry. As a teenager in Los Angeles in the 1960s, Mike didn't hang out after school at the beach or the local soda shop. He skipped rope and punched heavy bags in a filthy, sweat-soaked boxing gym over an abandoned movie theater on the edge of skid row. In 1968, he fought 28 amateur bouts. And within weeks of his 18th birthday in 1969 -- the year of Apollo 11, Woodstock and Chappaquiddick -- he knocked out Butch McCarthy in his first professional fight.

headline1: Diagnosing With Dickens
headline2: THE WAY WE LIVE NOW: 12-17-06: DIAGNOSIS; Diagnosing With Dickens
snippet: Lisa Sanders column on whether hallucinations, facial rigidity and stiff gait that Dickens gives to Ebenezer Scrooge in A Christmas Carol would suggest modern diagnosis; says symptoms perfectly describe Lewy body dementia, which lies at intersecti...
lead_paragraph: A lonely old man sits at home one Christmas Eve and has a series of unexpected visitors: the restless spirit of his long-dead business partner, followed by the ghosts of Christmas Past, Present and Future. By morning, this wretched, miserly recluse has been transformed into the season's icon of exuberant celebration. This is, of course, the story of Ebenezer Scrooge -- the way Charles Dickens wrote it in his novella "A Christmas Carol." But there's another way to tell this familiar tale: an elderly man with no known medical problems has a sudden change in mental status characterized by confusion and vivid hallucinations involving friends and relatives, which leaves him in a state of trembling mania and uncharacteristic euphoria. This also describes Ebenezer Scrooge -- but as a doctor might see him. What caused these extraordinary symptoms? a doctor might ask. Could some pathological process have accounted for Scrooge's remarkable experience?

headline1: Mr. Shtick
headline2: Mr. Shtick
snippet: Brian Gari letter on Adrian Nicole LeBlac's Dec 25 article on late comic Gene Baylos
lead_paragraph: It was gratifying to see that Gene Baylos's death was not overlooked (Adrian Nicole LeBlanc). When I was a struggling songwriter in 1971, living at a rather inexpensive motel on the Sunset Strip in Los Angeles, I would wander into the lobby and see comics of years gone by commenting on who was going to get a spot on "The Joey Bishop Show" that week. Gene Baylos was among them, and we struck up a conversation and a friendship. He was 65, and I was 19. When I returned to New York, I would see Gene on the corner of 55th Street and Seventh Avenue for many years. He always remembered me. . .until a few years ago, when I heard he was at the Jewish Home for the Aged, where my father was recovering from open-heart surgery. While visiting my father, I stopped by Gene's room. When I was introduced by his nurse, he didn't remember me anymore. Age and dementia had set in.

headline1: The Global Deterioration Scale for Assessment of Primary Degenerative Dementia
lead_paragraph: Stage 1: No cognitive impairment Unimpaired individuals experience no memory problems and none are evident to a health care professional during a medical interview. Stage 2: Very mild cognitive decline Individuals at this stage feel as if they have memory lapses, especially in forgetting familiar words or names or the location of keys, eyeglasses or other everyday objects. But these problems are not evident during a medical examination or apparent to friends, family or co-workers. Stage 3: Mild cognitive decline Friends, family or co-workers begin to notice deficiencies. Problems with memory or concentration may be measurable in clinical testing or discernible during a detailed medical interview. Common difficulties include: • Word- or name-finding problems noticeable to family or close associates • Decreased ability to remember names when introduced to new people • Performance issues in social or work settings noticeable to family, friends or co-workers • Reading a passage and retaining little material • Losing or misplacing a valuable object • Decline in ability to plan or organize Stage 4: Moderate cognitive decline At this stage, a careful medical interview detects clear-cut deficiencies in the following areas: • Decreased knowledge of recent occasions or current events • Impaired ability to perform challenging mental arithmetic-for example, to count backward from 100 by 7s • Decreased capacity to perform complex tasks, such as marketing, planning dinner for guests or paying bills and managing finances • Reduced memory of personal history • The affected individual may seem subdued and withdrawn, especially in socially or mentally challenging situations Stage 5: Moderately severe cognitive decline Major gaps in memory and deficits in cognitive function emerge. Some assistance with day-to-day activities becomes essential. At this stage, individuals may: • Be unable during a medical interview to recall such important details as their current address, their telephone number or the name of the college or high school from which they graduated • Become confused about where they are or about the date, day of the week, or season • Have trouble with less challenging mental arithmetic; for example, counting backward from 40 by 4s or from 20 by 2s • Need help choosing proper clothing for the season or the occasion • Usually retain substantial knowledge about themselves and know their own name and the names of their spouse or children • Usually require no assistance with eating or using the toilet Stage 6: Severe cognitive decline Memory difficulties continue to worsen, significant personality changes may emerge and affected individuals need extensive help with customary daily activities. At this stage, individuals may: • Lose most awareness of recent experiences and events as well as of their surroundings • Recollect their personal history imperfectly, although they generally recall their own name • Occasionally forget the name of their spouse or primary caregiver but generally can distinguish familiar from unfamiliar faces • Need help getting dressed properly; without supervision, may make such errors as putting pajamas over daytime clothes or shoes on wrong feet • Experience disruption of their normal sleep/waking cycle • Need help with handling details of toileting (flushing toilet, wiping and disposing of tissue properly) • Have increasing episodes of urinary or fecal incontinence • Experience significant personality changes and behavioral symptoms, including suspiciousness and delusions (for example, believing that their caregiver is an impostor); hallucinations (seeing or hearing things that are not really there); or compulsive, repetitive behaviors such as hand-wringing or tissue shredding • Tend to wander and become lost Stage 7: Very severe cognitive decline This is the final stage of the disease when individuals lose the ability to respond to their environment, the ability to speak and, ultimately, the ability to control movement. • Frequently individuals lose their capacity for recognizable speech, although words or phrases may occasionally be uttered • Individuals need help with eating and toileting and there is general incontinence of urine • Individuals lose the ability to walk without assistance, then the ability to sit without support, the ability to smile, and the ability to hold their head up. Reflexes become abnormal and muscles grow rigid. Swallowing is impaired.

headline1: Walter Mosleys Three-Book Deal
headline2: Walter Mosleys Three-Book Deal
snippet: The novelist Walter Mosley has signed a three-book deal with Riverhead Books.
lead_paragraph: The novelist Walter Mosley has signed a three-book deal with Riverhead Books, a unit of Penguin Group, to publish a literary novel and two books in a new mystery series featuring Leonid McGill, an African-American detective in New York City who first appeared in a short story included in “Best American Mystery Stories of 2006.” In an interview Mr. Mosley, right, said that the new character “couldn’t get more different from Easy Rawlins if you tried.” (He was referring to the detective who has appeared in 11 of his 27 books.) The new series, Mr. Mosley said, would be “very noir and contemporary and New York.” He has already completed the literary novel “Last Days of Ptolemy Grey,” about the relationship between an old African-American man with dementia and a 17-year-old girl. Sean McDonald, executive editor at Riverhead, acquired world rights to the three books from Gloria Loomis, Mr. Mosley’s agent. The first book in the new mystery series will be published in 2009.

headline1: ‘The Almost Moon’
snippet: “When all is said and done, killing my mother came easily. Dementia, as it descends, has a way of revealing the core of the person affected by it.”
lead_paragraph: When all is said and done, killing my mother came easily. Dementia, as it descends, has a way of revealing the core of the person affected by it. My mother's core was rotten like the brackish water at the bottom of a weeks-old vase of flowers. She had been beautiful when my father met her and still capable of love when I became their late-in-life child, but by the time she gazed up at me that day, none of this mattered.

headline1: Letters: Recipe Redux: Teddie’s Apple Cake
headline2: Recipe Redux: Teddie’s Apple Cake
snippet: Is my co-author Tony Flew “all there” mentally? The only reason that people ask questions about his mental faculties is that he dared to change his mind. He believes in God and therefore he has dementia, or he has dementia and therefore he believe...
lead_paragraph: I’ve been baking what I call Jean Hewitt’s version of the cake since 1973, when, as a junior in college, I read the recipe in The Times Magazine (Amanda Hesser, Nov. 4). The cake is delicious, easy to make and affordable — and thus proved useful to me as a college student, graduate student, young professional and working mother. The serving of this cake (at dinner parties, potluck suppers, fund-raisers at my children’s schools) always elicits requests for the recipe, which I have amended over the years to include some brown sugar, a bit of whole-wheat flour, lots of vanilla, more cinnamon, nutmeg, a variety of raisins and about twice as many apples. Tart are best, as you note. The cake also freezes well, but that rarely happens. Years ago, a roommate wrote on the recipe I clipped from the magazine — “Let cool before inhaling the entire cake.”

headline1: In an Unlikely Place, a Family Mom Never Imagined
headline2: In an Unlikely Place, a Family Mom Never Imagined
snippet: A woman who once thought that a nursing home meant a barren, paltry, isolated existence realized that for her mother, being there signified community.
lead_paragraph: FIVE years ago I promised my mother that I would never place her in a nursing home. “I couldn’t abide one of those places,” she had said. She was 78 at the time. At her younger brother’s urging, she had bought a long-term health care policy, and the possibility of not being able to live on her own had reared its head. Back then, my mother lived next door to me in Southampton. She was in good health, a vibrant dresser who liked to walk the half-mile into town when the weather was good.

All she did was use an M.R.I. to find the place in the brain where the ability to detect sarcasm resides. But then, you probably already knew it was in the right parahippocampal gyrus.

headline1: Partial Recall
headline2: Partial Recall
snippet: Sue Halpern finds out what scientists know about dementia.
lead_paragraph: Behind all the good-natured joking about “senior moments” lies real frustration and fear. How empowering, then, that we can do something to ward off normal, age-related memory loss: exercise. No, it’s not as easy as popping a pill. But as Sue Halpern reports in “Can’t Remember What I Forgot,” even a few brisk walks per week can have a measurable effect. Exercise promotes the birth of new neurons in the very part of the hippocampus (a brain structure crucial to forming new memories) that begins to malfunction with age. Exercise also counters age-related shrinking of the prefrontal cortex, an area involved in concentration and working memory (as in remembering a phone number long enough to dial).

headline2: Antibiotics Questioned In Care At Life’s End
snippet: A yearlong study is raising questions about the widespread use of antibiotics in nursing homes to treat infections in patients with terminal dementia.
lead_paragraph: A yearlong study is raising questions about the widespread use of antibiotics in nursing homes to treat infections in patients with terminal dementia  a treatment that the authors suggest is of dubious value to the patients and may be dangerous in the long run.

headline1: Marriage, Divorce and Alzheimer's Risk
headline2: Marriage, Divorce and Alzheimer's Risk
snippet: Becoming single in midlife through death or divorce dramatically increases risk for dementia in the older years.
lead_paragraph: (Photo: (Credit:Benjamin Sklar/Associated Press))   Whether you are single or divorced in midlife appears to influence your risk of developing Alzheimer's and other forms of dementia as you age.  It's long been known that social relationships can decrease the risk of developing dementia. In June, Harvard researchers reported how active socializing in old age could delay memory problems.   But most research on social relationships and dementia measures the social life of the very old. The newest study, presented at the 2008 Alzheimer's Association International Conference on Alzheimer's Disease in Chicago, focused on the effect relationships in midlife may have on long-term risk. It tracked 2,000 men and women in Finland beginning at the age of 50 and followed up with them 21 years later.   They found that people who were living with a spouse or a partner in midlife ran a 50 percent lower risk of developing dementia during their older years than people living alone. How long a person had been single and the reason they were single also affected risk. Living alone for your entire adult life doubled risk, but those who had been married and then divorced and remained single in midlife showed three times the risk.  Those at greatest risk of developing dementia were people who had lost their partner before middle age and then continued to live as a widow or widower. The study showed that these individuals had a six times greater chance of developing Alzheimer's than those who were married.  "This suggests two influencing factors -- social and intellectual stimulation and trauma," said lead author Krister Håkansson, a psychology researcher at Växjö University and the Karolinska Institute in Sweden. "In practice, it shows how important it is to put resources into helping people who have undergone a crisis."  Dr. Håkansson said future research will focus on whether risk is influenced by the quality of the relationship or whether someone always intended to live a single life or not.

headline1: Marriage, Divorce and Alzheimer’s Risk
snippet: Becoming single in midlife through death or divorce dramatically increases risk for dementia in the older years.
lead_paragraph: Whether you are single or divorced in midlife appears to influence your risk of developing Alzheimer’s and other forms of dementia as you age.

headline1: Robert Katzman, Alzheimer’s Activist, Dies at 82
headline2: Robert Katzman, Alzheimer’s Activist, Dies at 82
snippet: Dr. Katzman redefined Alzheimer’s disease as a major public health problem and as the most frequent progressive form of dementia in aging.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Robert Katzman, the neurologist, researcher and medical activist who redefined Alzheimer’s disease as a major public health problem and as the most frequent progressive form of dementia in aging, died Sept. 16 at his home in San Diego. He was 82.

headline1: Don’t Close the Door on the Wives of Ex-Players
headline2: Don’t Close the Door on the Wives of Ex-Players
snippet: A meeting of former N.F.L. players to discuss health issues like dementia took place behind closed doors. But at least there was a discussion.
lead_paragraph: The wives already know the dangers from football. The wives are the ones who manage their husbands when they spin out of control, who feed them and dress them and clean them and do the paperwork and ultimately find nursing care for them.

headline1: Thatcher’s Open Secret
headline2: Margaret Thatcher's Open Secret
snippet: Former British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher has dementia, her daughter says. Is it right to discuss her condition publicly?
lead_paragraph: A colleague in The Times's London bureau, Sarah Lyall, has just published a book called "The Anglo Files: A Field Guide to the British,'' a cross-cultural look at what makes the British British, as seen though the eyes of an American expatriate with an English husband whom she describes as "something out of 'Brideshead Revisited'.'' Given Ms. Lyall's perspective, I asked her thoughts on the recent revelation that former Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, like President Ronald Reagan before her, is losing her mind and her memories to a form of dementia. Here are her observations, with a link to the story that is striking a chord on both sides of the Atlantic. -- Jane Gross  (Photo: President Ronald Reagan and British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher in 1984. Mrs. Thatcher's daughter recently has been criticized for publicly discussing her mother's dementia. (Associated Press))   In Britain, it has long been an open secret that former prime minister Margaret Thatcher has been sliding into dementia. "Open" because old friends and political allies can all see the changes in the proud woman known as the Iron Lady, particularly since she suffered a series of mini-strokes in 2002 and withdrew from public speaking on her doctors' advice. And "secret" because no one has spoken publicly about it.   Until now. Last month her daughter, Carol Thatcher, revealed all to a newspaper, The Mail on Sunday. In an excerpt from her forthcoming memoir, "A Swim-On Part in the Goldfish Bowl," Carol Thatcher not only announced that her mother, now 82, is suffering from dementia but offered excruciating evidence.   Sometimes Mrs. Thatcher forgets what she has eaten for breakfast, her daughter wrote. Once she conflated the Falklands War with the Bosnian conflict. Cruelly, she has had to be reminded repeatedly that her beloved husband, Denis, is dead. (He died in 2003.)  Carol Thatcher's heartbreak at seeing her formidable mother reduced to a confused old woman is all too familiar to anyone caring for a friend or relative suffering a similar fate. But Mrs. Thatcher is an iconic and larger-than-life figure -- "far more than the sum of her parts," Vanessa Feltz wrote in the Daily Express -- and Britain is still a country where privacy, particularly in matters of health, is valued. Many people have reacted angrily to Carol Thatcher's disclosures.   In The Daily Telegraph, Andrew Pierce noted that Mrs. Thatcher's friends had purposely kept silent, in order to "preserve the great lady's dignity and grace in a quiet, discreet way." In The Daily Express, Anne Widdecombe, a Tory M.P., said, "The only consolation, perhaps, is that Margaret Thatcher almost certainly does not know what her daughter has done." And in The Sun, Kelvin MacKenzie raised the issue of who owns the reputation of a public figure like Mrs. Thatcher -- her family or the wider world?   "My question is: why did Carol think it right to reveal her mother's plight, especially when none of her political friends had ever done so even in their political books?" he asked. "I can only conclude it was done for money. I hope she feels proud of herself." And across the Atlantic, Ronald Reagan Jr. -- whose father publicly announced at age 82 that he was suffering from Alzheimer's disease -- called Carol Thatcher's detailed account "in monumentally bad taste and unnecessary."   But the debate doesn't end there.   On the one hand, it does seem to violate a proud woman's privacy to describe the sad diminishment of her formidable powers, particularly when she doesn't seem capable -- as President Reagan was -- of making the disclosures herself. On the other hand, it makes her poignantly human. Many of our parents will, in the end, suffer what she is suffering; many of us will, too, when our turn comes.   So why the secrecy and shame? Many people who have written to the British papers and posted on various Web sites have made robust arguments for speaking openly about one of the great taboos of our time. As a friend of mine put it, "If you refuse to talk about it, you're treating it as something shameful," once the common response to cancer.   My friend is acquainted with a 71-year-old woman whose mind is slipping. Her husband knows it; her acquaintances know it; she herself knows it on some level, despite her doctor's euphemistic diagnosis. She anxiously asks whether she is repeating things (she is) and frets that she is forgetting what she used to remember (she is).   But she refuses to confront the obvious, and her friends have all been forced to join this conspiracy of silence. This means there is a lot of speculating and gossiping about her condition. How bad is it? Can we bring it up with her husband? What plans is she making for the future? At the same time, there is no real chance to acknowledge the reality or commiserate with the family's pain.

headline1: Prowling the Ponzi Archives
snippet: Following up on the earlier discussion of exit strategies for Ponzi schemes, a look at archival coverage of the eponymous Charles Ponzi’s downfall.
lead_paragraph: Earlier today I wrote about what the architects of Ponzi schemes — which, by definition, cannot end — might envision their exit strategies to be. After looking through The Times’s archival coverage of the eponymous Charles Ponzi’s downfall, I realized I left out another strategy: claiming “financial dementia.”
