headline1: Football May Take a Toll on the Brain, Even Without Concussions
headline2: New Study of Football’s Toll on Brain
snippet: The brains of college football players showed signs of “fraying” after a season of play.
lead_paragraph: After a season of college football, portions of players’ brains can show worrying signs of damage, even if they did not experience a concussion, according to a timely new study of contact sports and brain health. headline1: Germs in Your Gut Are Talking to Your Brain. Scientists Want to Know What They’re Saying.
headline2: Beyond a Gut Feeling

headline1: How the Author of ‘Genius Foods’ Spends His Sundays
headline2: A Healthy Approach to ‘The Genius Life’
snippet: Max Lugavere starts every day with a glass of water and ends it with putting on his blue blockers. In between, he forces himself to work on his book, and he hangs out with his brothers, who live in the same building.
lead_paragraph: Max Lugavere is the author of “Genius Foods,” a book about optimizing brain function through diet. The subject became personal for him when his mother, Kathy, was given a diagnosis of dementia seven years ago, and he devoted himself to her care. She died last winter. “Now that Mom is gone, I am even more obsessed with the topic,” he said. Mr. Lugavere, 36, is currently working on his second book and also has a podcast, “The Genius Life.” He lives with his brother Ben, 30, a software engineer, and his cat, Delilah, in the Murray Hill neighborhood of Manhattan. Their brother Andrew, 33, lives in the same building and works in sales.

headline1: In Life, She Defied Alzheimer’s. In Death, Her Brain May Show How.

headline1: When Dementia Meets the Coronavirus Crisis

headline1: Can Hearing Aids Help Prevent Dementia?
headline2: Can Hearing Aids Help Prevent Dementia?
snippet: Research suggests that paying more attention to the “invisible disability” of hearing loss might improve our brains.
lead_paragraph: Hearing loss has long been considered a normal, and thus acceptable, part of aging. It is common: Estimates suggest that it affects two out of three adults age 70 and older. It is also rarely treated. In the U.S., only about 14 percent of adults who have hearing loss wear hearing aids. An emerging body of research, however, suggests that diminished hearing may be a significant risk factor for Alzheimer’s disease and other forms of dementia — and that the association between hearing loss and cognitive decline potentially begins at very low levels of impairment.

headline1: Daily Aspirin Does Not Lower Alzheimer’s Risk
headline2: Mind: Daily Aspirin and Alzheimer’s
snippet: Older men and women who took low-dose aspirin did not show improvements in memory or a lower risk of dementia.
lead_paragraph: There is good evidence that a daily baby aspirin reduces the risk for heart disease and stroke, and some have thought its inflammation-lowering effect might also help in delaying cognitive decline. But taking a daily low-dose aspirin did not appear to be effective in lowering the risk of Alzheimer’s disease or other forms of dementia, a new study reports.

headline1: Moderate Drinking Tied to Lower Levels of Alzheimer’s Brain Protein
headline2: Mind: Drinking and Alzheimer’s

headline1: Stanley Cohen, Nobelist, Dies at 97; Made Breakthrough on Cell Growth

headline2: Absences Haunt Amateur Sleuth As Clarity Fades

lead_paragraph: The BBC television movie “Elizabeth Is Missing” — a stand-alone episode of “Masterpiece” on PBS this Sunday — contains Glenda Jackson’s first screen performance since 1992. That certainly merits attention — Jackson, now 84, is one of the most technically accomplished and ferociously intelligent actresses of our time. Did it merit the rapturous British reviews on its release in 2019 and perhaps inevitable awards, including a BAFTA and an international Emmy, that she received for it? Not really, but it isn’t Jackson’s fault.

headline1: What Do I Owe My Difficult Mother-in-Law?
headline2: What Do I Owe My Difficult Mother-in-Law?
snippet: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on why offering regular help creates sometimes unwelcome obligations of its own — and more.
lead_paragraph: My husband’s father passed away not long ago, leaving behind a wife. They were together for decades, but she was never beloved by the three stepchildren, and she never had children of her own. A person she considers a “nephew” lives in the same city we do and encouraged her to move to be near him. She couldn’t stay in her home alone as she was showing mild signs of dementia, and there was evidence, such as unpaid bills, that she was not managing her affairs well. We assisted her in moving across the country, and she is residing in a very nice senior community. We manage her finances and health care and visit a few times a month. The “nephew” does visit her, but nothing more, and has asked for financial support a few times since she moved. She is not an easy person in some regards; for example, she broods about perceived slights and then wants to change her will to cut out the person she feels slighted her (this is a chronic issue). My question is, what are our ongoing obligations, if any, to this person? Name Withheld

headline2: N.F.L. Plan Drops Race In Gauging Dementia
snippet: The revised agreement eliminates race as a consideration in evaluating dementia claims by former players.
lead_paragraph: After months of haggling, the N.F.L. and lawyers representing Black players who accused the league of discrimination filed a joint proposal that will scrap the use of a race-based method to evaluate dementia claims made by former players in the league’s concussion settlement.

headline1: Seeking Early Signals of Dementia in Driving and Credit Scores
headline2: Seeking Dementia Signals in Everyday Behavior
snippet: The pathologies underlying brain decline can begin years before symptoms emerge. Can everyday behavior provide warning?
lead_paragraph: Learning your odds of eventually developing dementia — a pressing concern for many, especially those with a family history of it — requires medical testing and counseling. But what if everyday behavior, like overlooking a couple of credit card payments or habitually braking while driving, could foretell your risk?

headline1: Turning to Books to Grasp the Most Ungraspable Disease
headline2: The Devil of Dementia
snippet: Sandeep Jauhar offers a tour of books about Alzheimer’s, from the search for a cure to fictionalized accounts of living with this scourge.
lead_paragraph: When my family moved to the United States in 1976, the country was in the midst of what could be called the Great Alzheimer’s Awakening. Research conducted that decade suggested that dementia, far from being rare, was actually one of the leading causes of death in American society — just behind heart disease and cancer.

headline1: Earlier Diabetes Onset Could Raise Dementia Risk
headline2: Mind: Diabetes and Dementia Risk
snippet: The younger the age at diagnosis for Type 2 diabetes, the higher the risk for Alzheimer’s disease and other forms of dementia years later.
lead_paragraph: Type 2 diabetes is a chronic, progressive illness that can have devastating complications, including hearing loss, blindness, heart disease, stroke, kidney failure and vascular damage so severe as to require limb amputation. Now a new study underscores the toll that diabetes may take on the brain. It found that Type 2 diabetes is linked to an increased risk for Alzheimer’s disease and other forms of dementia later in life, and the younger the age at which diabetes is diagnosed, the greater the risk.

headline2: Mediator to Explore Claims  Of Bias in Concussion Deal

headline1: Judge John Hodgman on Faking a Sacramento Kings Championship Game
headline2: Bonus Advice From Judge John Hodgman
snippet: The real thing is unlikely to happen. Why not make him happy in the meantime?
lead_paragraph: Merany writes: My father wants to see the Sacramento Kings play in an N.B.A. championship game before he dies. This is unlikely. He worries that should he develop dementia, my sisters and I will take him to a regular Kings game and tell him it’s the finals. He has told us not to do this, but we think it would make him happy anyway.

headline1: ‘The Father’ Review: A Capricious Mind
headline2: Lost in the Dark Corners  Of Mind and Memory
snippet: Anthony Hopkins gives a scalding performance as a man stricken by dementia in this clever drama.
lead_paragraph: At once stupendously effective and profoundly upsetting, “The Father” might be the first movie about dementia to give me actual chills. On its face a simple, uncomfortably familiar story about the heartbreaking mental decline of a beloved parent, this first feature from the French novelist and playwright Florian Zeller plays with perspective so cleverly that maintaining any kind of emotional distance is impossible.

headline1: How Staying Physically Active May Protect the Aging Brain
headline2: Physical Activity and Aging Brains
snippet: Simple activities like walking boost immune cells in the brain that may help to keep memory sharp and even ward off Alzheimer’s disease.
lead_paragraph: Staying physically active as we age substantially drops our risk of developing dementia during our lifetimes, and it doesn’t require prolonged exercise. Walking or moving about, rather than sitting, may be all it takes to help bolster the brain, and a new study of octogenarians from Chicago may help to explain why.

headline1: The Loneliest Room, for My Sister in a Nursing Home
snippet: The pandemic has stolen away the chance to surround the sister we are losing to dementia with our love, so that she does not have to face death alone.
lead_paragraph: When I saw my sister Peggy in her nursing home last June, she was sitting up in bed, leaning forward slightly and staring into the corner of her room. She was 67, and did not know who I was. It had been five months since my last trip to see her. That time, she was in a hospital psychiatric unit being re-evaluated for treatment for both bipolar disorder and Alzheimer’s disease. It had taken her a moment to recognize me then, but once she did she hugged me and kept up a stream of chatter as we walked laps around the floor.

headline1: Tiny Love Stories: ‘My Body Told a Different Story’
snippet: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
lead_paragraph: The day my 80-year-old mother announced she was moving to my town for the rest of her life, I was so shaken, I couldn’t remember how to set the table. Three thousand miles separated us for a reason. She had betrayed and refused to support me at the worst moment of my life. Two decades later, she and her dementia arrived, challenging me to cross a chasm of ambivalence and distrust so I could become the daughter she needed. Her decline pushed every button I had, but before she died, my rusty, wounded heart cracked open. — Laura Davis

headline1: ‘I Feel Like I’m Just Drowning’: Sophomore Year in a Pandemic
headline2: ‘I Feel Like I’m Just Drowning’
snippet: A group of high school students try desperately to make it through an isolated and dire year.
lead_paragraph: On Aug. 11, Sarah, a cheerleader at Hickman High School in Columbia, Mo., turned 16 and passed her driving test. Triumphant, she arrived home to a Happy Birthday sign in the front yard, a treat of beignets from a Creole restaurant and the news that her 17-year-old brother did not have pinkeye, as their mother initially suspected, but Covid-19. They all did, it turned out: Sarah, who asked to be identified by her middle name to protect her privacy; her brother; their 85-year-old grandfather; and their mother, a nurse practitioner who started having trouble breathing two days after her son tested positive. Sarah had thought she would first take advantage of her license to drive herself to cheerleading practice; instead, she used it to take her mother to get a coronavirus test, when her mother realized she was already too weak to drive herself. Then, a week later, Sarah’s mother — who had not been leaving the couch and was having trouble finishing her sentences — told her she needed to be driven to the hospital. Her pastor and other members of her church would be checking in, but Sarah would have to look after everyone. That meant taking care of her grandfather, who had Parkinson’s disease and some dementia, and her brother, who had autism. Could she do that? Sarah, whose eyes had grown wide, quickly recovered. Yes, she told her mother. Of course she could.

headline1: ATHENA NEUROSCIENCES SHARES JUMP ON ALZHEIMER'S TEST
headline2: COMPANY NEWS; ATHENA NEUROSCIENCES SHARES JUMP ON ALZHEIMER'S TEST
lead_paragraph: Shares of Athena Neurosciences Inc. surged 50 percent yesterday after the company said it had developed a test to look for a protein that indicates if a person has a greater risk of developing Alzheimer's disease. The stock closed at $13.50, up $4.50, in Nasdaq trading. Athena, based in South San Francisco, Calif., said the test was recommended only for individuals who are already showing possible symptoms of the disease. The test looks for ApoE4, a protein in the blood, whose presence increases the probability that a patient will develop the disease.

lead_paragraph: DICK CAFFERY walks around the circular hallway, past the windows with the expansive view of a day unfolding outside, past people sitting in chairs, his back stooped, his eyes fixed on a point in front him. He walks all day at the care center where he lives, or sometimes he crawls, getting down on his hands and knees and making his way around the edge of a dining area. Then he stands and walks again.

headline1: AMERICAN TOPICS
headline2: AMERICAN TOPICS
snippet: Allen Roses of the Duke University Medical Center, who in 1993 discovered a genetic trait linked to Alzheimer's, says he has now figured out that it causes the disease by weakening the microscopic "plumbing" that carries nutrients to
lead_paragraph: Allen Roses of the Duke University Medical Center, who in 1993 discovered a genetic trait linked to Alzheimer's, says he has now figured out that it causes the disease by weakening the microscopic "plumbing" that carries nutrients to brain cells and flushes out the waste.He said the finding offers numerous possibilities for the development of drugs that might not "cure" the degenerative disease but could delay it for 20 years. That way, most people would not live long enough to get it.

headline1: Don K. Price, 85, Educator And Science Promoter, Dies
headline2: Don K. Price, 85, Educator And Science Promoter, Dies
lead_paragraph: Don K. Price Jr., an educator who devoted much of his career to promoting the role of science in the American Government, died today in the Newton-Wellesley Alzheimer Center in Wellesley, Mass. He was 85 years old and had suffered from Alzheimer's disease for several years. He was a longtime resident of Cambridge, Mass.

headline1: Bodies of Couple Found in Car
headline2: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING; Bodies of Couple Found in Car
lead_paragraph: The decomposed bodies of an elderly couple from Teaneck were found in their car yesterday in a densely wooded area several hundred feet off Interstate 87 in the Adirondacks of New York State. State Trooper Steve Smith said Edward Kirvin, 74, may have fallen asleep at the wheel. Mr. Kirvin and his wife, Audrey, who was 70 and suffering from Alzheimer's disease, had been on vacation and had last been seen two weeks ago.

headline1: Man Kills Wife and Himself
headline2: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING; Man Kills Wife and Himself
lead_paragraph: A Jersey City man, who was apparently worried that no one would care for his ailing 71-year-old wife if something happened to him, killed her with a single gunshot wound to the head and then turned the gun on himself, the Hudson County Prosecutor, Carmen Messano, said. Mr. Messano said a note found in the apartment where the couple, Nicholas and Jean Sprague, lived suggested that the woman's deteriorating condition from Alzheimer's disease led her husband, 79, to commit the murder-suicide, The Associated Press reported.

lead_paragraph: According to a recent survey of people considered at risk for developing Alzheimer's, 63 percent said they would take a genetic test for the disease, even though there is no treatment or cure for it. The study, which surveyed people who had a close relative with the disease, sparked renewed debate on the ethics of testing for incurable genetic diseases.

headline1: DIARY
headline2: DIARY
lead_paragraph: DIPLOMACY Trade War, the Mini-Series Relax. You can have your Lexuses. The United States and Japan brought their tariff-rattling spat to a close last week with a predictably dramatic 11th-hour deal. But this mini-drama somehow left viewers unsatisfied: weak tea when strong coffee had been promised. With portentous huffing and puffing, the Administration had vowed, in Phil Gramm's words, "a gunfight at the O.K. Corral" -- nothing less than a historic cracking-open of Japan's notoriously sealed markets. But the agreement that emerged was deliberately ambiguous: no specific Japanese commitments on opening its markets, nothing enforceable. As one American trade expert put it, "We talk loudly and carry a tiny stick." LAWSUITS Now, Let Investors Beware The flood of legislation that's swamping this nation is clearly a mess, and many people, in response, indulge in an age-old reflex: blame the lawyers. That reflex is surely behind the drive to discourage shareholder lawsuits -- a battle that has inundated innocent civilians lately with a barrage of advertising. Brokers and accountants, emboldened by the Republicans strutting their stuff, have pushed for a law to limit lawsuits, saying many suits are frivolous. Consumer groups have countered with ads cautioning that small investors would be left with little recourse if they were duped. But anti-lawyer fever is clearly strong these Republican days, and last week the Senate approved the measure with a veto-proof 70-29 vote. INSIDER TRADING Too Tempting to Resist If the money's lying there, they will take it -- whether it's theirs or not. That seemed to be the lesson last week when a former Cravath, Swaine & Moore senior associate, and his brother, pleaded guilty to insider trading. There is a lot of money lying around these days -- in the form of advance information about the current flurry of mergers. And cases of insider trading are growing in tandem. Until now Cravath had prided itself on keeping its nose clean, but this lawyer passed on information that resulted in trading profits of nearly $1 million. Now you'd think that someone who'd reached such professional heights had it made (if by "it" you mean money), but the siren song was clearly too loud. MUNICIPAL FINANCE A County Circles Its Oranges A lot of people are against taxes, but Orange County voters surely take the prize. Last week they refused to approve a mere half-percent emergency sales tax increase, even though this defiant stand nudged them toward a rather messy abyss. The county's in bankruptcy, its debt is now in default, a state takeover looms, and it's far from clear how the trash will be collected and the students taught. Couldn't the county issue more bonds to make it all better? Right. A fellow here has a nice bridge to sell to those bond buyers. And perhaps worse, municipal bonds all over the place have gotten a black eye. HEALTH CARE The H.M.O. Giant Is Coming H.M.O.'s are coming. Yes, yes, they've been here for some time, but now they'll really be a force to reckon with. Last week United Healthcare, an H.M.O. giant based in Minnesota, agreed to buy Metrahealth, a more traditional insurer. Metrahealth, carved recently out of the Met Life and Travelers health businesses, has 10 million customers, including 1.5 million in the New York area. The merger with United Healthcare will create the nation's largest health-plan company. So if H.M.O.'s have always seemed a distant concept -- somewhere else, affecting someone else -- that is sure to change in a hurry. TOBACCO Keeping Minors From Smoking Let's see. Philip Morris wants to sell cigarettes -- that's its business. And most smokers start when they are teen-agers. Yet last week the company said it would go all out to keep minors from smoking. (Well, not exactly all out: the plan will cost $5 million; 1994 profits were $4.7 billion.) Highlights of the program are a national ad campaign, warnings that say "Underage Sale Prohibited," and the end of promotional giveaways. What this means (choose one): a) Philip Morris, in a stunning about-face, actually wants fewer people to smoke, or b) "They are scared," as an American Heart Association spokesman said, and want to undercut efforts to regulate tobacco as a drug and head off state efforts to clamp down on sales to minors. CORPORATE DIRECTORS Part Time. High Pay. Perks. Do directors earn their often-substantial pay? With corporate austerity all the rage, many shareholders (whose jobs, perhaps, were devoured by that omnivorous austerity) have been asking just that. So Graef Crystal, a pay guru who clearly relishes tackling such questions, took a look. In a report out last week, he found a huge range in 1994 board pay, from $3,600 at Berkshire Hathaway to $180,700 at Roadway Services -- or, as he put it more tersely, "It's a mess." He created a formula for defining how much is too much, and in what was surely a string of amazing coincidences, he found many companies at which both directors and chief executives -- who scratch each other's wallets -- were significantly overpaid. WORKPLACE The 24-Hour-a-Day Fast Track It's easy to fantasize about a $1 million-plus salary, the freedom from worry (No more credit-card interest!) the money would bestow. But such a salary could be a thief of freedom, too. If you worked, say, for Ronald Perelman, you might be on call morning and night, weekday and weekend. That was fine with Fred Tepperman -- until his wife got Alzheimer's. Then he needed more time at home, and soon lost his job as Mr. Perelman's chief financial officer. The company said he "willfully failed to devote to his employer his entire time, energy and skill," while Mr. Tepperman insists it was no more than missing a few breakfast meetings to care for his wife. The courts will now decide who's right, for Mr. Tepperman has sued for more than $25 million in damages. TAKEOVERS How Does It Feel, Mr. Pickens? Takeover artists -- they're almost-mythic corporate rough riders, swooping in on pot-bellied managers, kicking them with their studded boots, and snarling, "Get with it or get out!" Such raiders, a breed apart, would surely never be on the receiving end of those kicks. Or would they? One fabled marauder of the wild 80's was one T. Boone Pickens -- the very name conjures images of a man who eats rusty nails with his steak. But sure enough, last week two big investors took aim at Mr. Pickens's natural gas company, Mesa, chanting the old raiders' chant: "Enhance shareholder value." And suddenly it was Mr. Pickens with his back to the saloon wall, for one of those investors is none other than Marvin Davis, the California billionaire.

headline1: Alzheimer Patients Present a Lesson On Human Dignity
headline2: Alzheimer Patients Present a Lesson On Human Dignity
snippet: Patients in early stages of Alzheimer's disease speak at Annual Mayoral Council on Alzheimer's Disease; patients are from support group run by Alzheimer's Assn; idea is to show doctors and others that Alzheimer's patients are still people; photo (...
lead_paragraph: THEY looked for all the world like elderly professionals, dressed casually in the typical New York hues of black and gray. But the two women and one man, sitting in front of a packed room at a recent meeting on Alzheimer's disease, were not researchers or directors of programs. They were patients, they had Alzheimer's disease and they were there to tell what it was like to know you have a disease that is slowly, inexorably, killing your brain.

headline1: LILLY PAYING FOR OBESITY AND ALZHEIMER STUDY
headline2: LILLY PAYING FOR OBESITY AND ALZHEIMER STUDY
snippet: Eli Lilly & Co reaches five-year deal to pay Neurocrine Biosciences Inc $74 milion in cash to develop new drugs for obesity and Alzheimer's disease (S)
lead_paragraph: Eli Lilly & Company has reached a five-year deal to pay Neurocrine Biosciences Inc. $74 million in cash to develop new drugs for obesity and Alzheimer's disease, the companies said yesterday. The accord provides financial and scientific backing for new compounds that Neurocrine is testing to treat those diseases, which are both linked with depressed levels of a hormone, called corticotropin releasing factor, or C.R.F. Neurocrine, based in San Diego, is a four-year-old biotechnology company developing drugs for disorders of the central nervous system and the immune system. Under the pact, Neurocrine will receive $22 million in initial fees and financing, including $10 million the first year.

headline1: Estrogen May Reduce Alzheimer's Risk in Women, Study Says
headline2: Estrogen May Reduce Alzheimer's Risk in Women, Study Says
snippet: Researchers report taking estrogen after menopause may reduce woman's risk of developing Alzheimer's or delay onset of disease (M)
lead_paragraph: Taking estrogen after menopause may reduce a woman's risk of developing Alzheimer's or delay onset of the disease, scientists said yesterday.

headline1: Hopes Are Rosy On Alzheimer's, But Results Slim
headline2: Hopes Are Rosy On Alzheimer's, But Results Slim
lead_paragraph: THE researchers who study Alzheimer's disease are a relentlessly upbeat bunch. They are on the verge, they say, of finding a way to diagnose the disease with a simple blood test. Quite soon, they say, they will turn up a way to delay its onset or slow its course. Any day now, they say, drugs will emerge that prevent the disease in people who would otherwise get it.

headline1: Tantalizing Data Suggest Estrogen May Prevent or Delay Alzheimer's
headline2: Tantalizing Data Suggest Estrogen May Prevent or Delay Alzheimer's
lead_paragraph: AS the number of patients with Alzheimer's disease continues to climb, researchers are studying the possibility that a common and already approved drug, estrogen, may help to prevent or delay it, and even reverse some of its symptoms.

headline1: WARNER-LAMBERT SHARES JUMP AFTER INVESTOR MEETING
headline2: WARNER-LAMBERT SHARES JUMP AFTER INVESTOR MEETING
snippet: Warner-Lambert Co shares hit record high amid speculation that Roche Holdings AG plans bid (S)
lead_paragraph: The shares of the Warner-Lambert Company hit a record high yesterday amid speculation that Roche Holdings A.G. of Switzerland would make a bid for the company. Shares of Warner-Lambert, which makes Halls cough drops and Cognex, a drug treatment for Alzheimer's disease, rose $2.875, to close at $62.75, on the New York Stock Exchange after trading as high as $63.375. Warner-Lambert, based in Morris Plains, N.J., is often mentioned as a takeover candidate. Still, some analysts discounted the latest speculation, saying the price jump was partly caused by renewed interest in Warner-Lambert's new drug pipeline after a Boston meeting between the company and investors on Tuesday. Roche and Warner-Lambert declined to comment.

headline1: Throw Them Out
headline2: Throw Them Out
snippet: Bob Herbert Op-Ed column scores decision by Pres Clinton to sign Republicans' welfare-reform bill (M)
lead_paragraph: They should have included, in this charade called welfare reform, instructions on how you actually get these useless elderly people out of their dwellings -- these blind people, and the men and women addled by Alzheimer's, and the ones disabled by strokes or cancer or heart disease. I'm talking about the elderly disabled immigrants who, by the grace of our President and a rabid Congress, are soon to be suddenly destitute. Paying rent will be out of the question, so they will have to be evicted. Do you get stretchers and carry them out of their homes and leave them at the curb, or do you wheel them out, or do you just drag them out?

headline1: Correction
headline2: Correction
lead_paragraph: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about Aaron Copland's house in Cortlandt misidentified the composer who contracted Alzheimer's disease after being photographed. It was Copland, not Leonard Bernstein.

headline1: THE NEXT PRO-LIFERS
headline2: THE NEXT PRO-LIFERS
snippet: Ben A Rich letter on Paul Wilkes's July 21 article on doctor-assisted suicide (S)
lead_paragraph: For me, the most ethically compelling requests for doctor assistance in dying come from the victims of such neurological conditions as amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (Lou Gehrig's disease) or Alzheimer's disease. Inadequate pain management is not the issue with these patients. The issue is suffering that they judge to be unendurable.

headline1: Tim Ryan Copes, and Crusades
headline2: TV SPORTS; Tim Ryan Copes, and Crusades
snippet: CBS sportscaster Tim Ryan, whose wife Lee has Alzheimer's disease, has asked John McEnroe and Jim Courier to play tennis exhibition in Boise, Idaho, on Dec 13 that will honor his wife and benefit Alzheimer's charities; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: The diagnosis of Alzheimer's disease came early for Lee Ryan. She was only 50. Now, eight years later, Ryan, the wife of the CBS sportscaster Tim Ryan, can no longer walk. She can barely speak except to blurt out an occasional word.

headline1: Volunteer Heads Gala to Fight Alzheimer's
headline2: Volunteer Heads Gala to Fight Alzheimer's

lead_paragraph: FOR Judith B. Resnick of Harrison, saying no is harder than saying yes. Which is why with an already loaded schedule of volunteer work, she took on another commitment that in itself is a full-time job: being chairwoman of ''The Gilded Age,'' the 13th annual Rita Hayworth Gala to benefit the Alzheimer's Association.

headline2: Center to Treat Those With Early Alzheimer's
snippet: Alzheimer's Association of Westchester-Putnam (NY) is preparing to open center for people in early stages of Alzheimer's which will offer counseling, referral and education to patients and family members (M) s
lead_paragraph: WHEN people think of Alzheimer's disease, they often envision the latest stages, the total devastation of personality and body functions lost to the illness. But the early symptoms of Alzheimer's may be equally destructive in their own insidious way: an individual who first experiences forgetfullness and disorientation and is aware of his diminished capabilities can be embarrassed, bewildered and terrified.

headline2: Estrogen and Alzheimer's
snippet: Researchers find that women who take estrogen after menopause are much less likely than those who do not to develop Alzheimer's disease (S)
lead_paragraph: RESEARCHERS in Maryland have found that women who take estrogen after menopause are much less likely than those do not use the hormone replacement to develop Alzheimer's disease.

headline1: Alzheimer's Homes Open
headline2: Alzheimer's Homes Open
snippet: Three boarding homes for people with Alzheimer's disease have opened in Bergen County in past year and eight more are planned (New Jersey Daily Briefing) (S)
lead_paragraph: Three boarding homes for people with Alzheimer's disease have opened in Bergen County in the past year and eight more are planned, according to the Northern New Jersey Chapter of the Alzheimer's Association. Some Bergen County residents have complained that people with Alzheimer's disease can be found wandering in the neighborhood unsupervised and pose a danger to themselves and others.

headline1: Alzheimer Studies Thwarted
headline2: Alzheimer Studies Thwarted
snippet: Researchers say needed clinical studies of role taking estrogen after menopause can play in preventing, delaying and perhaps treating Alzheimer's disease may never be completed because so many women are already convinced of benefits that they are ...
lead_paragraph: EVIDENCE that taking estrogen after menopause may prevent or delay and perhaps even treat Alzheimer's disease is increasingly compelling. But it is hardly conclusive, and the precise role that estrogen may play in curbing this devastating brain disease remains uncertain.

headline2: Alzheimer's Team Finds a New Genetic Link

headline1: Alzheimer's Fight in Her Mother's Name
headline2: Alzheimer's Fight in Her Mother's Name
snippet: Interview with Yasmin Aga Khan, who has devoted herself to cure of Alzheimer's disease, which claimed her mother, actress Rita Hayworth; photos (M)
lead_paragraph: YASMIN AGA KHAN, who spent many summers on the East End, has devoted herself to the cure of the disease that claimed her mother, the actress Rita Hayworth. The Rita Hayworth Galas have raised $16 million for Alzheimer's research. Public awareness of Alzheimer's has increased to where there are now 221 chapters of the Alzheimer's Association and 2,000 support groups in the 50 states. (The Long Island chapter can be reached at 516-289-6335). Ms. Khan's father, Aly Aga Khan, was probably more famous as a European playboy than as spiritual leader of 15 million Ismaili Muslims. Ms. Khannow divides her time between New York and Utah where she has what she describes as a ''New Age marriage.''

headline2: Drawing Attention To Alzheimer's Services

headline1: Research Hints at a Gene Link to Brain Afflictions of Boxers
headline2: Research Hints at a Gene Link to Brain Afflictions of Boxers
snippet: Researchers studying 30 boxers find preliminary evidence that gene already known to predispose people to Alzheimer's disease may be factor in why some 20 percent of professional boxers ultimately develop brain afflictions; see gene possibly linked...
lead_paragraph: Jose Torres, a 61-year-old former light-heavyweight champion, will never forget the first time he was ''shaken up,'' the boxers' term for a kind of out-of-body sensation that can result from a particularly solid blow to the head. He was 18 years old and fighting in Panama when the punch came.

headline1: Explorer of Aging Process Is Lighting Candles in the Dark
headline2: Explorer of Aging Process Is Lighting Candles in the Dark
snippet: Profile of Dr Caleb E Finch, who is at forefront in study of Alzheimer's disease and process of aging; he has suggested that Alzheimer's may be an inflammatory disorder, possibly preventable with anti-inflammatory drugs; he has also pioneered stud...
lead_paragraph: From the beginning, says Caleb E. Finch, a gerontologist at the University of Southern California here, he had ''an instinct for professionally dangerous pursuits.'' As an undergraduate at Yale University in the early 1960's, he realized that aging was an area of biology about which almost nothing was known and in which few scientists were interested. So Dr. Finch jumped in and began asking questions that today are at the forefront of aging research worldwide.

headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  TARPLIN, ELY

headline1: Judge Recuses Himself From Gigante Mob Case
headline2: Judge Recuses Himself From Gigante Mob Case
lead_paragraph: The judge who was to preside at the trial of the suspected Mafia boss Vincent Gigante said yesterday that he had taken himself off the case because he did not feel he could be fair, after Mr. Gigante's lawyers said their client might have Alzheimer's disease.

headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYER, VICTOR B., PH.D.

Memorial service at a later date. Plant a perennial in his memory.

headline1: Writing That Can Strengthen The Fraying Threads of Memory
headline2: Writing That Can Strengthen The Fraying Threads of Memory
snippet: Dr Alan Dienstag, a Manhattan psychologist, and novelist Don DeLillo have created writing program to help Alzheimer's patients recall their past; class has evolved into a place where patients can share a laugh; photo (L)
lead_paragraph: ''I THOUGHT we might start with 'Saying Goodbye,' '' the writing teacher said, announcing the day's topic. After the usual groans, his three students got down to work; for the next 10 minutes they fought the writer's struggle to turn thoughts into words.

headline1: Lawyers May Seek Delay In Gigante Murder Trial
headline2: Lawyers May Seek Delay In Gigante Murder Trial
snippet: Lawyers for suspected Mafia boss Vincent Gigante say that they may seek another postponement in his long-delayed murder and racketeering trial because doctors found he might have Alzheimer's disease (S)
lead_paragraph: Lawyers for the suspected Mafia boss Vincent Gigante said yesterday that they may seek another postponement in his long-delayed murder and racketeering trial, because doctors found he might have Alzheimer's disease.

headline1: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, IRVING MORRIS
headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, IRVING MORRIS
lead_paragraph: GREENBERG-Irving Morris. On January 22 in New Brunswick at age 84. For many years, he was a commercial real estate broker, landholder, and investor. Born in Manhattan on May 23, 1912, he moved with his parents, Louis and Dora, to Etra, New Jersey, where he met and married Rose Sokolow, his beloved wife of 61 years. Generous in all aspects of his life, he was a man of great integrity and heroic perserverance. He lent his strength to all who knew and loved him. Father of Joan Rencarge and the late Linda Kahny, grandfather of Sheri, Debra, Robert and Lisa, great grandfather of Michelle. He is survived by his loving sisters, Ruth Fagan and Miriam Diner. A resident of East Brunswick, New Jersey during the prime of his life, he moved to Monroe Township in 1972 and was a founder and past president of the Jewish Congregation of Clearbrook. An extraordinary supporter of many charities, he was devoted to the State of Israel, Beit Halochem, Special Olympics, educational funding, research in diabetes, cancer, Alzheimer's disease, and many other humanitarian causes. Those who wish to remember him may give to research in Alzheimer's disease, cancer, or Parkinson's disease, all of which deeply affected his life. Private family services.

headline1: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAEBURN, BEN
headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAEBURN, BEN
lead_paragraph: RAEBURN-Ben. 1911-1997. Founder, president, editor, Horizon Press, NYC. Renowned for integrity and quality. Published dozens of pre-eminent writers and creative thinkers, including his close friends Frank Lloyd Wright, Irving Howe, Harold Rosenberg, B.H. Haggin, James Hanley. Admired for his idealism, ethics, high standards, & brilliant, independent intellect. Loved for his graciousness, generosity and wit. Family requests donations to Alzheimer's associations or research.

headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, CHARLOTTE

headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANSING, RICHARD

headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEINBERG, CHARLOTTE

headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  LICHT, NATHAN

headline1: Paid Notice: Deaths  RANZAL, EDWARD
headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  RANZAL, EDWARD
lead_paragraph: RANZAL-Edward. The family of Edward Ranzal mourns his passing on April 1, 1997. He is survived by his two sons and their wives, Ted and Eleanor, and Gerry and Barbara, and his 4 grandchildren, Robin, Susan, Scott, and Stacey. He joins his wife Celia who passed away April 9, 1996. He was a newspaper reporter on the staff of the New York Times for over 50 years. During that time his beat included the Bronx courthouse, the federal courthouse at Foley Square, and Mayors Lindsay and Koch. Since his retirement he has been a resident of Deerfield Beach Florida. If so desired, a memorial donation may be made to: The Alzheimer's Association, or The Jacob Perlow Hospice at Beth Israel Hospital.

headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBENSTEIN, PHILIP
lead_paragraph: RUBENSTEIN-Philip, March 15, 1997. Husband of Sylvia (nee Gervis) of Philadelphia, PA (formerly of NYC). Father of Lynne Kaiser and Bobbi (Ken) Gray. Brother of Betty Gruber-Schneider. Grandfather of William (Marcy) Kaiser, Lauren (Paul) Kaiser-Albert, Paul (Kimberly) Kaiser, Garrett (Lisa) Gray, David Gray & Ronald Gray. Great-grandfather of Samuel Kaiser, Jessica Gray, Jason Gray, Elizabeth Kaiser, Abigail Kaiser and Matthew Kaiser. Services on Tuesday 12:30 PM, Platt Memorial Chapels, Inc., 2001 Berlin Road, Cherry Hill, NJ. Entombment Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ. The family respectfully requests contributions in his memory be made to the Alzheimer's Assoc., or the American Heart Assoc.

headline1: Paid Notice: Deaths  GELARDIN, HUGO J.
headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  GELARDIN, HUGO J.
lead_paragraph: GELARDIN-Hugo J., July 17, 1997. Beloved husband of Cordula. Loving father of Christine Gelardin and Nicole Berlin. Adoring grandfather of Alexander, Nicholas, Emily, Charles, Isabella and Jacques. Dear brother of the late Albert J. Gelardin. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, on Monday and Tuesday, 1-9 P.M. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Ignatius Loyola Church, Park Ave. at 84 St., Wednesday, 10 AM. Interment Quogue Cemetery. Contributions in his memory may be made to Joslin Diabetes Center, 1 Joslin Pl., Boston, MA 02215, Attn: Development Office and/or Alzheimer's Disease Association, NYC Chapter, 420 Lexington Ave., NY, NY 10170, Attn: Development Office.

headline1: Paid Notice: Deaths  DREITZER, SHIRLEY WOLFF COHEN
headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  DREITZER, SHIRLEY WOLFF COHEN
lead_paragraph: DREITZER-Shirley Wolff Cohen. On Wednesday, December 31, at age 85, of New York and Palm Beach. Devoted wife of the late Albert J. Dreitzer, and, for 39 years, devoted wife of the late William I. Cohen. Loving mother of Stephanie C. Rosen Halpern and Cathleen C. Cavell. Dear sister of Ethel W. Freeman and Annette W. Katz. Loving grandmother of Elizabeth, Carolyn, Pamela and Katherine Rosen, Benjamin and David Cavell, and loving stepgrandmother of Rachel Cavell. Services Friday, 10:45AM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Interment, Old Montefiore Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Alzheimer's Disease and Related Disorders Association, 919 North Michigan Avenue, Chicago, IL 60611

headline1: Paid Notice: Deaths  TIPLITZ, GEORGE LEWIS
headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  TIPLITZ, GEORGE LEWIS
lead_paragraph: TIPLITZ-George Lewis. On September 9, 1997. Succumbed to death after a heroic battle with pneumonia and Alzheimers at White Plains Medical Center. He leaves his wife of 50 years Doris (nee Wiederschall), one son John Evan, and two grandchildren Lee Evan and Ian David; two cherished sisters Ruth Zelinka and Anita Kirsten, husband Marvin. He also leaves myriad nieces and nephews who adored and were devoted to him. Service Friday, September 12, 1:30 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Those who may wish to remember him may send contributions to White Plains Medical Center, White Plains, New York or a charity of your choice.

headline1: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, CALVIN OTIS
headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, CALVIN OTIS
lead_paragraph: SMITH-Calvin Otis. Of Glenwood Landing, Long Iisland, on December 18, 1997. Beloved husband of Patricia F., loving father of Margaret S. Larom, David M., Elizabeth C. and Mary W. Grandfather of Julia and Natalie Smith, Christopher and Daisy Larom. Fond step-father of Glenn Pearsall. Loving brother of Nancy S. Olsen, Mary M. Smith, Margaret S. Davenport and the late Barbara S. Thayer. Also survived by his first wife Dorothy B. Blakeman. Visiting 3-5 and 7-9 PM, Sunday, Whitting Funeral Home, Inc. Glen Head, LI. Funeral service 3 PM, Monday, St. Luke's Episcopal Church, Sea Cliff. Interment Sound Avenue Cemetery, Northville, LI. Contributions may be made to the Long Island Alzheimer Foundation or St. Luke's Episcopal Church.

headline1: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPTON, TESS
headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPTON, TESS
lead_paragraph: LIPTON-Tess, on January 24, 1997. Resident of Las Vegas, Nevada. Formerly of New York City, Shrub Oak Park, Century Village, Deerfield Beach, Florida. Beloved wife of the late Koppel Lipton. Loving mother to Howard, Paul and Daughter-in-law Elaine. Missing her will be grandchildren: Ross, Jeffrey and his wife Randi. Nieces and nephews Barbara Leonard, Marilyn and Ike Hazan. Edward and Chris Gitelson, Paul and Nancy Gitelson. Sister-in-law Bertha Givertzman and other cousins and their children. She was quick with a smile, generous and a very caring member of her family. She leaves a painful void, but will always be remembered with love, admiration and respect. Services were held Sunday, January 26, 1997, Riverside Chapel, 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue, NYC. Contributions may be made to the Alzheimer's Association.

headline1: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAYBURN, DR. JOHN W.
headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAYBURN, DR. JOHN W.
lead_paragraph: RAYBURN-Dr. John W., died on May 28, 1997, in Plainview, MN, from the toll taken by Alzheimer's Disease, degenerative palsy, and multiple strokes. A founding member of Mercy College in Dobbs Ferry, NY, Dr. Rayburn was Professor of Music and Fine Arts and choral conductor there from 1961-1994. He began his career in church music as organist and choir director at St. Joseph's Cathedral in La Crosse, WI, and continued in this type of service in communities wherever he taught. His most recent posts were at Edgehill Church in Riverdale and at the Dobbs Ferry Lutheran Church. Dr. Rayburn is survived by three sisters: Glorieux (James) Dougherty of New York and Marie (Fred) Stafford and Kathryn Rayburn of Rochester, MN; two nephews and three nieces. He will be buried at St. Mary's Parish in Durand, WI.

headline1: Paid Notice: Deaths  XUEREB, JEAN PIERRE
headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  XUEREB, JEAN PIERRE
lead_paragraph: XUEREB-Jean Pierre, 65. Died after a valiant struggle with a Parkinson's/Alzheimers disease on November 27 in Rochefort, France. In the 1960's he went to Paris where he joined Olivetti and attained a managerial position and then entered the world of fashion. Seeing opportunities in the U.S., he moved to New York where he was a driving force in the development of Createurs Industriels, a group of designers which included Yves St. Laurent, Issey Miyake, J.C. de Castelbajac, Emmanuel Kahn, Jean Muir, Mark Held and others. A man of dreams and vision, he founded Ensuite, Inc, the company responsible for launching and developing the lingerie trademark Fernando Sanchez. A man of charm, kindness and generosity, a gentleman always, he is survived by his wife Bobbie Sioux and their son Cody, his sons Cyril, Salvator and Emmanuel and their mother Sophie, his brother Marc and wife Minette and his granddaughter Clea.

headline1: Paid Notice: Deaths  QUAID, DONALD J.
headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  QUAID, DONALD J.
lead_paragraph: QUAID-Donald J. 82, of Falmouth, ME. Retired Equitable Life Assurance Society executive. He rose from office boy at age 15 to create and manage the Accounts Division of the Pension Department as Vice President. He retired in 1980 after 50 years of service. Beloved husband of the late Evelyn (Feczko), brother of Dorothy Erb, David L., Geraldine Ryan and the late Delores, father of Donald R., Andra and the late Patrouchka (Patricia), grandfather of Molly Bergman Quaid and David L. B. Quaid. Uncle to 18 nieces and nephews. Calling hours Sunday, Brackett Funeral Home, Brunswick, ME. Funeral mass Monday 10 AM. Charles Borromeo Church, Brunswick. Calling hours Tuesday evening, Powell Funeral Home, Southern Pines, NC. Memorial contributions may be made to the Alzheimer's Disease Association, 163 Lancaster Street, Portland, ME 04101.

headline1: Ailing, Goldwater Fades Out of the Game
headline2: Ailing, Goldwater Fades Out of the Game
snippet: Barry Goldwater's wife reports that 88-year-old former senator and Presidential candidate is ailing, with bouts of memory loss and confusion that may be early stages of Alzheimer's disease or effects of 1996 stroke; his photo (S)
lead_paragraph: From his hilltop home in this affluent suburb of Phoenix, Barry M. Goldwater can scan the city and sprawling desert landscape with ease and comfort through a telescope.

headline1: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANISH, ROY
headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANISH, ROY
lead_paragraph: DANISH-Roy. Died on November 20, 1997, at the age of 78. He is survived by his daughters Elisabeth Wheeler and Caroline Thies, his brother Keith, and three grandchildren. Born in Manhattan on March 2, 1919, he graduated from Columbia in 1940, earned an MBA from Harvard in 1942, then served as lieutenant in the U.S. Navy from 1942-1946. His career in broadcasting began with nine years at Mutual Broadcasting System, where he rose to the position of Vice President and Assistant to the President. From 1955 to 1959 he worked at McCann-Erickson as account supervisor and Vice President, then became a partner at Smith-Greenland Advertising in 1959. In 1960, Roy began his twenty-seven year career with Television Information Office, where he served as Director from 1962 to 1987. He worked with his multitalented staff to maintain a bridge of understanding between the television industry and its many publics. Donations in his memory may be made to the Alzheimers Association, 420 Lexington Avenue, New York, NY 10170.

headline1: Paid Notice: Deaths  KWASHA, H. CHARLES. (CHICK)
headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  KWASHA, H. CHARLES. (CHICK)
lead_paragraph: KWASHA-H. Charles. (Chick). Age 90. Of North Miami, FL. Born in Providence, R.I. December 2, 1906. Passed peacefully on May 4, 1997. Graduated Magna Cum Laude, Sigma Psiand Phi Beta Kappa from Brown University in 1928. Founded the Kwasha-Lipton Company, a pre-eminent actuarial consulting firm, in 1944. His company has provided actuarial services to many Fortune 500 corporations for more than fifty years and was recently purchased by Coopers and Lybrand. He contributed to many charities in his lifetime, among which are Brown University, The Alzheimer's Foundation, Boys Town of Jerusalem and Juvenile Diabetes. Survived by his wife Sylvia H. Kwasha, his children Linda D. Kwasha, Bruce C. Kwasha and Robert D. Kwasha and his seven grandchildren. Funeral service to be held graveside at Mount Nebo Memorial Gardens, 5505 N.W. 3rd St, Miami, Wednesday, 2:45pm. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made to the Diabetes Research Institute Foundation.

headline1: Man Finds His Voice, but Forgets Having Lost It
headline2: Man Finds His Voice, but Forgets Having Lost It
snippet: Jose Gomez, who indicated he was deaf and mute when he showed up at Newark hospital with his mother, begins talking again at Woodhull Medical Center in Brooklyn; says he cannot remember being unable to communicate; mother, who has Alzheimer's dise...
lead_paragraph: The Brooklyn man who had indicated to officials of a Newark hospital that he was deaf and mute has found his voice again upon returning home to New York City -- but he says he cannot remember being unable to hear or speak.

headline1: Paid Notice: Deaths  CRANDELL, EDWIN HAWLEY
headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  CRANDELL, EDWIN HAWLEY
lead_paragraph: CRANDELL-Edwin Hawley, died on May 7th, 1997 at the age of 82. Devoted husband of the late Maxine Hothorn Crandell who died on November 30, 1996. Mr. Crandell was also a beloved uncle to Cathy Crandell Long of Summit, NJ, Laurie Roberts of NYC and many other nieces and nephews. Mr. Crandell was a longtime resident of Rye, New York. A retired partner of N.J. Meehan, he was a member of the New York Stock Exchange for more than fifty years. Mr. Crandell attended the Westminster School, Bronxville High School & New York University. He was a Captain in the Army Engineering Corps during World War II. He was a member of the Apawamis Club, the American Yacht Club, the US Seniors and the Buttonwood Club. In addition to his nieces and nephews he is survived by 2 sisters-in-law, Mary Elizabeth Crandell of Ponte Verde, FL, and Cynthia Hothorn Williams of Aiken, SC. He will be sorely missed by all who knew him. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Alzheimer's Association - West chester Chapter, 785 Mamaroneck Avenue, White Plains, NY 10605 or the American Lung Association, 35 Orchard St., White Plains, NY 10605. A memorial service for both Maxine and Edwin Crandell will be held at 1 PM, on Sunday, May 18th, at Rye Presbyterian Church in Rye, New York. Any questions please call 914-967-0129.

headline1: Q&A;: Noel Schwerin; The Ramifications of Gene Mapping
headline2: Q&A;: Noel Schwerin; The Ramifications of Gene Mapping
snippet: NOEL SCHWERIN, a documentary film maker for the last 15 years and former associate producer for the NOVA science and technology series on the Public Broadcasting System,  produced, directed and wrote ''A Question of Genes: Inherited Risks,'' which...
lead_paragraph: NOEL SCHWERIN, a documentary film maker for the last 15 years and former associate producer for the NOVA science and technology series on the Public Broadcasting System, produced, directed and wrote ''A Question of Genes: Inherited Risks,'' which aired this fall on public television. Through several first-person stories, the film explores the conflicted decision of individuals at risk for heart disease, breast and ovarian cancer and Alzheimer's disease to undergo genetic testing, and the practical and moral problems that their decisions -- and the findings -- force them to confront.

headline1: Personal Health
headline2: Personal Health
snippet: Personal Health column, first of two articles on hormone replacement, discusses dilemma facing many women concerning long-term use of postmenopausal estrogen (M)
lead_paragraph: WOMEN of a certain age are justifiably confused. One day they hear that taking postmenopausal estrogen may cut their risk of Alzheimer's disease by more than 50 percent. The very next day, another study links the long-term use of postmenopausal hormones to a 50 percent decline in deaths from heart disease but also a 43 percent increase in breast-cancer deaths.

headline1: Gilbert Fitzhugh, 88, Dies; Ex-Metropolitan Life Chief
headline2: Gilbert Fitzhugh, 88, Dies; Ex-Metropolitan Life Chief
snippet: Gilbert W Fitzhugh, former chairman and chief executive of Metropolitan Life Insurance Co, dies at age 88; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: Gilbert W. Fitzhugh, a former chairman and chief executive of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, died on Monday at the Meadow Lakes Health Care Center in Hightstown, N.J. He was 88 years old and had been ailing for several years with Alzheimer's disease, said his son, Gilbert Van Ingh Fitzhugh.

headline1: Virgilio Barco, Ex-Colombia Chief, Dies at 75
headline2: Virgilio Barco, Ex-Colombia Chief, Dies at 75
snippet: Virgilio Barco, American-educated former President of Colombia whose dream of combatting rampant poverty with land reform and other ambitious social measures was sidetracked by American-backed civil war with powerful drug barons, dies at age 75; p...
lead_paragraph: Virgilio Barco, an American-educated former President of Colombia whose dream of combatting rampant poverty with land reform and other ambitious social measures was sidetracked by an American-backed civil war with powerful drug barons, died Tuesday at a hospital in Bogota. He was 75 and had been suffering from Alzheimer's disease since shortly after leaving office in 1990.

headline1: Thalassa Cruso, 88, Plant Lover Who Shared Her Passion on TV
headline2: Thalassa Cruso, 88, Plant Lover Who Shared Her Passion on TV
snippet: Thalassa Cruso, plant expert who wrote and starred in television gardening program, dies at age 88; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: Thalassa Cruso, an authority on plants who was known as ''the Julia Child of horticulture'' for her common-sense if often loopy gardening programs on television in the 1960's, died on June 11 at Newton and Wellesley Alzheimer Center in Wellesley, Mass. She was 88 and lived in Marion, Mass.

headline1: America's Aging, Violent Prisoners
headline2: America's Aging, Violent Prisoners
snippet: Imprisonment boom of past two decades has had unintended byproduct: sharp growth in number of elderly and geriatric inmates; number of those in Federal and state prisons who are considered geriatric, 55 or older, jumped to estimated 30,000 from 9,...
lead_paragraph: STANLEY WILSON can no longer recall his age or why he was sent to prison. Alzheimer's has stolen his memory. His hazy mind wanders through space much more freely than his body these days, and he believes he will be released from his prison in the rolling hills of western Pennsylvania ''this weekend.''

headline1: I Am More Than Hands
headline2: I Am More Than Hands
snippet: Mozelle Mimran letter on Jane Bendetson's Apr 13 article contrasting high personal cost of carrying for chronically ill relative with idealized picture in film Marvin's Room (S)û
lead_paragraph: I believe that articles like Jane Bendetson's ''I Am More Than Hands'' (Lives, April 13) raise awareness to the reality, not the Hollywood version, of the care-giving experience. As the leader of a support group for care-givers whose spouses or parents have Alzheimer's disease, I see both the love and the frustration of the members. The people in my group, many of whom are in their 70's and 80's and dealing with their own fragile health, spend 24 hours a day caring for their relatives.

headline1: ARTS ABROAD: Devotion Refuses to Yield; Alzheimer's Disease Cannot Divide a Literary Couple
headline2: ARTS ABROAD: Devotion Refuses to Yield; Alzheimer's Disease Cannot Divide a Literary Couple
snippet: Sarah Lyall interview with John Bayley, critic, retired Oxford professor and novelist, on poignant life he shares with his wife, Iris Murdoch, once-brilliant writer now sadly in grip of advanced Alzheimer's disease; Bayley, 73, has written memoir,...
lead_paragraph: Iris Murdoch, the celebrated author of 26 rigorously intellectual novels, stood uncertainly in the doorway of her living room, her face frozen in the blank expression that is a sure badge of Alzheimer's disease. It was only when she saw her husband, the critic, professor and novelist John Bayley, that a flicker of comprehension sparked in her eyes. But it was gone, as quickly as it came.

headline1: LIVES; A Gift to My Father
headline2: LIVES; A Gift to My Father
snippet: Patti Davis article on giving Christmas gifts to her father, Ronald Reagan, along with her brother Michael; says the meaning of Christmas gifts becomes clearer through the realization that her father's mind loses more ground each day to Alzheimer'...
lead_paragraph: Christmas is supposed to be about giving -- not so much the material kind, but giving of the self, the soul, the heart. Giving at any time is supposed to be about that, but it's easy to forget, particularly at Christmas. The concept gets buried beneath Neiman Marcus catalogues, lists, bills. My grandmother understood the essence of giving and never forgot it. In the 40's and 50's, Nelle Reagan regularly visited tuberculosis patients at Olive View Medical Center in Sylmar, Calif. She had little money, but believed that giving to others is a vital part of life. She always brought the patients something, even if it was just a card or a pencil.

headline1: ADULT BRAIN CELLS SAID TO REPRODUCE
headline2: ADULT BRAIN CELLS SAID TO REPRODUCE
snippet: Team of American and Swedish scientists, through rare glimpse inside human brain, reports that they have discovered generation of brain cells in adult humans for first time, opening an important area of investigation into possible new treatments f...
lead_paragraph: Through a rare glimpse inside the human brain, a team of American and Swedish scientists reported yesterday that they had discovered the generation of brain cells in adult humans for the first time, opening an important area of investigation into possible new treatments for such debilitating neurological disorders as Alzheimer's disease, Parkinson's disease and stroke.

headline1: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLLIN, MICHAEL
headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLLIN, MICHAEL
lead_paragraph: WOLLIN-Michael. A retired Civil Court Judge in Kings County, died on April 17 in Oxford, New York. He was 83 and a former resident of Brooklyn. Mr. Wollin was born in Brooklyn and worked his way through college and Brooklyn Law School. After a thirty year career in private practice, he served as both Deputy Public Administrator and Public Administrator of Kings County. He served as a Civil Court Judge for nine years, following which he returned to private practice. In his last years, Mr. Wollin had suffered from Alzheimer's disease. Donations may be made to the Alzheimer's Association, 420 Lexington Avenue, Suite 610, New York, New York 10170.

headline1: Scientists Find New Ways To Break Into the Brain
headline2: Scientists Find New Ways To Break Into the Brain
snippet: Scientists seek to pierce blood-brain barrier, elaborate security system that shields brain from toxins, hormonal surges or other substances that normally flow in the blood but also also keeps useful drugs, like possible treatments for Alzheimer's...
lead_paragraph: DRUG companies working on promising new treatments for brain disorders like Alzheimer's disease, tumors and depression are learning a hard lesson: it is easier to make a medicine that will act on the brain than it is to make one that will get into the brain.

headline1: Paid Notice: Deaths  ENDERS, CHARLES M.
headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  ENDERS, CHARLES M.
lead_paragraph: ENDERS-Charles M. 87 years old. Died April 25, 1998 after a long battle with Alzheimers disease. Beloved husband of Miriam Russo, widowed of Alline Driscoll, loving father of Tim, beloved brother of Sue Winston and Katherine Flack. Born 1910 in Hershey, PA, Chuck graduated with a B.S. in Chemistry from Purdue in 1932 & received an M.B.A. from Harvard Business School in 1933. During WWII, Chuck served as a Captain in the Signal Corps of the U.S. Army stationed in Philadelphia. After the War, he became a Senior Partner in the investment banking firm of F. Moseley & Co. and was instrumental in the organization of the Howard Johnson Corporation of which he became a Director. Private family services were held in Plant City, FL. Friends who knew and loved him may celebrate his memory by donating to the National Alzheimers Association.

headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANRICH, FANNY
lead_paragraph: SANRICH-Fanny. Of Roanoke, Va. Passed away Wednesday, January 14, 1998. She was born on October 25, 1920 in Paris, France. A daughter of Adolph and Alice Blumenthal. She was preceded in death by her husband, Norman Sanrich. She is survived by her daughter and son-in-law Sylvia and Paul Shoenfeld, grandchildren, Eric and Brooke, and brother, Pierre Blumenthal. A graveside service will be held at 11 A.M., on Friday, January 16 at the Temple Emanuel Cemetery in Roanoke. Another daughter, Susan Prince died last year. Services were held at ''Gutterman-Musicant''. Donations to Alzheimer's Association would be appreciated.

headline1: Father and Son, Bound by Baseball
headline2: 1998 WORLD SERIES: YANKEES VS. PADRES; Father and Son, Bound by Baseball
snippet: New York Yankees infielder Chuck Knoblauch discusses his father Ray's battle with Alzheimer's Disease; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: Baseball has always drawn Chuck Knoblauch and his father together, the time spent in the car going to Little League and high school games, the hours of playing catch in the backyard. So, after Knoblauch slugged a game-tying three-run homer in Game 1 of the World Series, he settled on the Yankee bench and thought of his father, Ray, who is suffering from Alzheimer's disease.

headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  BORKOW, ALTHEA KLEIGER

headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEENAN, FREDERICK M., JR.
lead_paragraph: KEENAN-Frederick M., Jr., 74. A retired sports photographer for the Patriot Ledger, Quincy, MA, died August 24, 1998 at his home in South Yarmouth, MA. after a long illness. He was well known for his award-winning photo of Bobby Orr scoring the 1970 Stanley Cup hockey winning goal. He is survived by his loving wife, Barbara Keenan, his daughter Kathleen Keenan Snow of Provincetown, Boston and New York; two sisters and one brother and three stepchildren. Box 953, Barnstable, MA 02630 or to Parkinson's Disease Association, 720 Harrison Ave., Boston, MA. 02118.

headline1: Paid Notice: Deaths  DORR, RUTH MILLER
headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  DORR, RUTH MILLER
lead_paragraph: DORR-Ruth Miller, 91. Of Fort Myers, FL. Homemaker, artist, died September 21, 1998. Studied at The Art Students League of New York, graduated from The Boston Museum School of Fine Arts and La Sorbonne, Paris, France with awards. Taught at The Nightingale Bamford School, NYC. Exhibited paintings in Paris, France, Ankara, Turkey, and the United States. Married Russell H. Dorr, lawyer, diplomat and international banker. While living in Turkey, she founded the Turkish-American Woman's Society, a nursing school, & was active in The Red Crescent Society. Survivors: son Goldthwaite H. Dorr 3rd, daughter Virginia D. Maxwell, sister Charlotte M. Luippold, eight grandchildren and eight great-grandchildren. Memorial services to be announced. Contributions to The National Alzheimer Foundation or The Church at Point O'Woods, Fire Island, New York.

headline1: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, ALFRED G.
headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, ALFRED G.
lead_paragraph: COHEN-Alfred G. 85. Died March 15, 1998. He was the president of Macon Umbrella Corp., located in Brooklyn, NY. Mr. Cohen pioneered in the use of aluminum in the construction of the garden umbrella, winning awards from his national trade association. He was instrumental in the formation of the Association of the National Summer Furniture Manufacturers and was an officer of the Association for many years. He was also an active member of the committee that built the Israel Center of Hillcrest Manor in Queens. Mr. Cohen leaves behind his beloved wife of 60 years, Mildred; his children, Michael Cohen, Ellen Masters and Marilyn Cohen Savryn; and his grandchildren, Marc and Caryn Masters and Sophia and Penny Savryn. Family man, friend and businessman, Al was loved and respected and will be dearly missed. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Alzheimer's Association or the Boys Club of New York.

headline1: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERMAN, WILLIAM C.
headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERMAN, WILLIAM C.
lead_paragraph: BERMAN-William C. Beloved and devoted husband who was care giver to his dear Alzheimer-afflicted wife Fanny, for 12 years until her passing in 1992. cherished, adored and loving father of Marilyn Grosfeld. Devoted, proud, and greatly admired ''professor of life'' grandfather (''Poppie'') of Scott. Adored, best friend and father-inlaw of Sonny Grosfeld. Those who knew him will always have fond memories of his intense loyalty, devotion and unconditional support of family and friends; his business acumen and take-charge leadership qualities which served him well as past president of both the amalgamated and Wynmoor Cooperatives; his inquisitive, inventive genius; his quick wit, sense of humor and ''impish'' charm; his common sense approach to and lust for life. We thank him for always being there for us-our Renaissance man. We will miss him forever. Service to be private on Tuesday, January 6, 1998.

headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEL, JAMES EDWARD

II veteran & worked for the New York Times as a dispatcher for 30 plus years. He is survived by his loving wife of 55 years, Beverly E. Friel, children Carol (James) Leuschner, James E. Friel, Steven (Laurie) Friel, Gerard (Maria) Friel, Lori (Martin) Gensler. Grandchildren Loren, Kelly, L.J., Chris, Keri Jean, Adam, Erica, Tara, Jesse, Gillian, Tyler & Brendon. headline1: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAMER, PHILIP
headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAMER, PHILIP
lead_paragraph: KRAMER-Philip. January 30, 1998 in Boca Raton, FL. Beloved husband of Sarah. Loving father of Noelle and Robert, Marilyn and Howard, Glenn and Lynn. Devoted grandfather of Seth, Marc, Allison, Jeffrey, Randee, Douglas, Alexander, Robyn and Kira. Loving great-grandfather of Ross, Brett and Adam. Mr. Kramer will be dearly remembered by his loving family and many devoted friends and business associates. He died after a long and valiant battle with Alzheimer's. Mr. Kramer received his MBA from the Harvard Graduate School of Business. He served as an officer with the Navy in World War II. He was President and COO of Amerada Hess. Services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 181 W. 76th St., New York City, Sunday, February 1, at 1:45 PM. We will all miss him.

headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  HENNESSEY, JULIA (NEE DUNN)

Devoted mother of Maureen Murdock of Venice, CA, and Rosemary Mc Glynn and son-in-law Denis Mc Glynn of Potomac, MD. Dear sister-in-law of Julia Durrence. Michigan Avenue, Suite 1000, Chicago, Illinois 60611 or VNA/Hospice Association, P.O. Box 2752, Vero Beach, FL 32961.

headline1: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUCKHOLD, ELLEN
headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUCKHOLD, ELLEN
lead_paragraph: BUCKHOLD-Ellen. Beloved wife, mother, and grandmother, on Sunday morning, Nov. 15, 1998. She is survived by her husband, Werner, her daughters, Leslie SchweitzerMiller, and Emily Andelman, and her grandchildren, Marc and Gillian Schweitzer, and Ethan and Matthew Andelman. In addition to her devotion to her family, she was a role model to those who knew her, and leaves behind a legacy of concern and caring for the less fortunate. She volunteered her time to childrens' causes, served as President of both the Glen Cove and Long Island Chapters of B'nai Zion, and received a certificate of Congressional recognition for her other philanthropic work. She was blessed with many talents: a beautiful lyric soprano voice, an artistic eye, a love of language and great literature, and a soaring and fertile imagination. She had music in her heart and poetry in her soul, and though all her memories were stolen, we will always remember. Services will be held Tuesday, Nov. 17, 1998 at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street in New York City. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made to The Alzheimers Association, or B'nai Zion, 130 E. 39th St, NY, NY 10016.

headline1: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRAGER, JACK (YANKEL)
headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRAGER, JACK (YANKEL)
lead_paragraph: FRAGER-Jack (Yankel). On March 7, 1998 at 95, peacefully in his sleep after a long decline. Born in the Ukraine, he witnessed the Russian Revolution, escaped the Civil War at 18, arriving in the U.S.A. in 1923. He was: a lifelong anarchist, served on Committee to save Sacco and Vanzetti, spoke nationally, helped found the Libertarian Book Club, etc; a tireless trade unionist and reformer who taught labor history at Brookwood Labor College; an anti-war activist arrested repeatedly, in War Resisters League and Broward County Anti-Nuclear Committee. Devoted nurturer of Yiddish culture, on the Editorial Board of the Freie Arbiter Schtimme, member League for Yiddish, founder Sunrise Yiddish Culture Club. Wife Myra died 1985. Survived by three children: Michelle Louise, Sholom Dwight, and Cheshire Emily and their spouses, John Bellidori, Louise Frager, and Jerry Rotondi; four grandchildren: Shoshannah, Tam, Lincoln, and Rebecca Frager; and great grandson, Caleb Frager. Beloved uncle of Paul and Mannie Schweisberg. Contributions may be sent to the Alzheimer's Association. Memorial on June 9 at Brecht Forum.

She was blessed with many talents: a beautiful, lyric soprano voice, an artistic eye, a love of language and great literature, and a soaring and fertile imagination. She had music in her heart and poetry in her soul, and though all her memories were stolen, we will always remember. Services were held Tuesday, Nov. 17, 1998. headline1: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARSONS, LORENZO L., SR.
headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARSONS, LORENZO L., SR.
lead_paragraph: PARSONS-Lorenzo L., Sr. Died June 20, 1998. Beloved husband of Isabelle. Devoted father of five children, Loretta Parsons Poole, Richard Parsons, Janet Parsons and Diane Parsons, and the late Lorenzo, Jr. Proud grandfather of Gregory Parsons, Leslie Parsons and Rebecca Parsons. Cherished uncle of Sharon Banks and a great host of other nieces, nephews, inlaws and friends. He was an important part of all their lives and will be missed dearly. A wake will be held Thursday, June 25 from 25PM and 7-9:30PM at the Bernard F. Dowd Funeral Home located at 165-20 Hillside Avenue, Jamaica, N.Y. A funeral service will be held Friday, June 26 at 10AM at New Hope Lutheran Church located at 167-25 118 Avenue, Jamaica, New York. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to the Alzheimers Association, 919 North Michigan Avenue, Chicago, IL 60611 or to the Larry Parsons Scholarship Fund at New Hope Lutheran Church, in memory of the deceased.

headline1: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEBER, MORTIMER W. , M.D.
headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEBER, MORTIMER W. , M.D.
lead_paragraph: WEBER-Mortimer W. , M.D., age 84 of Wayne, NJ, formerly of Franklin Lakes, NJ. Beloved husband of Barbara (nee Steuert) Parker Weber. Dear father of Jon Weber of Monterey, CA., and James Weber of Seattle, WA. Dear uncle of Tamara Leuchtenberg of NYC, NY. Loving grandfather of five granddaughters. Dr. Weber was a pediatrician in private practice in New York City for 50 years. He was a physician at Lenox Hill Hospital, New York Eye Infirmary and a physician and teacher at New York University Medical Center and Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center, all in New York City. He was an Army veteran of World War II, and served in the Philippines and in Japan as a doctor with the rank of Captain during his Army service. He was a 1938 graduate of New York University Medical School, a life member of the Alpha Omega Alpha Honor Society, & a member of the American Medical Association. Funeral services on Thursday 10 AM at the Oakland Memorial Home, 330 Ramapo Valley Road (Route 202) Oakland, NJ. Burial Woodlawn Cemetery, Bronx, NY. Visiting Wednesday 2-4 & 7-9 PM. In lieu of flowers donations to the Alzheimer's Association, 229 Cherry Hill Road, Parsippany, NJ 07054 would be appreciated.

headline1: Paid Notice: Deaths  AUCHINCLOSS, HUGH
headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  AUCHINCLOSS, HUGH
lead_paragraph: AUCHINCLOSS-Hugh, MD of Westwood, MA and Manchester, MA, formerly of Ho-Ho-Kus, NJ, died on October 25, 1998 at the age of 83. His death resulted from complications of Alzheimer's Disease. Dr. Auchincloss was born in New York City, the son of Dr. Hugh Auchincloss and Frances C. (Newlands) Auchincloss. He attended Groton School, graduated from Yale in 1938 and from the Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons in 1942. After service in the Navy during World War II, he finished his residency and joined the faculty at Columbia as Associate Clinical Professor of Surgery at Columbia. He was also Attending Surgeon at Valley Hospital in Ridgewood, NJ for 39 years prior to his retirement in 1992. He is survived by his wife of 56 years, Katharine Lawrence (Bundy) Auchincloss, three daughters, Katharine A. Corbin of Phoenix, AZ, Margaret A. Strachan of London, Elizabeth L. Auchincloss, MD of New Rochelle, NY, his son, Hugh Auchincloss, Jr, MD of Newton, MA, two sisters, Maria A. Look of West Tisbury, MA and Barbara A. Thacher of New Canaan, CT, eleven grandchildren and one great grandson. Services and interment at Mount Auburn Cemetery in Cambridge will be private. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Valley Hospital, N. Van Dien Ave, Ridgewood, NJ 07450. For information, The J.S. Waterman and Sons-Waring Funeral Home, Wellesley, MA.
