headline1: Paid Notice: Deaths  TATE, WILLIAM
headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  TATE, WILLIAM
lead_paragraph: TATE-William. A longtime Stamford resident passed away at the Courtland Gardens Health Care Center on Wednesday, April 22, 1998 due to stroke. He was 87. Born in Hackensack, New Jersey on November 6, 1910, he was the son of the late Thomas and Sarah Tate. Mr. Tate was employed at the New York Times for forty-seven years from 1929-1976. He served in classified, national and international advertising. He was named Assistant Advertising Manager in 1946, Director of Special Advertising Project in 1965, International Advertising Manager in 1968 and Advertising Manager with responsibility for the retailadvertising department in 1973. A World War II army veteran, Mr. Tate was a sergeant in the Second United States Calvary from 1943 to 1945. He served as an Armored Car Commander during World War II and was distinguished with The Silver Star, The Purple Heart and The Bronze Star. He was predeceased by his sister Doris Mitros in 1997. He is survived by his wife Mildred A. Hemmerich Tate of Stamford, Connecticut. His 3 sons: Bill Tate of Palm Harbor, FL, Brad Tate of Oceanside, CA., and Allan Tate of Bedford, MA; his two daughters Joyce Robinson of Tolland, CT., and Elaine Hjelte of Ridgefield, CT.; his sister Ethel Bullett of Fairlawn, New Jersey and eight grandchildren. Funeral services will be held at the Arlington National Cemetery in Arlington, Virginia on Friday, May 1, 1998 at 2 PM. There will be no calling hours. For further information, contact Bouton & Reynolds Funeral Home, 2900 Summer Street, Stamford, Connecticut. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to The Alzheimer's Association, Fairfield County, Chapter 607, Main Avenue, Norwalk, CT 06851.

headline1: Our Memories, Our Selves
headline2: Our Memories, Our Selves
snippet: Stephen S Hall article on nature of memory and implications of quest for memory-enhancing drugs; notes diverse group of researchers have made spectacular progress on cellular and genetic front, laying groundwork for pharmaceutical manipulation of ...
lead_paragraph: The radio was on in the background the other day, low volume as usual, when I found myself inclining toward vaguely familiar music. It was something I had once known very well, and as I began to listen more intently, a few swells of melody pushed a button somewhere in my brainpan: Gershwin. The overture to ''Of Thee I Sing.''

headline1: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARTIGAN, FRANCES GAYNOR
headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARTIGAN, FRANCES GAYNOR
lead_paragraph: HARTIGAN-Frances Gaynor. 88, died peacefully Dec. 30, 1998 in Albany, NY after suffering many years of Alzheimers Disease. Born in Troy, NY, she resided there until 1980 and was the daughter of the late John Dolan and Josephine A. McGovern Gaynor. Frances graduated from Catholic Central High School, attended the College of Mount Saint Vincent and graduated from the State University of New York at Albany. She taught English for many years at Troy High School, Troy, NY. She was the former president of the Seton Guild, former president of the United Community Services of Rensselaer County and former chairman of the Rensselaer County of Mental Health. She also formerly belonged to the Country Club of Troy, NY. Her husband, Vincent A. Hartigan, predeceased Frances in 1987, whom she married in 1935. Survivors include her children, Mary Anne Shrank of Albany, NY, Maurice H. Hartigan, II and his wife Anne Magilligan of Mount Kisco, NY, Vincent A. Hartigan, Jr. and his wife Katherine McGuire of Chicago, IL, John Gaynor Hartigan of Albany, NY and Anthony Francis Hartigan and his wife Ceile Blakeslee of Concord, NH; sister of Sister Mary Carmel, RSM of Albany, NY and Mrs. Charles F. Murphy of Albany, NY; dear friend of Eva Cox, Ecolia Morman and Gussie Biskin; also survived by 18 grandchildren and several nieces and nephews. Funeral services Saturday from the McVeigh Funeral Home, 208 North Allen St., Albany, NY 518489-0188, thence to the Church of St. John's-St. Ann's, Albany, NY. Relatives and friends are invited and may call Friday, 4 to 8 PM in the funeral home. Interment will follow the mass at St. Mary's Cemetery, Troy, NY. Those wishing to remember Frances and her family in a special way may send contributions to either the Retirement Fund of the Sisters of Mercy, 634 New Scotland Ave., Albany, NY 12208 or St. John's Center, 154 Franklin St., Albany, NY 12202.

headline2: PUBLIC LIVES; Reagan's Biographer, Memory and Teacher

lead_paragraph: OVER the last 12 years, as the biographer Edmund Morris penetrated deeper into the past of Ronald Reagan, there emerged a painful relationship between historian and subject: Mr. Morris's knowledge of the former President was expanding as Mr. Reagan's was contracting. By 1994, shortly after Mr. Reagan announced that he had progressive memory loss because of Alzheimer's disease, Mr. Morris stopped interviewing him.

headline1: Scientists Find Enzyme Linked To Alzheimer's
headline2: Scientists Find Enzyme Linked To Alzheimer's
snippet: Scientists discover enzyme that plays into development of Alzheimer's disease, opening door to developing drugs that might block it and, if drugs prove safe, to preventing or slowing the disease; discovery of enzyme had eluded teams of scientists ...
lead_paragraph: The long, brutal process that leads to Alzheimer's disease starts when a single enzyme snips a protein that protrudes from brain cells, leading to the release of toxic shards. Now scientists report that they have found that enzyme, opening the door to developing drugs that might block it and, if the drugs prove safe, to preventing or slowing the disease.

headline1: October 17-23; Scientists Find Enzyme Linked to Alzheimer's
headline2: October 17-23; Scientists Find Enzyme Linked to Alzheimer's
lead_paragraph: Scientists have known for years that to forestall or treat Alzheimer's disease they needed to prevent hard balls of debris from accumulating in the brain. Now researchers at Amgen have taken the first step toward that goal. They found an elusive enzyme that snips a brain protein in two, initiating the formation of the debris. The next challenge, experts say, is to find a drug that will block that enzyme. If the scientific theory is correct, such a drug might halt the death of brain cells in people with the disease and even prevent the disease in people destined to get it. GINA KOLATA

headline1: July 4-10; Vaccine in Mice Offers Hope in Alzheimer's Fight
headline2: July 4-10; Vaccine in Mice Offers Hope in Alzheimer's Fight
lead_paragraph: Scientists have developed a potential vaccine for Alzheimer's disease. Researchers at Elan Pharmaceuticals in South San Francisco, a division of the Elan Corporation of Dublin, used mice that had been genetically altered so they produced plaques of amyloid protein in their brains, a primary abnormality in Alzheimer's.

headline1: The Zen of Alzheimer's
headline2: The Zen of Alzheimer's
snippet: Suzanne Cloud disputes Steve Gettinger's August 15 column calling Alzheimer's disease a grace, cocoon and escape (S)
lead_paragraph: To call Alzheimer's disease ''a grace, a cocoon, an escape into the pure moment,'' sent shivers through me. Gettinger confuses a Zen moment with successive periods of mental blankness that engender no reflection at all. A patient in the end stages of this disease could be looking at a flower or a shoot-'em-up on TV and not know the difference. I understand that he needs to put the best face on the experience of dealing with his mother's disease, but saying that forgetfulness ''set her free'' is ludicrous. The sooner a treatment is found the better.

headline1: Injection Of Cells Aids Mice
headline2: Injection Of Cells Aids Mice
snippet: Biologists partly cure mice of a disease resembling multiple sclerosis by injecting restorative cells into their brains; Dr Evan Y Snyder of Harvard Medical School says his experiment shows, in principle, that neural stem cells can migrate all ove...
lead_paragraph: In a possible glimpse at the brain surgery of the future, biologists have partly cured mice of a disease resembling multiple sclerosis by injecting restorative cells into their brains.

headline1: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHER, ZACHARY
headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHER, ZACHARY
lead_paragraph: FISHER-Zachary. The scientists, researchers and health professionals of The Zachary and Elizabeth M. Fisher Alzheimer's Disease Education and Resources Program of the New York University School of Medicine are profoundly saddened by the passing of Zachary Fisher. Mr. Fisher's generosity, personal kindness and vision enabled the creation of our program which has permitted us to articulate a new science of Alzheimer's Disease management and to disseminate this information worldwide. All victims of Alzheimer's Disease and their loved ones have lost a true and wonderful friend and ally. Barry Reisberg, M.D., Dir. Sunnie Kenowsky, D.V.M., Co-Director Emile Franssen, M.D. Liduin E.M. Souren, R.N., M.S.N. and our fellow program scientists

headline1: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOBIN, RAE KATZ
headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOBIN, RAE KATZ
lead_paragraph: TOBIN-Rae Katz. Age 85, died on Monday, Nov. 29, 1999. The light in Rae's eyes shone with intelligence, love, good humor and wit. With heart and mind, she nurtured her family, fought for a better world and nursed her husband Mike through his terrible battle with Alzheimer's. She left the world a better place. We'll miss this warm and wonderful woman. Rae is survived by her sister Norma Katz Menter, her son Daniel, her daughter and son-in-law Susan and John Schoonover and grandchildren Carl, Danny and Julie. Contributions to Alzheimer's Association, 360 Lexington Avenue, New York, New York 10017.

lead_paragraph: HALBFINGER - Martin William (Bill). Died on June 19, 1999, at age 62, of heart failure after years battling Alzheimer's Disease. Donations may be made to Alzheimer's Disease Research, 15825 Shady Grove Rd., Suite 140, Rockville, MD 20850.

headline1: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERMAN, HAROLD
headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERMAN, HAROLD
lead_paragraph: SILVERMAN-Harold. Age 87 years. Died peacefully in his sleep after a long battle with Alzheimer's disease. Beloved and cherished husband of Evelyn, adored father of Nancy and Norman, grandfather of Morgun and William. Harold was a devoted son, husband and father, who used his gifts of uncommon wisdom, compassion and insight to inspire and improve the lives of many who knew him. He rose to meet the many challenges in his own life with indefatigable determination, a clarity of purpose and an abundance of humor. We will miss him. Services today in San Diego, CA. In lieu of flowers, the family would appreciate a donation to the Alzheimer's Association, 360 Lexington Ave., New York, NY 10017.

headline1: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROGOVIN, JACK
headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROGOVIN, JACK
lead_paragraph: ROGOVIN-Jack. Age 87, passed away on October 17, 1999 in Hollywood, Florida due to complications of pneumonia and a heart attack. Longtime teacher of French, Spanish & Russian and Guidance Counselor at Tilden High School in Brooklyn. Active in the Teachers Union. He served in the Army Signal Corps, South Pacific during W.W.II. Devoted husband of the late Gussie whom he visited faithfully every day for more than a dozen years after she contracted Alzheimers. Survived by numerous loving nieces and nephews. In lieu of flowers please make contributions to the Alzheimers Disease and Related Disease Association of Broward County, FL (He was President of the Fort Lauderdale chapter for many years.) Services 11AM Thurs, New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, L.I., NY.

headline1: Paid Notice: Deaths  TIMMERMAN, ROBERT E.
headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  TIMMERMAN, ROBERT E.
lead_paragraph: TIMMERMAN-Robert E. Died July 29, 1999 at the Greenwich Hospital of Alzheimer's disease. Mr. Timmerman was a long-time resident of Greenwich, Conn., but also maintained homes in Palm Beach, Fla., and Kennebunkport, Me. Mr. Timmerman was the son of the late Hearst Publisher Edward W. Timmerman and Maude Ayer Timmerman of Chicago. He is survived by his wife, Paula Reid Timmerman. Mr. Timmerman attended the Taft School and Brown University. During World War II, he was an officer in the Air Corps. During his lifetime, Mr. Timmerman had an active career in the field of advertising, holding senior positions with a number of agencies in New York City. At the time of his retirement, he was a senior vice president with Needham, Harper, Steers. In addition to his business interests, Mr. Timmerman was active in a number of social clubs including the Kennebunk River Club, Greenwich Country Club, Metropolitan Club and the Everglades Club. A private family service will be held in Rhode Island. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Alzheimer's Foundation would be preferred.

headline1: Paid Notice: Deaths  MATTLAGE, LOUISE
headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  MATTLAGE, LOUISE
lead_paragraph: MATTLAGE-Louise. Multi-talented modern dance, artist, and poet died on March 9, 1999, in Boca Raton, FL. She was 92, and the cause was advanced Alzheimer's Disease. A sophisticated woman with a wide range of cultural interests, Ms. Mattlage's career took her from modern dance with Jose Limon, and Doris Humphrey, to director and choreographer of her own dance company, based in CT, called The Dancers of Faith. The Dance Company performed in countless churches and synagogues throughout the eastern United States. She taught modern dance at college and universities all around the world. She was the author of four books of poetry. Her numerous poems and essays were published in periodicals often concerning women's issues. Born and raised in Boston, MA, Ms. Mattlage lived for many years in Fairfield and Southport, CT. She moved to Key Biscayne, FL in 1971. She continued to spend summers in Fairfield, CT. She was a member of the Miami chapter of the Pen Women and she lectured and performed her dance and poetry well into her 80's. In 1989, she moved to Boca Raton, FL. She is survived by her son Jonathan Mattlage of Acworth, GA, her daughter Valerie Mattlage of Boca Raton, FL, and her two grandsons: Jason Ledyard, of New York, NY, and Jonathan Mattlage, Jr. of Kennesaw, GA. She was pre-deceased by her husband of 65 years, W.F.H. Mattlage. Memorial contributions may be made to either the National Organization for Women, or The Alzheimer's Association.

headline1: Paid Notice: Deaths  CORSON, RICHARD
headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  CORSON, RICHARD
lead_paragraph: CORSON-Richard. On January 13th, 1999. Eminent theatre makeup authority, teacher and author of ''Stage Makeup'' in current use, with the 9th edition forthcoming. His essential reference works include ''Fashions in Hair: The First 5000 Years,'' ''Fashions in Makeup: From Ancient to Modern Times,'' and ''Fashions in Eyeglasses: From the 14th Century to Present Day.'' These definitive reference sources have been translated throughout the world. He taught at USC-Long Beach, was Adjunct Professor at Southern Methodist University, and conducted numerous seminars. He was consultant for productions on and off-Broadway. Contributions in his name may be made to Alzheimer's research.

headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOWARD, HELEN (NEE BERRYMAN)
lead_paragraph: HOWARD-Helen (nee Berryman). On February 16, 1999. Age 91. Formerly of Montclair, N.J., Dorset, VT. and Hilton Head, S.C. Beloved mother of Ann (Stuart) Tisdale, Fox Point, WI. and Barbara (James) Mihalke, Pittsburgh, PA. Dear grandmother of Peter Holan, Moscow, ID., Scott (Tena) Holan, Shorewood, WI., Bruce (Angela) Holan, Shorewood, WI., Nicholas Mihalke, Pittsburgh, PA., Michael (Julie) Mihalke, Columbia, MD., and William Mihalke, New York, N.Y. Loving great grandmother of Haley Holan and Amanda Mihalke. Further survived by five step grandsons and their families. Also survived by dear nieces, their families, other relatives and friends. Service in Dorset, Vermont. at a later date. Memorials appreciated to Alzheimer's Association or National Multiple Sclerosis Society.

headline1: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLACK, EDWARD
headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLACK, EDWARD
lead_paragraph: BLACK-Edward. Age 90. Beloved husband for 63 years of Muriel Fleischman Black, wonderful father of Jo Ann and Howard Chase, adored and adoring Grandpa Eddie to Adam Chase, loving brother to five siblings and Uncle Eddie to every child he ever met. He was ''The Baron'' of the New York Journal American for many years before going into the public relations business. He served in Great Britain in World War II. Eddie was blessed with an extraordinarily outgoing personality, a great sense of humor and genuine kindness and generosity to all who crossed his path. Services were held Sunday, October 10, in Miami. Contributions in his memory may be made to ''Alzheimer's Care Committee/Notables'' of Douglas Gardens, 5200 Northeast Second Avenue, Miami, FL 33137.

headline1: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWMYER, ARTHUR G., JR.
headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWMYER, ARTHUR G., JR.
lead_paragraph: NEWMYER-Arthur G., Jr. On April 30, at Suburban Hospital in Maryland, beloved father of Barbara N. Johnson and A. G. Newmyer III, and brother of James M. Newmyer; devoted grandfather. A funeral service will be held at The Washington Hebrew Congregation cemetery in Washington, DC, at 1 p.m. on Sunday, May 2. The family will receive friends at 4 p.m. on May 2 at the home of Mr. and Mrs. James Newmyer, 3003 Audubon Terrace, N.W. Contributions in Mr. Newmyer's memory may be made to the National Conference for Community and Justice at Suite 1050, 1815 H Street, N.W., Washington, DC 20006; the Alzheimer's Association at 1003 K Street, N.W., Washington, DC 20001; or The Fair Care Foundation, at Suite 350, 3201 New Mexico Avenue, Washington, DC 20016.

headline1: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, JULIUS
headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, JULIUS
lead_paragraph: BERNSTEIN-Julius. Of Andover, MA, formerly of New York, NY. On Wednesday, March 3. Beloved husband of the late Ann (Miller) Bernstein. Loving father of Janie Fischbach of Indiana and Daniel J. Bernstein of Andover, MA. Father-in-law of Ephraim Fischbach and Doree T. Barton. Cherished grandfather of Jonathan, Jeremy and Michael Fischbach, Jenna and Meredith Bernstein. Dear brother of Simon Burnett of New Jersey, Regina Brooks of Boston, MA, and Ethel Morse of California. Memorial observance Friday until 7 P.M. and Saturday 6 to 9 P.M., at the home of Daniel Bernstein & Doree Barton. headline1: Paid Notice: Deaths  WIMSATT, MARGARET ELIZABETH HECHT
headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  WIMSATT, MARGARET ELIZABETH HECHT
lead_paragraph: WIMSATT-Margaret Elizabeth Hecht died November 22, 1999. She was born in Chicago, IL, February 26, 1919, to the late Frank Abner and Margaret Lipps Hecht. She is survived by her son, James Velvet Wimsatt, and her daughter-in-law, Nancy Lee Abbey, of Hamden, CT. She was predeceased by her son, Alexander Wimsatt, a student, and her husband, William Kurtz Wimsatt Jr., Sterling Professor of English at Yale University. She was a graduate of the University of Chicago and Yale. She was a poet, reviewer, essayist and a teacher of English composition at the University of New Mexico and Yale. She was a resident of New Haven, CT. from 1941-1997. In lieu of flowers, memorial gifts may be sent to the South Central CT Chapter of the Alzheimer's Association, 2911 Dixwell Avenue, Hamden, CT. 06518. For information: The Hawley Lincoln Memorial, 493 Whitney Avenue, New Haven, CT.

headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCADAMS, JOHN V. SR.
lead_paragraph: McADAMS-John V. Sr.., 82, of Kirland Village, Bethlehem, PA. formerly of Rancho Sante Fe, CA., and Monclair, NJ on Wednesday, November 10, 1999. No calling hours. Memorial contributions to Alzheimers Disease & Related Disorders 325 Chestnut St., Phil, PA Survivors are wife Anne McAdams of CA., sons John V. Jr. of Pittson, NJ, Michael X. of Sommertown, TN., Bruce E. of Park City Utah, Scott T. of Melbourne Florida, Gregg of Waretown, NJ. Helen Radcliffe of Bath, PA.

headline1: Paid Notice: Deaths  PFEIFFER, MARTHA GOLDHAMMER NEE ADDIS
headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  PFEIFFER, MARTHA GOLDHAMMER NEE ADDIS
lead_paragraph: PFEIFFER-Martha Goldhammer nee Addis, formerly of the Bronx, New York, died on May 5, 1999. Born on September 25, 1908. Daughter of Henrietta nee Weinberg and Percy Addis, widow of Rubin Pfeiffer, predeceased by her first husband, Isidore Goldhammer, and her son, Dr. Robert Goldhammer. Survived by her daughter-in-law, Florie Brettler Goldhammer, of Pittsburgh; granddaughters, Anne M. Goldhammer Moore, of Chicago, and Elizabeth P. Kuzma, of Pittsburgh; a great-granddaughter, Emily Morgan Kuzma, of Pittsburgh; and a brother, Aaron Addis, of Delray Beach, FL. After receiving her Master's degree from New York City's Hunter College in 1933, Mrs. Pfeiffer taught French, Latin, Italian & German at James Monroe and DeWitt Clinton high schools in New York City until her retirement in 1973. Memorial services will be held at the Goldhammer residence on Sunday, May 9, at 1 P.M. Instead of flowers, contributions may be made to the Alzheimer's Disease Alliance of Western Pennsylvania, 5180 Campbell's Run Road, Pittsburgh, PA 15205, Attention: Martha Fenchak Bell.

headline1: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEIDER, NORMAN
headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEIDER, NORMAN
lead_paragraph: SCHNEIDER-Norman. Age 88 of New York City. Devoted husband to Jo Anne, adoring father of Lois Oppenheim and Melanie Tucker, and loving grandfather of Sarah and Keith Oppenheim. He founded and was President of Allison Manufacturing Company and later was President of the Leisure Products Division of the Beatrice Cos. He gave unstintingly of himself to many charitable institutions and professional associations, and served with distinction on various corporate boards. Services will be held on Monday, July 19th at Temple Emanu-El, 1 East 65th Street, at 12:00 noon. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his name to the New York City Chapter of the Alzheimer's Association, 360 Lexington Avenue, 5th Floor, New York, New York 10017.

headline1: Novartis Profit Rises; Merger Savings Cited
headline2: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS; Novartis Profit Rises; Merger Savings Cited
snippet: Novartis AG says its profit in the second half of 1998 rose 20 percent to 2.51 billion Swiss francs ($1.7 billion) from 2.09 billion year earlier (S)
lead_paragraph: Novartis A.G., the world's No. 3 drug maker, indicated yesterday that its profit in the second half of 1998 rose 20 percent on improved profit margins and on cost savings resulting from the merger that formed the company. The implied second-half profit at the company, which makes the hypertension drug Diovan and the Alzheimer's drug Exelon, rose to 2.51 billion Swiss francs ($1.7 billion) from 2.09 billion a year earlier.

headline1: When a Loss Remains Unresolved
headline2: When a Loss Remains Unresolved
lead_paragraph: Jenny and and her husband had enjoyed 15 years of an emotionally and intellectually fulfilling marriage when he suffered a stroke and Jenny's whole life suddenly screeched to a halt. Instead of gradually recovering, over the next five years her husband got progressively worse. The stroke had unmasked or hastened the onset of Alzheimer's disease, and Jenny became his permanent de facto caretaker.

headline1: Paid Notice: Deaths  PINKHAM, MARY S.
headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  PINKHAM, MARY S.
lead_paragraph: PINKHAM-Mary S. (''Bunnie''). On March 8, 1999. Born in New York City December 28, 1916, the dear daughter of the late William W. and Mary G. Struthers. Adoring wife of Richard Alden Ray Pinkham, whom she married in 1941, who died in 1997. Loving and dedicated mother of Mary P. (''Penny'') Janeway of Cambridge, MA, Richard Jr. of Rye, NY, David of Barrington, RI and Elizabeth P. (''Betty'') Anderson of Billings, MT. Delighted grandmother of Sam, Daisy, Laurie, Rick, Mary, Rosie, Jamie and Tim. Sister of Nina S. Bremer, Sara S. Frothingham and the late William W. Struthers, Jr. She lived in Rye, NY until 1981 when she and her husband moved to Hobe Sound, FL and Greenwich, CT. She was a student, teacher, parent, grandparent and President of the Board of Trustees of her dear alma mater, Rye Country Day School. When the School expanded to become co-ed through 12th grade, The Mary Struthers Pinkham Building was named in her honor. She served on the Board of Managers of the United Hospital, where her four children were born, and where she died. She also served on the Advisory Board of the Foundation for Children with Learning Disabilities. An athlete all her life, she was an All-American in lacrosse and field hockey, a notable tennis player, and a golfer in her later years. Her dearest friendships lasted a lifetime, and she was widely admired and loved for her loyalty, sense of duty, selflessness, uprightness and old-fashioned grace. She has gone from the double darkness of Alzheimer's and bereavement into the Light. We grieve and we rejoice. Family visitation at William H. Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Road in Rye on Wednesday, March 10 from 6:00 to 8:00 pm. Memorial service at 11:00 am, Thursday, March 11 at Christ Church, Milton Road, Rye. Contributions in her name may be made to the Rye Country Day School, Rye, New York 10580.

headline1: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEPHENS, THOMAS J.
headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEPHENS, THOMAS J.
lead_paragraph: STEPHENS-Thomas J., a White Plains lawyer, died on March 2, 1999 in Briarcliff Manor, New York, after a long bout with Parkinson's disease. He was 76. Mr. Stephens was born in Brooklyn, New York on September 18, 1922. He graduated from Polytechnic Preparatory School in Brooklyn and Colgate University where he attended summer sessions in order to join the U.S. Army during World War II as a private in 1942. Mr. Stephens served in the 36th infantry division of the 5th Army and eventually rose to first lieutenant in command of a rifle company with the 7th Army. He served in North Africa, Italy, France and Germany and participated in numerous campaigns, including Rapido River, Monte Cassino, the Breakthrough at Anzio, the liberation of Rome, and the invasions of Southern France and the German Rhineland. He received a battlefield commission for heroic action beyond the line of duty, the Bronze Star with a cluster, five battle stars and the combat infantryman's badge, among other decorations. After the War, Mr. Stephens earned his law degree from Syracuse University and practiced in New York City before founding the firm Stephens & Buderwitz in White Plains, New York where he practiced for nearly 40 years. Mr. Stephens ran for mayor of White Plains in 1952 and was continually active in White Plains and Westcheter County affairs. He served as President of the Bar Association of White Plains, President of the YMCA, President of the Board of Trustees of the Presbyterian Church in White Plains and on the board of EM Industries and numerous other corporations. He was a member of the Whippoorwill Club in Armonk, New York. Mr. Stephens was instrumental in the planning and design of the Kingsley House residences on Barker Avenue in White Plains, restructured its sponsorship and funding and assured its completion after the initial program encountered difficulties prior to completion. Funeral services will be held at the White Plains Presbyterian Church 39 North Broadway, White Plains on Saturday, March 6, at 10:30 am. The family requests that, in lieu of flowers, donations be sent to the Alzheimer's Association. Mr. Stephens is survived by wife Inge of North Salem, New York, sister Margaret Christie, son Christopher, daughters Eleanor and Merielle and granddaughter, Lara.

headline1: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDHAR, MAXWELL
headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDHAR, MAXWELL
lead_paragraph: GOLDHAR-Maxwell, 82, a man who enriched the lives of his family, friends and the people of Ontario, died suddenly at home Tuesday night from a heart attack. Still active in business and pursuing his dreams through his last days, Mr. Goldhar left major accomplishments and a loving circle of family and friends behind him. Mr. Goldhar devoted over 50 years of his life to voluntary service, and he was recently invested with the Order of Ontario. He was well known for his substantial contributions to technology, manufacturing and natural resources companies in Canada and internationally, in particular Ontario Store Fixtures, Fantom Technologies and Fifty Plus Net International. As a business leader he earned the nickname ''Dr. Business'' for his achievements in helping to ''turn around'' declining Ontario companies. Founding president of the President's Council of the Canadian Opera Company and a founding director of the York Racquet Club, Hockley Valley Ski Club and the Island Yacht Club, Mr. Goldhar was a leader who constructively countered the exclusion of Jews from many of the city's social organizations by opening new opportunities for them through these organizations. Mr. Goldhar was treasurer of the building campaign for the northern YMHA and served for many years as director of the Canadian Society for the Weizmann Institute of Science. At the time of his death, Mr. Goldhar was an active director of ''CARP,'' the Canadian Association of Retired Persons, and a founding director of Fifty Plus Net International, the leading Internet supplier to seniors in Canada. Mr. Goldhar recently joined the board of Sunnybrook and Women's Health Sciences Centre, and served as Chair of the Board of Women's College Health Research Inc. Previously, he served as the Chair of the Hospital Council of Metropolitan Toronto, Chair of the Board of both the Northwestern General Hospital and the Northwestern Health Centre Foundation, a director of Women's College Hospital and treasurer of the Alzheimer Association of Ontario. He is survived by his loving family: by his son, Dan, and Dan's wife, Janet; by daughters Nancy, Heather and Renanah and Heather's partner, James Neal; by his grandchildren Jeremy and Rachel; his brothers Albert and Morty and their wives Booty and Rosemary, respectively; and by his sister, Wendy Rue. Mr. Goldhar was predeceased by his wife of 50 years, Jeanette, and survived by his loving spouse, Marilou McPhedran. Services will be conducted at 2:30 PM today by Mr. Goldhar's close friend and tennis partner, Rabbi Gunther Plaut, at Holy Blossom Temple in Toronto.

headline1: The Growing Business of Helping Elders Cope
headline2: The Growing Business of Helping Elders Cope
snippet: Deborah Newquist is geriatric care manager in Newport Beach, Calif, occupation that did not exist when she received her master's degree in social work 24 years ago; field was born in response to nation's rapidly aging population and health care sy...
lead_paragraph: When an 86-year-old woman with Alzheimer's disease broke her hip, Deborah Newquist was the person who stayed with her at the hospital here. Years earlier, Dr. Newquist had arranged 24-hour home care for the woman and her bedridden husband, and she also took care of everything from having their house painted to getting their cat to the veterinarian.

headline1: Talk, Too, As Topics Trip By
headline2: DANCE REVIEW; Talk, Too, As Topics Trip By
snippet: Jack Anderson reviews Tere O'Connor Dance program at Kitchen (S)
lead_paragraph: Tere O'Connor's ''Hi Everybody!'' certainly wasn't boring. It couldn't have been. Mr. O'Connor changed his choreographic mind so often in it that no single subject ever grew dull. As presented on Thursday night at the Kitchen by Tere O'Connor Dance, the 45-minute piece touched on such matters as cancer, Alzheimer's disease, war, peace, retirement communities, gay marriage and homophobia, to name only a few of the topics that whizzed by to outbursts of recorded music by James Baker.

lead_paragraph: It happened very suddenly and was perhaps the most violent act in which I have ever participated. A space became available and we had to grab it or risk waiting maybe six or eight months for another.

headline1: The Next Job Perk: Elder Care for Parents
headline2: The Next Job Perk: Elder Care for Parents
snippet: Article on rising focus on care of aged among Long Island companies as their work forces age and more employees have to care for their elderly parents; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: MARILEE CRISPINO said she had always dreamed of retiring at age 55. Now it's definite, but hardly as pleasurable a prospect as she had anticipated. She is ''hoping and praying,'' she said, that she can juggle office and home responsibilities until June 9, 2000, when she will quit being an administrative assistant at the New York State United Teachers in Hauppauge and devote her days to caring for her 81-year-old mother, who has Alzheimer's disease.

headline1: Louis Feraud Is Dead at 79; Prominent Fashion Designer
headline2: Louis Feraud Is Dead at 79; Prominent Fashion Designer
snippet: French fashion designer Louis Feraud dies at age 79; photo (S)
lead_paragraph: Louis Feraud, a prominent French fashion designer who first made his name in the mid-1950's when Brigitte Bardot began wearing his brightly colored summer dresses, died on Tuesday at his home in Paris. He was 79. French news reports said he had been suffering from Alzheimer's disease.

headline1: The Way We Live Now: 10-24-99: The Ethicist; Be Medicareful
headline2: The Way We Live Now: 10-24-99: The Ethicist; Be Medicareful
snippet: The Ethicist column answers question about transferring assets in order to qualify for Medicaid nursing home care; also answers question on taking gasoline from closed service station, when driver has been led down dark road by sign (S)
lead_paragraph: My mother has Alzheimer's disease and her doctor has warned me that she soon will need to be placed in a nursing home. Several years ago, her lawyer advised me to transfer her assets to my name so that she could qualify for Medicaid and I could inherit her money. This is perfectly legal, and according to other people in the same situation I've spoken to, it is widely done. But is it ethical? /G.O.

headline2: Serving the Less Fortunate For Credit and Just Because

headline1: VITAL SIGNS: AT RISK; A Village Visited Often by Alzheimer's
headline2: VITAL SIGNS: AT RISK; A Village Visited Often by Alzheimer's
snippet: Researchers studying Wadi Ara, Arab village in Israel with unusually high rates of Alzheimer's disease, suspect recessive gene plays role in condition when carried by both parents; all other genes related to Alzheimer's are dominant (S)
lead_paragraph: An Arab village in Israel with unusually high rates of Alzheimer's disease suggests that a recessive gene plays a role in the condition, one that must be carried by both parents to take effect, according to a new study in the journal Neurology.

headline1: Hints of Alzheimer's Found in the Nose
headline2: VITAL SIGNS: AGING; Hints of Alzheimer's Found in the Nose
snippet: Researchers say problems identifying aromas may indicate early Alzheimer's disease, but only when patients do not realize that something is amiss with sense of smell (S)
lead_paragraph: In recent months, researchers have pointed to possible signals of Alzheimer's disease that could allow doctors to detect the ailment before symptoms start. They have spoken of small areas of the brain that appear to shrink, and psychological tests that yield subtle clues.

headline1: Losing My Father, One Day at a Time
headline2: Losing My Father, One Day at a Time
snippet: Jonathan Kozol Op-Ed article on his father's deterioration from Alzheimer's says Medicare and Medicaid rules should be revised to cover long-term care for this illness; lauds Pres Clinton's plan for $50 million research program to advance early di...
lead_paragraph: President Clinton recently announced a $50 million research program to advance the early diagnosis and investigate the possible prevention of Alzheimer's, a disease that now afflicts more than four million people in our nation. One of them is my father, and, like others who have seen their parents' mental faculties assaulted by this illness, I was grateful for the president's decision, wishing only that my father were still young enough to benefit.

headline1: JOHNSON & JOHNSON ALZHEIMER'S DRUG NEARS APPROVAL
headline2: COMPANY NEWS; JOHNSON & JOHNSON ALZHEIMER'S DRUG NEARS APPROVAL
snippet: Johnson & Johnson's treatment for Alzheimer's disease, Reminyl, is close to Food and Drug Administration approval (S)
lead_paragraph: Johnson & Johnson's treatment for Alzheimer's disease, Reminyl, is close to Food and Drug Administration approval, the agency said, bringing the company a step nearer to selling the drug in the United States. Johnson & Johnson said yesterday that it had received a so-called approvable letter from the F.D.A. The letters spell out final issues to be resolved before the agency will allow a drug to be marketed; such issues often involve product labeling. A study financed by Johnson & Johnson found that the drug, which has the chemical name of galantamine hydrobromide, improves all three types of disabilities that Alzheimer's patients commonly suffer.

headline1: Separating Research From News
headline2: REFLECTIONS; Separating Research From News
snippet: Gina Kolata column on recent ado over early phase testing of Alzheimer's disease vaccine; discusses ethics of reporting research on drugs that may never make it to market (M)
lead_paragraph: The news seemed breathtaking. An Alzheimer's vaccine that had previously worked in mice now seemed safe in patients. Many newspapers ran enthusiastic articles; some even put the news on their front pages, signaling that it was among the most important events of the day. Radio and television programs were even more upbeat, hinting strongly that help was on the way for the four million Americans with Alzheimer's.

headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOKAYER, EDITH
lead_paragraph: TOKAYER-Edith. Of Riverdale, NY, and Boca Raton, FL. Beloved mother, sister, aunt, died on February 5, due to complications from Alzheimer's Disease. She was 81 years old. She was a graduate of Hunter College and an elementary school teacher in the Bronx for more than 30 years. Member of Brandeis Women. Dear wife of the late Barney L. Survived by her loving children, Marilyn, Douglas and daughter-inlaw Susan; sister Thelma; nieces Debra and Linda; nephews Eric and Jonathan. Services will be at Riverside Chapel in Mt. Vernon, NY, on Monday, February 7, at 12:30 PM. In lieu of flowers, donations to Alzheimer's Association appreciated. Family will receive friends at 158 Ogden Ave, Dobbs Ferry.

headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  NIERENBERG, JOAN WERBLIN
lead_paragraph: NIERENBERG-Joan Werblin. Age 80. On July 16, 2000 after a valiant battle with Alzheimer's. Former Life Magazine copy chief and SUNY Purchase Trustee. Born in Somerville, N.J., graduate of Mount Holyoke College, and longtime resident of Chappaqua, N.Y. Survived by her husband, David E. Nierenberg of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., and sister Elinor Glass of Bedminster, N.J. She also leaves behind her loving children Wendy Gibney of Berkeley, Ca., David Nierenberg of Lebanon, N.H., Lorie Nierenberg of McLean, Va., and six grandchildren, of whom she was so proud. Memorial contributions may be made to the Alzheimer's Association-New York City Chapter, 360 Lexington Ave, Fifth Floor, New York, NY 10017.

headline2: Is Memory Loss Inevitable? Maybe Not
snippet: Brain researchers study memory loss, with view to tracing memory loss in the aging process and developing treatments; studies have shown that more than a third of elderly can remember names and events in their lives as sharply as their 20-year-old...
lead_paragraph: Ruth Arnold can recall a time when her memory was perfect. Years ago, working as a college reference librarian, she could put her finger on any piece of minutia at will. ''I remembered all the books and what was in them,'' Mrs. Arnold said.

headline1: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPIVACK, JOHN D.
headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPIVACK, JOHN D.
lead_paragraph: SPIVACK-John D. 80, passed away December 23, 1999, in Suffern, NY, after a long struggle with Alzheimer's disease. He received his Ph.D. in chemistry from McGill in 1947, married, emigrated to the United States, and became a loving father to three children. He worked for thirty-six years for Ciba Geigy Corporation in Ardsley, NY, on light stabilizers and antioxidants and was considered an international expert in the field, credited with over 125 patents. He was politically active throughout his life, and culturally involved in Yiddish language and cultural activities. He is survived by his wife of 52 years, Thelma Goresky Spivack of Chestnut Ridge, NY; two sisters, Ruth Rubin and Esther Marks; three children, Berel, Ellen and Simon; as well as three grandchildren, Daniel, Jordan and Jacqueline. Private services were held at the family home. Donations to the Alzheimer's and Parkinson's foundations are appreciated.

headline1: August 13-19; New Hope for Nerve Disease
headline2: August 13-19; New Hope for Nerve Disease
lead_paragraph: Bone marrow cells that would normally turn into tendon, cartilage, bone, muscle and fat can also turn into nerve cells, scientists report. All that is needed is to add a simple mixture of chemicals to a broth that nourishes the marrow cells in the laboratory. While cautioning that the work is in its earliest stages, researchers say it may eventually offer a new source of nerve cells to treat spinal cord injuries or diseases like Alzheimer's and Parkinson's. Gina Kolata

headline1: January 16-22; Feeding Tubes Can Be Cruel
headline2: January 16-22; Feeding Tubes Can Be Cruel
lead_paragraph: When people with advanced Alzheimer's disease become unable to eat, it might seem humane and logical to feed them through a stomach tube, as many hospitals and nursing homes do. But tube feeding is far from an act of kindness, according to an article in The New England Journal of Medicine. Experts say tube feeding does not help most demented patients, and may increase their suffering: they often pull out the tubes, and wind up in restraints and sedated.

headline2: States See Problems With Care at Chain Of Centers for Aged
snippet: Nation's largest chain of assisted living facilities, operated by Alterra Healthcare Corp, comes under scrutiny by state regulators over quality of care and safety conditions at some of its centers; regulators in at least five states complain that...
lead_paragraph: The nation's largest chain of assisted living facilities, including about 150 residences for people with Alzheimer's disease, has come under scrutiny in recent months by state regulators over the quality of care and safety conditions at some of its centers.

headline1: CAMPAIGN NOTES: JOHN McCAIN; WHOSE LAUGH?
headline2: CAMPAIGN NOTES: JOHN McCAIN; WHOSE LAUGH?
snippet: New Hampshire affiliate of National Right to Life committee, which opposes Sen John McCain's presidential candidacy because he wants to change campaign finance laws, picks up on joking remark McCain made, accusing him of being insensitive to elder...
lead_paragraph: One day last September, Senator John McCain was bantering with reporters on his campaign bus about something that had slipped his mind, and he joked that at 63 he was becoming old and senile. ''The nice thing about Alzheimer's,'' he cracked, ''is you get to hide your own Easter eggs.''

Uncle of Roberta Doocey and Frances Doocey of Roslindale. Memorial service and reception on Sunday, December 10, 1-4 PM, at Brookline High School, Brookline, MA. In lieu of flowers, donations in memory of John may be made to Alzheimers Association of Eastern Ma., 36 Cameron Ave., Cambridge, MA 02140. Late WWII veteran. For information, Commonwealth Cremation Service, Boston.

headline1: Paid Notice: Deaths  KING, ROBERT W.
headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  KING, ROBERT W.
lead_paragraph: KING-Robert W. On August 4, 2000, at age 81. Beloved husband of Virginia. Loving father of Cynthia Betts, Sara Gervasio, John E. King, Mary Braley and William W. King. Step-father of Susan DeVoge and Deborah Dunn. Adored grandfather of 12. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Tuesday, 68 PM, and Wednesday, 12-3 PM. headline1: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOFFMAN, LEON
headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOFFMAN, LEON
lead_paragraph: HOFFMAN-Leon. On September 30, 2000, at 85 years old. Beloved husbnd of the late Rita. Loving father of Roy and his wife Sandra, Jane and her husband Dr. David Zelman. Cherished grandfather of Lisa, Mark, Lori, Jeremy and Allison. Dear brother of Rose Hateau. Unselfishly placing his family's needs above his own, he was an exemplary role model for his adoring grandchildren. Former New York Daily Mirror photographer, former President of the New York Press Photographers Association and member of the Board of Directors for over 40 years. Services Tuesday, October 3, 10 AM, at Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Turnpike in Woodbury, LI. Contribuitons in his name to Alzheimer's Association.

headline1: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERARD, FREDERICA STEVENS
headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERARD, FREDERICA STEVENS
lead_paragraph: BERARD-Frederica Stevens, died May 12, 2000 at age 92, in Middletown, R.I. Daughter of the late Frederic William Stevens and Alice Caroline Seely Stevens. Predeceased by her beloved husband Philippe Roger Berard and her daughter Joan Hone King. Survived by her daughter Frederica Stevens Neff and Eugenie Gallatin Angles, her son Philip Hone Auerbach, twelve grandchildren and twelve great - grandchildren. Funeral to be held at the American Cathedral in Paris on June 9, 2000 at 2:30PM. Donations may be made in her memory to Columbia University Alzheimer's Disease Research Center, 230 West 168th Street, New York, NY 10032.

headline1: Paid Notice: Deaths  KETIVE, SHIRLEY ''SHIRL
headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  KETIVE, SHIRLEY ''SHIRL
lead_paragraph: KETIVE-Shirley ''Shirl.'' Of Fort Lauderdale, FL, on October 20. Adoring, devoted wife of the late Nathan. Beloved mother of Alice (Fred) Rudin, Harriet Lerner and Sam (Randy) Ketive. Revered grandmother of Mitchell and Robert Rudin, and Rebecca Rudin Schoenberg, Valerie Ann and Jacques Lerner, and Kimberly Ketive. Great-grandmother of Scott and Benjamin Rudin, Elisabeth and Katherine Lerner, Greg, Jacob and Lilly Rudin, Miles and Paul Schoenberg. We pray she gets a chance to be with her beloved ''Nicky'' again. Interment private. Visits may be paid to the home of Randy and Samuel Ketive, Monday evening through Wednesday, October 25. Donations in her memory to the Alzheimers Foundation. For information, Gutterman-Musicant, 800522-0588.

headline1: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLLACK, IRVING
headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLLACK, IRVING
lead_paragraph: POLLACK-Irving. Died at 86 of Alzheimer's on July 5, exactly 32 years after his beloved wife Marcella. Devoted father of Darryle, Carla and Josh; loving grandfather of Rachel, Leah, Aaron, Alli, Nicholas, Daniel and Spencer. He was an important pioneer and visionary who helped develop Miami Beach into a thriving tourist area. Between the late 40's and early 80's he owned and operated hotels including the Surfcomber, Nautilus, Shelborne, and Newport. He grew up in Monticello, graduated from Cornell in 1935 and moved to Miami Beach after the war. Known as a successful businessman, he was totally dedicated to his family, who will always love and miss him.

headline1: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICHMAN, LILLIAN B.
headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICHMAN, LILLIAN B.
lead_paragraph: RICHMAN-Lillian B. On December 25, 2000 at age 76. Beloved wife of the late Dr. George Richman. Cherished and devoted mother of David. Adoring grandmother of Shoshanna Richman and Gabriel Richman. Beloved & adored sister of May Glantz and the late Saul Sorrin and adoring mother-in-law of Elizabeth Sultan. Lillian was a former partner at Bower & Gardner, and one of the first female partners at a major law firm in New York. She set a standard of excellence both in her profession and in her life that touched everyone. The funeral will take place at Gutterman's Funeral Home, 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, New York on Wednesday, December 27th, 2000, at 1 P.M. Expressions of sympathy may be made in Lillian's name to the Alzheimer's Association.

headline1: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHELAN, HAROLD SIDNEY
headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHELAN, HAROLD SIDNEY
lead_paragraph: SHELAN-Harold Sidney. On June 3, 2000, at the age of 85. Beloved husband of the late Lucille (nee Geist). Loving father of Diane and Steven Fox. Cherished grandfather of Jayson. Broad St., Mt. Vernon, NY. Funeral service Tuesday, June 6, 9:30 AM, at Congregation Kol Ami, 252 Soundview Ave., White Plains, NY. headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRESS, AGNES THERESA (NEE GEIDEMAN)

Dear mother-in-law of Dr. Joseph W. Coady and Mary J. Dress. Cherished grandmother of Dr. Loretta M. Coady-Fariborzian, Regina, Virgina and Andrew Coady; and Jimmy, Justine and Robert Dress. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests contributions to the Alzheimer's Foundation or the American Cancer Society.

headline1: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHMELTZER, ELEANOR
headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHMELTZER, ELEANOR
lead_paragraph: SCHMELTZER-Eleanor, 86, died Wednesday in Rye Brook, NY. Born in Greenwich, CT on April 22, 1913 she was the daughter of the late Alexander and Clara S. Hall Dommerich and the wife of the late Robert Schmeltzer. She attended Greenwich Academy, Rosemary Hall and Mrs. Hall's School in Pittsfield, MA. She was a member of the National Horse show, the Junior League of New York, Affiliate with Squadron A., Field Club of Sarasota, FL and the East Chop Beach Club in Martha's Vineyard, a parishoner of West Tisbury Congregational Church in Martha's Vineyard. Services will be held Monday March 6, at 11:30 AM in Dingletown Community Church, Stanwich Road, Greenwich. Memorial contributions may be made to the Alzheimer's Association, 607 Main Ave., Norwalk, CT or to a charity of one's choice.

headline1: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEILICER, BERNARD
headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEILICER, BERNARD
lead_paragraph: HEILICER-Bernard, 79, of Plainview died July 2, 2000, of natural causes after a short illenss. He enjoyed a successful career as an aeronautical engineer at Fairchild Republic. His loving and cherished wife of 57 years, Norma, passed on in September, 1999. Cherished father of Sandra Barmak, Lorraine Glaser and Shelley Gross. Loved father-in-law of Len Barmak, Gary Glaser and Michael Gross. Loving and adoring grandfather (''Pop'') of Allan and Julie Barmak and Lesley and Michael Reilly, Samantha and Evan Glaser, and Jeffrey and Amy Gross; loving and adoring great-grandfather of Taylor Barmak. Services on Thursday, July 6, 12 noon at Guttermans Memorial Chapel, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury. Donations may be sent to the Alzheimers Association or to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Center. He will be greatly missed.

headline1: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, SAM
headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, SAM
lead_paragraph: SCHWARTZ-Sam passed away at Mt. Sinai Hospital in New York City on August 30, 2000 after a prolonged illness. Loving father of Sheila Paulos and grandfather to Leah Paulos and Daniel Paulos, father-in-law of John Allen Paulos. Beloved companion of Marsha Engelsher. Jean Gibenstein his wife of 56 years died of Alzheimer's Disease in 1997. Born in New York City in 1917, Mr. Schwartz was founder and president of Metropolitan Window Washing Company in White Plains, NY. He lived life passionately with great love for his family and friends. He will be missed by all who knew and loved him. Services will be held at Louis Hirsch and Sons, Inc., 1225 Jerome Avenue, Bronx, New York on Thursday, August 31st at 1:30 P.M. Interment is at Cedar Park, Paramus, New Jersey.

headline1: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAGNALL, JUNE
headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAGNALL, JUNE
lead_paragraph: BAGNALL-June. Died November 28, 2000 at age 74. Ms. Bagnall was the daughter of the late Jeanette and Richard Bagnall. She is survived by her nephew Rodney Stewart, his wife Anita, son Jonathan and her many friends and neighbors. Ms. Bagnall was a New York City art teacher for over 30 years. She received her MFA from Columbia University. We remember her for her many good works including working with Alzheimers patients, the 23rd Precinct Community Council and St. Ambrose Church. There will be a viewing on Friday, December 1, 910AM with a service following at St. Ambrose Church, 9 W. 130 St, NYC. The family has asked that in lieu of flowers, donations be given to the National Kidney Foundation of NY/NJ, 1250 Broadway, Suite 2001, New York, New York 10001.

headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  MINDNICH, JOHN DAVID

headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  KISTER, FRANK F.

Byrne Jr. and their spouses, Stephen E. Fischer and Mary F. Byrne. Dear brother of his late sisters Bernice K. Devin and Maryon K. Byrne. headline1: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARSON, NELSON
headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARSON, NELSON
lead_paragraph: KARSON-Nelson. Of Great Neck died on April 16, 2000. He was 79 years old and died at North Shore University Hospital of complications following a stroke. Mr. Karson was a retired electrical engineer. He moved to Great Neck in 1957 and resided there until his death. He was married to the late Janet Rothschild Karson, who died in 1995. Mr. Karson is survived by a son, Scott and his wife Joleen of Stony Brook; a daughter, Shelley and her partner Harriet Mendlowitz of Jackson Heights; a granddaughter, Tobi Karson Sevdalakis and her husband Christos; a grandson Jared Karson; and a sister Annette Karson. A memorial service for Mr. Karson was held at the Ethical Humanist Society of Long Island in Garden City on April 22, 2000. Donations may be made to the Alzheimer's Association, 66 South St., Patchogue, NY 11772 or to Planned Parenthood Hudson Peconic, 70 Maple Ave., Smithtown, New York 11787.

headline1: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALPRIN, MAXINE (NEE RICKARD)
headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALPRIN, MAXINE (NEE RICKARD)
lead_paragraph: HALPRIN-Maxine (nee Rickard), age 72, of Hoboken, NJ, formerly of Juno Beach and Miami, San Antonio and New York City, died May 27, 2000. Daughter of the late George ''Tex'' Rickard, the boxing promoter and founder of the New York Rangers Hockey Club, who built the Madison Square Garden building that stood at Eighth Ave. and 50th St. in NYC. Devoted mother of Edwin Rickard Goodfellow of San Antonio, TX, Joan Christine Halprin of Beaufort, SC and Joseph Rickard Halprin of Hoboken, NJ. Her smile, friendship and love will be missed by all. Visitation on Tuesday from 7-9PM at Lawton-Turso Funeral Home, 631 Washington St., Hoboken. Funeral Wednesday. Mass 10AM at Sts. Peter and Paul R.C. Church, 4th and Hudson Sts. Interment Woodlawn Cemetery, Bronx, NY. Contributions to Alzheimer's Association or American Heart Association greatly appreciated.

headline1: Paid Notice: Deaths  JENNINGS, FRED M.
headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  JENNINGS, FRED M.
lead_paragraph: JENNINGS-Fred M. Of Hobe Sound, FL, and Sandwich, NH, formerly of New Canaan, CT, on November 4, 2000, in Augusta, ME. He received his BA degree at San Diego State College and law degree at the University of Chicago. Fred served in the Pacific during WWII as an officer on the USS Guardfish, the only submarine to be awarded the Presidential Unit Citation for Valor twice. He worked in New York City in the legal profession at Milbank Tweed law firm and as House Counsel at Riegel Paper Corp. and VP at Great Lakes Paper Company in White Plains, NY. He started an American style feedlot in Australia in 1974. He is survived by his beloved wife, Peggy, his son, Douglas of Hallowell, ME, daughter, Nanci Ouellette of Lansing, MI, and two grandchildren, Amy and Douglas Jennings. Services will be for the family in Hallowell, ME. Memorial contributions to the Alzheimers Association, Chicago, IL.

headline1: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOPPENFELD RESIKA, ELSA
headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOPPENFELD RESIKA, ELSA
lead_paragraph: HOPPENFELD RESIKA - Elsa. March 2, 2000. Adored mother of Carol and husband Howard Hillman, loving grandmother to Molly Mehlsack, beloved aunt of Barbara Mehlsack, Herbert and Jeannette Spiegel, Beaty Evin, Lili Spiegel, Sol Spiegel, Shirley Sklar, Diana Katz, and many loving Hoppenfeld nieces and nephews, and Finn and Barbara Caspersen, Finn Michael and Emily, Eric and Anna, Sam, and Andrew Caspersen, and Nancy Manheim. She loved humanity and worked for social justice all of her life. Her family and friends were the most important thing in the world to her. She showed us her love and support in every waking moment. We will miss her, but we will carry on her legacy. Service Sunday, March 5, 3PM at The Riverside, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Alzheimer's Disease and Related Disorders Association, Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cencer Center or the Guttman Institute.

headline1: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURPHY, EDMOND C.
headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURPHY, EDMOND C.
lead_paragraph: MURPHY-Edmond C. Age 79, of Baldwin, NY, died Friday, January 7. Beloved husband of the late Blanche Murphy and devoted father of three children and seven grandchildren. Dear brother of Patricia and Richard. Distinguished career as Chief Clerk of Family Court for City of New York. Highly respected college basketball official and former President of the American Association of Basketball Officials. An avid golfer, he will be remembered for sharp wit, compassion for others and devotion to his family. Friends may visit at Vanella's Funeral Chapel, 2860 Long Beach Rd., Oceanside, NY, on Sunday, January 9, 2-5 PM, and 7-9 PM. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held on Monday, January 10, at St. Christopher's, Merrick Rd, Baldwin, NY, at 10:30 AM. Interment at St. Charles Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Alzheimer's Association, 919 North Michigan Ave., Suite 1000, Chicago, IL 60611-1676.

headline1: Paid Notice: Deaths  YOUNG, LUCILE HALLE
headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  YOUNG, LUCILE HALLE
lead_paragraph: YOUNG-Lucile Halle. A native of Cleveland, Ohio; died at the age of 89 on September 1, 2000 after a long illness. She attended Miss Fuller's School in Ossining, NY. She was married to the late Fritz Wolff and the late Lewis B. Young of Drexel, Burnham, Lambert & Co. She began her career in the children's wear department at Jane Engels. Afterwards she started the Infant and Children's Department at Henri Bendel. Lucile was recognized as one of the industry's leading buyers of fine children's clothes until she retired in 1962. She is survived by her daughter Susan W. Spiegel and her husband Andrew of Highland Park, Illinois; and stepdaughter Linda Barnes. Adored grandmother of Sally Spiegel and Jill Spiegel Brozic and her husband Joe of Minneapolis. Stepgrandmother of Andrew and Kimberly and her husband Al and great-stepgrandmother of David Alexander. Friends will be received at 1075 Park Avenue from 6-9PM on Thursday September 14. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Alzheimers Foundation.

headline1: Paid Notice: Deaths  BADER, NATHAN
headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  BADER, NATHAN

Loving grandfather of Richard, Larry and Tracy and great grandfather of Alixandre, Zachary and Sophia. Graveside service at Mt. Hebron Cemetery, Sunday, May 14, 2:00 PM. headline1: Paid Notice: Deaths  LORBER, RUTH
headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  LORBER, RUTH
lead_paragraph: LORBER-Ruth, 83. Of Lake Worth FL, passed away on December 19, 2000. Mrs. Lorber and her husband Jerry owned and directed Camp Ranger for over 30 years. She was a Life Member of Hadassah, an Officer of the Sisterhood at the Israel Center of Hillcrest Manor and an active fundraiser for the Friends of the Retarded. She leaves to cherish her memory, a devoted family: loving husband of 62 years, Dr. Jerome W. Lorber; beloved children Susan and Matthew Liebman and Sandy and Sheldon Cohen; loving brothers and sister Irving, Charlotte and Harold. A very special Grandma to Eileen and Lowell, Alan and Sandi, David and Alison, and Debbie. Great-grandmother to Kyle and Jake, and many nieces and nephews. She will be greatly missed by her family and many dear friends who knew and loved her. Expressions of sympathy may be made in Ruth Lorber's memory to the Alzheimers Association. Shiva will be held on Monday evening at 8 PM and all day and evening on Tuesday at the home of Susan Liebman, 101-06 67th Drive, Apartment 5A in Forest Hills.

headline1: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURGHEIMER, ALAN JOSEPH
headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURGHEIMER, ALAN JOSEPH
lead_paragraph: BURGHEIMER-Alan Joseph. A Rye resident, died on November 24, 2000, at his home, at age 87. Born in NYC on July 16, 1913, he is the son of the late Jacob and Gertrude Kahn Burgheimer. A veteran of the United States Navy, he served the nation during WWII. Mr. Burgheimer was the owner and executive of the Fisher Beer Co. in NYC. On June 20, 1939, he married Jeanne Schwarz at the Waldorf Astoria. He was a member of the City Athletic Club in Manhattan, as well as the Beach Point Club in Mamaroneck. In addition to his wife Jeanne, of Rye, he is survived by his daughters Margo Burgheimer of Rye, and Joanne Robinson and her husband Jerrold of Keswick, VA. He is predeceased by a sister, Sylvia Kapp. Funeral service will be held on Monday, 11:30 AM, at Zion Memorial, followed by entombment at Maimonides Cemetery in Elmont, NY. The family requests that donations be sent to the Alzheimer's Association in his memory. For information contact Zion Memorial Chapel, 785 East Boston Post Road, Mamaroneck, NY 10543; 914-381-1809. www.zionmemorialchapel.com

headline1: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALLEE, SUZANNE D.
headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALLEE, SUZANNE D.
lead_paragraph: SALLEE-Suzanne D. 92 years old, Lake Worth, FL died Monday, September 25 at her residence. Born in New York City, former resident of Cold Spring Harbor, NY graduated from Rosemary Hall, and attended Bennett Jr. College where she later served on the Board of Trustees. Mrs. Sallee and her husband, George, retired to Key Biscayne, FL in 1967. He died in 1985 shortly after their 50th wedding anniversary. Mrs. Sallee moved to West Palm Beach, FL in 1989. She is survived by her son, John C. Sallee of Manila, the Phillippines; her daughter, Mrs. Clifford Slater of Pacific Palisades, CA; and her five grandchildren. A memorial service will be held on Tuesday, October 3, at the Episcopal Church of Bethesda-by-the Sea, Palm Beach, FL. Graveside service Thursday at the Memorial Cemetery of St. John's Church in Cold Spring Harbor. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in her memory to the Alzheimer's Association, Greater Palm Beach Area Chapter, Inc., 1325 S. Congress Ave., Suite 203, Boynton Beach, FL 33426.

headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAUSER, LEVIN, LILLIAN
lead_paragraph: HAUSER-LEVIN-Lillian. 92, of Great Neck, NY. Died peacefully at home on March 25, 2000. She was predeceased by her first husband, the late Milton I. Hauser, and by her second husband, the late Jess Levin. She is survived by her children Harry and Deborah Hauser of Newton, MA, and Richard and Joan Hauser of Northport, NY, and by her grandchildren: Mark and Andrea Hauser of Newton, MA, and their sons Jeffrey and George; Joshua and Kimberly Hauser of Vancouver, BC, and their sons Zachary and Jacob; Bradford and Nurit Hauser of Jerusalem, Israel, and their children Daniel, Yohanatan, Tuvya and Rachel; Matthew Hauser and Susan Motamed of Brooklyn, NY, and their sons Benjamin and Alexander; Jonathan and Quinella Hauser of Jonesboro, GA, and their son Jonathan II; Betsy and Douglas Abernathy of Naperville, IL, and their daughters Celia, Rose and Jane; and by Andrew Hauser of San Diego, CA. headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  ENGEL, JOSEPH G.
lead_paragraph: ENGEL-Joseph G. Of Princeton, New Jersey. Died peacefully on May 7, 2000 at age 83 after a long illness. Survived by his wife of 52 years, Jane D. Engel of Princeton, NJ. Engel, his five grandchildren, John, Robert, Bill, Betsy, and Libby, his brother Edward G. Engel and his sister, Mary E. Flannery. Funeral services and interment private. headline1: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSTON, ROBERT EMMETT
headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSTON, ROBERT EMMETT
lead_paragraph: JOHNSTON-Robert Emmett, 83, died 1-15-00 in Florida after a long illness. Mr. Johnston, formerly of New York, was retired president and chief executive officer of Harbor Distributing Corp. in Hicksville. Harbor distributed Anheuser Busch beers. Previously, he was president of Port Distributing Corp. of Long Island City. Mr. Johnston served in the Army in Europe with the 3rd Infantry Division from 1944 through January 1946. He was graduate of Pace University. In 1981 he was honored by the National Multiple Sclerosis Society, and in 1983 by the New York Kidney Foundation. He was predeceased by his wife, Patricia, (nee McCabe), in 1995. He is survived by three daughters, Patricia O'Hearne of New Hampshire, Stefanie Gugelot and Mary Morrell of Florida; five grandchildren, Brian O'Hearne, Mary O'Hearne, Jennifer Shepard, Deirdre Gugelot, and Caitlin Morrell; five great-grandchildren; devoted friends, Felicita Gimenez and Gus Camarasa; and many nieces and nephews. Visitation at the Branch Funeral Home Inc., 190 E. Main St., Smithtown will be on Wednesday from 3-5 and 79pm. In lieu of flowers please send contributions to the Alzheimer's Association of Massachusetts, 36 Cameron Ave., Cambridge, MA 02140

headline1: PHARMACEUTICALS ACQUISITION
headline2: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: EUROPE; PHARMACEUTICALS ACQUISITION
snippet: Elan Corp acquires Dura Pharmaceuticals Inc for $1.8 billion in stock; graph (S)
lead_paragraph: The Dublinbased drugmaker the Elan Corporation acquired Dura Pharmaceuticals, Inc. of San Diego, for $1.8 billion in stock, paying 0.6715 of an Elan A.D.R. for each Dura share. The purchase, Elan's third acquisition this year, raises its North American sales force to more than 1,000. Dura's antibiotics and its Spiros brand of inhaler had sales of $301 million in 1999. The products will broaden Elan's offerings, which are now focused on painkillers and treatments for breast cancer and Alzheimer's disease. Brian Lavery

headline1: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENE, WALLACE B.
headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENE, WALLACE B.
lead_paragraph: GREENE-Wallace B.. Formerly of Newburgh, NY, died peacefully at age 88 on January 13 in Goshen, NY. After graduating from New York University in 1934, he founded the accounting firm of Robbins Greene and Sosnoff with offices in Newburgh and New York City (which firm subsequently merged into Citrin Cooperman and Company) and became active in the American Institute of CPAs and served as President of the MidHudson Chapter of the New York State Society of CPAs as well as Chairman of the Ethics Committee. Despite the demands of his accounting profession, he made a significant commitment to public service, serving as a member of the Board of Directors and as the President of St. Luke's Hospital in Newburgh, President of the Newburgh Lions Club and President of the Otterkill Country Club. He still managed to find time for his passion for photography, classical music and bass fishing in the St. Lawrence River. He is survived by his wife, Ruth, his son, Stephen, his daughter-in-law, Marilyn, his granddaughters, Lisa Mirsky and Jennifer Susser, and his greatgrandsons, Jack David Mirsky and Michael Drew Mirsky, all of whom he cherished and all of whom will miss him dearly. He was truly a class act. In lieu of flowers, donations in Wallace's name can be made to the Alzheimer's Association, New York Chapter, 360 Lexington Ave., NYC 10017.

headline1: Paid Notice: Deaths  GELMAN, MILTON
headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  GELMAN, MILTON
lead_paragraph: GELMAN-Milton. Age 90, of Lake Worth, FL, formerly of Brooklyn, NY, died Thursday after a brief illness. He leaves his loving family, his wife Sylvia (Garfield) of West Palm Beach, two daughters, Arlene Brod and her companion Barry Kay of Great Neck, NY, and Nancy Blecher Davis and her husband Franklin Davis of Brookline, MA, three grandchildren, Mark Blecher and wife Robin Skirboll of San Francisco, Mari Blecher and husband Rick Tetzeli of Brooklyn and Craig Blecher and wife Angela of Richmond, VA, and three great-grandchildren, Robert and Kerry Blecher and Jonah Tetzeli. Milton Gelman practiced law in New York for 40 years and was a significant leader in the Jewish community of Brooklyn. A former President of Progressive Synagogue, Mr. Gelman received numerous honors and awards and was recognized by the State of Israel for his work on behalf of Israel Bonds. He was looked to for advice by several generations of friends and relatives who were fortunate enough to know this truly giving man. A graveside service will take place 1 PM, Sunday, November 5 at Mt. Lebanon Cemetery, Queens, NY. Donations may be sent to the Alzheimers Association or charity of choice. For information, contact ''Gutterman's,'' Brooklyn, NY.

headline1: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORDON, LAWRENCE
headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORDON, LAWRENCE
lead_paragraph: GORDON-Lawrence. Born July 26, 1922, died September 8, 2000, of New York and Palm Beach, following a courageous battle with Alzheimer's and cancer. He was the devoted son of the late Harry and Etta Gordon and brother to Seymour. Lawrence is survived by his loving wife Janet and their children, Wendy, Scott, Peter and Petula, and from a previous marriage, daughter Kathy and grandson Eric. A decorated World War II veteran and a pioneer of industry, he was Chairman of the Board and CEO of Lehigh Valley Industries and Blue Ridge Winkler Textiles, among other Fortune 500 companies. Lawrence was a loving, charismatic, brilliant, dynamic, creative and adventurous man, and a champion golfer. Our lives have been blessed by his honor, integrity and love. He was a loving husband, father, colleague and friend, and he will be deeply missed by all who have known him. As Lord Tennyson wrote: ''Love is the only gold.'' Services will be held at Temple Emanu-El, 5th Avenue at 65th Street, Monday, September 11, 5 PM. A celebration of his life will follow the service. Contributions can be made to: Foundation of Neurologic Diseases, 10 State Street, Newburyport, MA 01950, Attn: Dr. Selkoe or to the Jacob Perlow Hospice, Beth Israel Health Care System, First Avenue at 16th St, NY, NY 10003-9973.

headline1: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACKIN, JOHN F.
headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACKIN, JOHN F.
lead_paragraph: MACKIN-John F. 85. Died on August 25, 2000. Formerly of Throgs Neck, Scarsdale and Long Beach Island, New Jersey. He was born on February 3, 1915 to John and Catherine (nee Smith) Mackin in NYC. John was a U.S. Army veteran during W.W.II. Mr. Mackin was a basketball official and baseball umpire at high school and college levels and a member of Catholic High School Athletic Association Hall of Fame. John worked for Metropolitan Life for 44 years, retiring in 1979. He is predeceased by his wife Edith (nee Connelly) Mackin in 1976, three sisters and one brother. He is survived by one son, Joseph Mackin of Hawthorne, NY; three daughters, Peg Adamo of Chappaqua, NY, Mary Grosso of Hingham, MA, Patricia Walsh of Wilton, CT; one brother, Peter Mackin of Yonkers, NY and twelve grandchildren. Reposing, Hawthorne Funeral Home, 21 Stevens Ave, Hawthorne, NY, (914) 769-4404, Sunday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass, Holy Rosary Church, Hawthorne, NY on Monday, 11:00 AM. Interment, Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations to Alzheimer's Association Westchester Chapter, 785 Mamaroneck Avenue, White Plains, NY 10605, would be appreciated.

headline1: Paid Notice: Deaths  HABER, RUTH
headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  HABER, RUTH
lead_paragraph: HABER-Ruth. Cherished wife of Ted. Devoted mother of Muriel and Bonnie. Adored grandmother of the late Robert Warren Haber Gilbert. Loving mother-in-law of Sven Mohr. Beloved sister of Eddie and Hilda, Sol and Gertie, Ray and Ursula Aronow. Loved cousin of Murray and Elsie, Milton and Frances Somerfield. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside Chapels,'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I., Wednesday, May 10, 12:30 PM. Donations: Long Island Alzheimer's Foundation, 5 Channel Drive, Port Washington, New York 11050.

headline1: Paid Notice: Deaths  BETTMANN, ROBERT E.
headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  BETTMANN, ROBERT E.
lead_paragraph: BETTMANN-Robert E. (Born December 22, 1922-December 24, 00) Bob, ''Mr B.'', a longtime resident of Hartsdale and Edgemont, New York. Devoted husband to Lynn. Loving father of Ellen Piontek of Holliston, MA, and Andy Poland of Milford, Connecticut. Graduate of Columbia Grammar School, attended University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill, until joining the army during W.W. II. Was a P.O.W. Worked in the textile business. Volunteered 1000's of hours to the Dad's Club, Boy Scouts, Kiwanas and others. Received numerous awards including Silver Beaver Award and President's Citation for volunteerism. Devoted cousin and friend to so many. Also leaves grandchildren Kelly, Mike, Kenny, Cliff, Tim and Todd. Will be deeply missed in his community and by all those whose life he has touched. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to The Bob Fund c/o Ellen Piontek, 170 Mellen Street, Holliston, MA. 01746. Or to the Alzheimer's foundation or American Cancer Society or The Connecticut Hospice, Bradford, Ct. Visiting hours at the Bennett Funeral Home, 824 Scarsdale Avenue, Scarsdale, NY, 914725-1137, Thursday December 28, 8:30AM-10:30AM. Service at Congregation Kol Ami, Chapel in the Woods, 252 Soundview Avenue, WP, NY, 914-949-4717, Thursday December 28, 12:00. Interment to follow at Mt. Pleasant Cemetery.

headline2: IN BUSINESS; High-Rise for Seniors Opens in Yonkers
snippet: Divison of Hyatt hotel company, in partnership with Forest City Daly developers, opens Classic Residence by Hyatt, new high-rise for seniors, in Yonkers, NY (S)
lead_paragraph: The first residents are moving into a new high-rise for seniors built in Yonkers by a division of the Hyatt hotel company in partnership with Forest City Daly developers. The 17-story building has 310 apartments, with mostly independent living units, a personal care section and an area for Alzheimer's sufferers.

headline1: Paid Notice: Deaths  POWERS, RUTH PEDERSEN
headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  POWERS, RUTH PEDERSEN
lead_paragraph: POWERS-Ruth Pedersen. Died July 25, 2000 in Saint Louis, MO. at the age of 93. She had a long, effective career as a social worker in Buffalo with the Family Service, and in New York City at Travelers' Aid & Community Service Society. Ms. Powers was born in Brooklyn and moved to Stroudsburg, PA. during her high school years. She graduated from Cornell University, with a B.A. and from the New York School of Social Work with a MSW. At Travelers' Aid, she was in charge of the Port Department in the years after WWII, assisting the displaced persons arriving at the New York docks. She then worked at Community Service Society where she managed the Homemaker Service Program that offered temporary support to help clients weather a variety of domestic crises. After her retirement from CSS, she lived an active, independent life in Morningside Gardens where she enjoyed serving as surrogate grandma to several foreign students. For the past three years, she suffered from Alzheimer's Disease, finally succumbing, reluctantly to its complications. She was briefly married to Wollerton Powers and had two daughters, Elizabeth Harris of New York & Susan Lagunoff of Saint Louis, MO. She has five grandchildren, Nick and Sam Jordan, and Rachel, Liza and Michael Lagunoff, and one great granddaughter Sasha Lagunoff Eberhardt. An older sister, Laura Henninger lives in Seattle. Memorial contributions may be made to Habitat for Humanity, 334 Furman Street, Brooklyn, New York 11201.

headline1: Paid Notice: Deaths  REA, ELIZABETH (BETTY)
headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  REA, ELIZABETH (BETTY)
lead_paragraph: REA-Elizabeth (Betty). Former Broadway actress, retired daytime TV casting director and social activist died December 23, 1999 of respiratory failure in Santa Monica, CA, she was 82. She was born Elizabeth Wilson in Montreal to Morris Wilson, President of the Royal Bank of Canada, Chanellor of McGill University and Clara Leone Wilson. In New York while appearing on Broadway in ''Media'' she met her future husband Oliver Rea who helped found The Gutherie Theater. Subsequently she worked as a talent agent for The Tranum Agency before landing the position of casting director of the soap opera ''Guiding Light''. Rea was the casting director for the Guiding Light from 1970-1996 and concurrently casting director for ''As The World Turns'' from 1979-1983. In 1997 Rea was recognized for her work and inducted into the Soap Opera Hall of Fame. She previously won the Soap Opera Digest Editors Award in 1994 and received the Casting Society of America's Hoyt Bowers Awared in 1995. Rea's many charitable contributions included service as President of the New York Junior League of which she is a lifetime member and on the boards of The Fountain House and The Maternity Center of New York. Rea is survived by two daughters, Edith Rea and Margaret Rea of Los Angeles and a son Peter Rea of Princeton, NJ and seven grandchildren. In lieu of flowers donations in Rea's name can be made to the Alzheimer's Association or to the Actors Fund. A memorial service will be held in New York on January 31st at 7 PM, at the Second Stage Theater, 307 West 43 Street.

headline1: Paid Notice: Deaths  PIZZURRO, MARGARET ELIZABETH HOLTKAMP
headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths  PIZZURRO, MARGARET ELIZABETH HOLTKAMP
lead_paragraph: PIZZURRO-Margaret Elizabeth Holtkamp, beloved wife of Joseph C. Pizzurro and mother of Joseph, Peter, Virginia, Mary (Esposito), Elizabeth (Ossoff) and Catherine (Hliboki) and grandmother of ten died September 30, 2000 following a short hospitalization. Her two sisters, Sr. Catherine Mary and Esther (Wenzel), and her brother Edward also survive her. Mrs. Pizzurro was born in Kalida, Ohio on December 21, 1924, the second daughter of Edward and Mary Holtkamp. Mrs. Pizzurro attended Mary Manse College of Toledo, Ohio and in 1946 was awarded a B.A. in Chemistry. She earned a M.S. degree from the University of Detroit in Biology in 1948, a notable achievement for a woman at that time. Mrs. Pizzurro is remembered by her friends and family as a woman of unfailing grace and kindness. She was extensively involved in church and charitable activities. She had a lifelong love of music, which she shared through the piano, her singing and work in amateur musicals. Her strength and inner beauty will be cherished by her family and all those whose lives she touched. She was an active parishioner at Our Lady of Perpetual Help in Ardsley for over forty years and most recently attended St. Augustine's parish in Ossining. Calling hours at The Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville between the hours of 7 to 9PM Monday 2 to 4 and 7 to 9PM Tuesday. Mass of Christian Burial St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville on Wednesday, Oct. 4 at 10AM. In lieu of flowers donations may be made in her name for Alzheimer's disease research to the Mayo Foundation, 200 First Street SW, Rochester, Minnesota 55905.
