lead_paragraph: CARING for an elderly parent is emotionally and mentally draining. There are diagnoses to decipher, housing issues to consider, health aides to vet and a raft of legal documents to complete. It can seem overwhelming, even when families are in complete agreement on how to care for an elderly relative. And often they are not.

headline2: The Alzheimer's Project

headline1: Safety: When to Ground Alzheimer’s Drivers?

lead_paragraph: Sooner or later, people who have Alzheimer’s disease will have to give up the keys to the car. But figuring out when poses a problem for doctors and families, because the loss of driving privileges also means less freedom and mobility.

headline1: HBO Puts Alzheimer’s Under the Microscope
headline2: HBO Puts Alzheimer’s Under the Microscope
snippet: A premium channel’s health campaign will be available for all cable subscribers.
lead_paragraph: HBO, the pay-cable home to blood-sucking 173-year-olds, polygamous Mormons and stressed-out, therapy-seeking C.E.O.’s, is not the usual place for explanations of amyloid plaques, computer-rendered brain-imaging scans or distressing tales of a woman told she can never drive again. But as it does every few years, HBO will soon intrude on its largely fiction-oriented lineup of series and second-run Hollywood movies to deliver five prime hours of a multimillion-dollar public service health campaign. Starting May 10, in its most far-reaching initiative yet, HBO tackles Alzheimer’s disease.

headline1: Knowing About Forgetting
snippet: With a family history of Alzheimer’s disease, even minor memory lapses can be terrifying.
lead_paragraph: This morning I couldn’t remember the street number of my house. My own house! Don’t panic, I thought, don’t struggle to remember it. Just go on with other things, and it’ll float to the surface. But it didn’t, so I opened the front door and read the street numbers aloud, trying to fix them in my brain.

headline1: Diane Keaton to Write Memoir
headline2: Diane Keaton To Write Memoir
lead_paragraph: Having played roles in the fictional lives of Alvy Singer and the Corleone clan, Diane Keaton, below, is about to shine a spotlight on her own family. Ms. Keaton, of “Annie Hall” and “The Godfather” fame, will write a memoir for Random House about herself and her mother’s 15-year battle with Alzheimer’s disease, the publisher said in a news release. Ms. Keaton’s mother, Dorothy Keaton Hall, kept some 90 notebooks during her life, chronicling the upbringing of her children and her frustrating marriage. Ms. Keaton read those journals back to her mother during her final years, and began writing her memoir soon after her mother’s death in 2008. The book, as yet untitled, is planned for publication in 2012. Financial terms of the deal were not announced.

headline1: Permanent Ellipses
headline2: Permanent Ellipses
snippet: This novel imagines life as faced by a man with Alzheimer’s.
lead_paragraph: No disease is more feared by more people than Alzheimer’s. It tops cancer and heart disease on the anxiety scale, even though both are more prevalent. This may be because Alzheimer’s is primarily a disease of old age, and we are an aging nation. With 10 million baby boomers expected to develop Alz­heimer’s in their lifetimes, with one new case every minute or so, the numbers are wickedly inclusive. But it cuts deeper. We all have an inkling of what it might be like to have this disease because we know what it’s like to forget a name or lose a word, and the mind, envisioning its own demise, is quick to parlay those lapses into something bigger: a permanent ellipse where words had been or a string of unremembered faces that eventually come to include the face we see in the mirror.

headline1: Mediterranean Diet May Prevent Mental Decline

headline1: A New Understanding of Glaucoma
headline2: A New Understanding of Glaucoma
snippet: Glaucoma isn't simply an eye disease, experts now say, but rather a degenerative nerve disorder not unlike Alzheimer's or Parkinson's disease.
lead_paragraph: For years, glaucoma was defined as elevated pressure within the eye that leads to vision loss. And for years experts knew there were glaring gaps in that definition. Many people with abnormally high intraocular pressure never develop glaucoma. As many as one in three people who do get the disease have normal or even low pressure.

headline1: Who’s Competent?
headline2: The Tricky Question of Competence
snippet: The verdict in the Astor trial may turn on the question of Brooke Astor's competence on the day she revised her will. But experts note that many Alzheimer's patients are intermittently lucid, and legal competence can be hard to ascertain.
lead_paragraph: Socialite Brooke Astor was losing ground cognitively, a procession of friends testified last week in a Manhattan courtroom. She no longer recognized people she'd been close to for decades. She wandered. Hosting a dinner party for the former secretary general of the United Nations, she had to ask another guest - Henry Kissinger, as it happened - who "that man" Kofi Annan was. She was unable to draw a clock face accurately, according to the geriatrician who diagnosed her Alzheimer's disease.

headline1: Living in the Moment
headline2: Living in the Moment
snippet: A daughter turns to her study of yoga to help her understand her mother's Alzheimer's disease.
lead_paragraph: My sister and I had inklings of a slow atrophying of my mother's mind, perhaps of her very self, before she was diagnosed with Alzheimer's disease in April, 2008. And yet, strangely, I'd also noticed around that time she'd seemed to be more "herself." So I felt oddly reassured at the news. The diagnosis seemed to explain something about who my mother was, perhaps who she'd been most of my life. Due to its seeming genetic component, we believed the type to be early-onset. It could have started when I was still a kid.

headline1: Change in Medicaid Rules May Pose Stark Choice for the Chronically Ill
headline2: Change in Rules May Pose Stark Choice for the Chronically Ill
snippet: The federal government ruled that New York cannot grant couples the same income protections when the sick spouse receives at-home care instead of a nursing home.
lead_paragraph: For 20 years, federal law has protected married couples from having to choose between divorcing or becoming impoverished when one spouse needs expensive nursing home care, allowing the healthier spouse to retain assets and income while the sicker one’s care is covered by Medicaid.

headline2: The perils and joys of self-esteem

headline1: Children at the Nursing Home
headline2: Little Feet Among the Walkers
snippet: When should I bring my children to the nursing home to visit their grandfather? And when should I stop?.
lead_paragraph: My father-in-law had been in a nursing home for several weeks when my husband and I decided to bring our daughters, ages 3 and 5, for a visit. Our kids knew that their grandfather, who suffers from Alzheimer's disease, osteoporosis and severe arthritis, had been ill for a long time, just as they knew that recently he had needed more help than their grandmother could provide at home.

headline1: Brooke Astor’s Lasting Legacy
snippet: The Astor trial, expected to conclude soon, heightened awareness of elder abuse, a problem that will only continue to grow.
lead_paragraph: Remember the Astor trial? The ongoing case raised questions about whether noted philanthropist Brooke Astor, diagnosed with Alzheimer’s disease, understood what she was doing when she changed her will in 2004, diverting millions that had long been promised to charities to her son, Anthony Marshall. Allegations also arose that her son and a co-defendant — charged with conspiracy, fraud, larceny and forgery — manipulated a confused centenarian into parting with her treasured $10 million painting.

headline1: The Familiar Place
headline2: The Familiar Place
snippet: Familiarity seems inherent, but it’s really an artifact of consciousness.
lead_paragraph: Recently, I’ve been thinking about the geography of familiarity. By that I mean something like a map of my habitat, the paths I travel most often, the places I feel most comfortable, the routines embedded in the rural and urban landscapes I know best. Most days, familiarity seems inherent in the world right around me, but every now and then I remember that it’s really an artifact of consciousness, a form of perception that can be lost, say, in someone with Alzheimer’s. It’s disorienting to grasp that the world itself is neutral and that all the familiarity and unfamiliarity I feel is being carried around in my head.

headline1: Confusion About Mediterranean Cuisine
headline2: Confusion About Mediterranean Cuisine
snippet: What can countries that created lasagna and steak frites tell us about healthful eating?.
lead_paragraph: What is a Mediterranean diet anyway? This week researchers reported on a link between Mediterranean-style eating and better brain health. But every time a new report emerges on the health benefits of Mediterranean eating, many consumers are left scratching their heads. How could countries that gave us pizza, lasagna, steak frites and lamb souvlaki teach us anything about healthful eating?  Here are answers to some common questions about Mediterranean eating and health.  What foods are included in the typical Mediterranean diet?  Mediterranean eating is focused on simple cooking and includes all the foods you already eat, just in different proportions. The diet is plant-based in nature, with a heavy emphasis on fruits and vegetables, nuts, grains, seeds, beans and olive oil. Eggs, dairy, poultry and fish are consumed regularly, but the portions are smaller than typically consumed in a Western diet. Meat makes only an occasional appearance, and it's usually added in small amounts to make sauces, beans and pasta dishes more flavorful. Refined sugar and flour and butter and fats other than olive oil are consumed rarely, if at all. Mediterranean eating also typically includes moderate consumption of red wine. One of the key components of Mediterranean eating has to do with the elevation of the meal as a social event. Meals are consumed at leisure with family and friends.   "One of the basic tenets is the enjoyment of food, and respect and pleasure of food,'' says Nicki Heverling, program manager for the Mediterranean Foods Alliance, part of Oldways, the nonprofit food issues think tank that has promoted Mediterranean eating for nearly two decades. "When you're in the Mediterranean, your meals are three hours and you savor your food.''  Why do so many of my recipes for French, Italian and Greek foods have loads of cheese and meat in them?  The Mediterranean eating plan is based on foods that have traditionally been consumed by communities situated along the Mediterranean sea. Many of the recipes we typically associate with Mediterranean countries don't come from coastal communities, but from regions farther to the north. Today's Mediterranean diet pyramid is largely based on the dietary traditions of the Greek island of Crete and southern Italy around the 1960s, when rates of chronic disease were among the lowest in the world, and adult life expectancy was among the highest. Unfortunately, many of the communities where the diet was first studied have changed dramatically, a concern chronicled in the recent Times story "Fast Food Hits Mediterranean; a Diet Succumbs.''   How do we know Mediterranean eating is good for you?  The original work that sparked scientific interest in Mediterranean eating habits came from researcher Ancel Keyes at the University of Minnesota. His landmark seven countries study focused on the link between eating habits along the Mediterranean and better health, despite inferior medical care in the region. Research on the diet took off in the 1990s, as scientists noted that people in Mediterranean countries lived longer and had low rates of serious disease despite high rates of smoking and drinking. Last year, the British medical journal BMJ published an extensive review of Mediterranean diet studies. It found that the eating plan is associated with significant health benefits, including lower rates of heart disease, cancer, Parkinson's disease and Alzheimer's. More recently, researchers found a link between Mediterranean eating and diabetes risk as well as lower blood pressure. The Oldways Web site offers a lengthy list of studies of Mediterranean eating and health.  Do I really have to eat meat only once a month?  While the traditional diet included meat only about once a month or on special occasions, most health experts say adhering to Mediterranean eating doesn't have to mean giving up meat. It just means consuming smaller portions less often. If you are packing your diet with produce, nuts, legumes and whole grains, you won't have a lot of room left on your plate for big servings of meat anyway. "What we try to convey to people is don't cut anything out of your diet you enjoy,'' says Ms. Heverling of Oldways. "Make smaller portions and when you have it, really enjoy it. In the traditional diet, someone wasn't eating a 12-ounce Porterhouse steak. They ate small bits of meat in a sauce. It was there to get flavor and taste from. Meat is delicious and they knew that.''  How can I learn more about Mediterranean eating?  The Web is filled with resources. Click on the links above, or visit the Oldways Web site to get started. The Mayo Clinic also offers a useful summary of the eating plan. About 150 products are labeled with the Med Mark from the Mediterranean Foods Alliance. And "The New Mediterranean Diet Cookbook: A Delicious Alternative for Lifelong Health" received a starred review from Publisher's Weekly and includes a foreword by New York University nutritionist Marion Nestle.  Finally, the Mediterranean diet has its own food pyramid. A version can be found on the Oldways site, or below you can find one created by the Greek Health Ministry to explain the diet. They pyramids have some differences but both support the idea that a Mediterranean diet is largely based on plant foods and whole grains.  (Photo: The Mediterranean Diet (The New York Times))

headline1: In Push to Detect Early Alzheimer’s Markers, Hopes for Prevention
headline2:
In Alzheimer’s Research,
Hope for Prevention
snippet: Groups that have proposed new diagnostic guidelines seek to counter criticism that drug companies will be the main beneficiaries.
lead_paragraph: Will Alzheimer’s disease, a terrible degenerative brain disease with no treatments and no clear guidelines for diagnosis before its end stages, become like heart disease? That might mean early markers of risk, analogous to high cholesterol levels, that predict who is likely to get it. And it might mean drugs that actually prevent it.

headline1: Taking an Alternative Path in Fighting the Disease
headline2: Taking an Alternative Path in Fighting the Disease
snippet: While most Alzheimer’s research focuses on blocking amyloid and plaque, other scientists are concentrating on another protein, tau.
lead_paragraph: Ideas about how to treat Alzheimer’s fall into two main categories. The main one pins its hopes on blocking amyloid beta peptides that form areas of plaque on the brain. But there is also another protein, tau, that is part of the disease. Tau is damaged when patients have Alzheimer’s, chemically modified so it wrecks structures inside cells that are used to transport chemicals.

headline1: Lilly Halts Alzheimer’s Drug Trial
snippet: The drug maker stops another late-stage clinical trial, representing yet another failure in efforts to treat the disease.
lead_paragraph: In yet another setback in efforts to treat Alzheimer’s disease, Eli Lilly & Company announced on Tuesday that it had halted development of an experimental treatment after the compound actually made patients worse in two late-stage clinical trials.

headline1: Infection Defense May Spur Alzheimer’s
headline2: Infection Defense May Spur Alzheimer’s
snippet: Beta amyloid, which was once thought to be a chief villain in Alzheimer’s, may be part of the brain’s normal defenses, researchers at Harvard suggested.
lead_paragraph: For years, a prevailing theory has been that one of the chief villains in Alzheimer’s disease has no real function other than as a waste product that the brain never properly disposed of.

headline1: Who Benefits From Early Diagnosis of Alzheimer’s?
snippet: Should patients be given an early diagnosis of Alzheimer’s if there’s nothing they can do about it? And why are the diagnostic guidelines changing, anyway?
lead_paragraph: In July, medical experts proposed a major change in the criteria for Alzheimer’s disease, part of a new movement to diagnose and, eventually, treat the disease earlier. The new diagnostic guidelines would mean that new technology like brain scans would be used to detect the disease even before there are evident memory problems or other symptoms.

headline1: A Scientific Shift Yields New Insights Into Alzheimer’s
snippet: New cooperation among Alzheimer’s researchers is beginning to pay off.
lead_paragraph: The Times reports this morning that a shift in research strategy among scientists is beginning to yield insights into how Alzheimer’s disease begins. The key to the Alzheimer’s project was an agreement as ambitious as its goal: not just to raise money, not just to do research on a vast scale, but also to share all the data, making every single finding public immediately, available to anyone with a computer anywhere in the world.

lead_paragraph: Chess can be diverting, amusing, engrossing, perplexing, exasperating, infuriating, and a few other things. But is it good for your mental health?

headline1: Ayckbourn and Seldes Are Early Tony Winners
headline2: Ayckbourn And Seldes Are Early Tony Winners
lead_paragraph: The Tony Awards Administration Committee announced on Thursday that the playwright and director Alan Ayckbourn and the Tony Award-winning actress Marian Seldes had been chosen to receive Lifetime Achievement Awards. Mr. Ayckbourn, who has written more than 70 plays, is probably best known for the “The Norman Conquests,” which won the Tony Award for best revival of a play in 2009. Ms. Seldes, who made her Broadway debut in “Medea” in 1947, won as featured actress for “A Delicate Balance” in 1967. Another familiar face on Broadway, David Hyde Pierce, above, is being given the Isabelle Stevenson Award, which recognizes charitable and humanitarian work. He is being honored for his contributions toward finding a cure for Alzheimer’s disease.

headline1: Breakthrough Award for New Novelist
snippet: James P. King has won the Amazon award.
lead_paragraph: With the publication this week of his first novel, “Bill Warrington’s Last Chance,” James P. King, 55, is living the dream of every hopeful writer who persists at his work despite rejection slips from publishing houses and agents. After Mr. King, who lives in Wilton, Conn., won the Amazon Breakthrough Novel Award, in which more than 6,500 writers from 22 countries competed, his novel, a road story in which an elderly veteran who is developing Alzheimer’s disease travels across the country with his rebellious 14-year-old granddaughter, was acquired by Viking. “This is what reading is about, and what a good book is supposed to do,” the mystery writer Sue Grafton writes in a blurb for the novel, Mr. King’s fourth attempt at fiction.

headline1: When Youth Is a Job Qualification
headline2: When Youth Is a Job Qualification

lead_paragraph: Steven M. Volpe, 21, who graduated in June from the College of Staten Island, parlayed an unpaid spring internship at the New York City chapter of the Alzheimer’s Association into a paid summer internship. In August he was offered a job as a social media associate. He lives with his parents in Dongan Hills on Staten Island and moonlights Saturday nights selling business machines at a local Staples.

headline1: LaBute and Weller in MCC’s New Season
headline2: Labute And Weller In MCC’s New Season
snippet: Premieres of new plays by Neil LaBute, Michael Weller and Sharr White (“Six Years”) will make up the 2010-11 season of MCC Theater.
lead_paragraph: Premieres of new plays by Neil LaBute, Michael Weller and Sharr White (“Six Years”) will make up the 2010-11 season of MCC Theater, that Off Broadway theater company said. According to a preview of MCC’s season, which will run at the Lucille Lortel Theater, Mr. LaBute’s new play, “The Break of Noon,” about a spiritual awakening after an office shooting, will be directed by his frequent collaborator Jo Bonney. The show will be a co-production with the Geffen Playhouse in Los Angeles. Mr. White will make his New York debut with “The Other Place,” about a strong-headed Alzheimer’s researcher whose private life takes a scary turn. Mr. Weller’s new play, “Side Effects,” is a sequel of sorts to his last MCC show, “Fifty Words,” which turned in part on the revelation of an extramarital affair.

headline1: Theater News
headline2: Theater News
snippet: Amanda Peet will join David Duchovny in MCC Theater’s production of Neil LaBute’s “Break of Noon.”
lead_paragraph: Amanda Peet will join David Duchovny in MCC Theater’s production of Neil LaBute’s “Break of Noon,” the theater announced on Monday. Mr. Duchovny was previously slated to play a man who sees the face of God during an office shooting; Ms. Peet will do double duty playing that man’s wife, Ginger, and Ginger’s cousin, Jesse. The play, to be directed by Jo Bonney, will begin previews at the Lucille Lortel Theater on Oct. 28 and open on Nov. 15; its limited run is scheduled through Dec. 12. MCC Theater’s second production of the 2010-11 season will pair Laurie Metcalf (“Roseanne,” “Brighton Beach Memoirs”) with her “November” director, Joe Mantello for the world premiere of Sharr White’s “Other Place.” In this thriller, Ms. Metcalf will play a woman who finds herself at the center of a mystery just as she hits upon a potential breakthrough in the treatment of Alzheimer’s disease. It is to begin at the Lortel on March 10 and open on March 28, with a limited run through April 24. ... Mos Def, Jeffrey Wright and Paul Dano are among the cast members in Lincoln Center Theater’s coming production of John Guare’s play “A Free Man of Color,” the theater announced on Monday. Mr. Guare’s drama, set in New Orleans in the early 19th century, will be directed by George C. Wolfe. Previews begin on Oct. 21, with opening night set for Nov. 18 at the Vivian Beaumont Theater.

Charlie, who is immensely likable, has Alzheimer’s disease, the central fact of “Pop.”

headline1: She Remembered, He Remembered
headline2: She Remembered, He Remembered
snippet: In this first novel, a widowed research scientist tries to solve the puzzle of his marriage.
lead_paragraph: In fiction as in life, you can’t save people from themselves. Although that never keeps anyone from trying, as Rosecrans Baldwin’s amiable first novel demonstrates. Dr. Victor Aaron is 58 years old, a research scientist specializing in Alzheimer’s disease at a small (but well endowed) college on Mount Desert Island in Maine. Almost three years earlier, he lost his wife, Sara, in a car accident. They had no children. Everyone around Victor is concerned about him, and with good reason. His response to Sara’s death is not so much stoic as anesthetized. He goes about his routines of healthy breakfast, swimming, work and more work, seeming increasingly numb and remote. As another character puts it, “Your wife had died and everyone knew but you.”

headline1: Parkinson’s Disease, 1858
headline2: Parkinson’s Disease, 1858
snippet: The disease was called “shaking palsy” before it took the name of James Parkinson.
lead_paragraph: Parkinson’s disease is second only to Alzheimer’s as the most common neurological illness in the United States, and its symptoms  rigidity, imbalance and uncontrollable shaking  are all too familiar. By the time James Parkinson formally described it in 1817, the illness had been known for centuries.

headline1: Franz Schurmann, Cold War Expert on China, Dies at 84
headline2: Franz Schurmann, 84, Expert on China
snippet: A professor at the University of California, Berkeley, for nearly four decades, he traveled the world and helped found the Pacific News Service.
lead_paragraph: Franz Schurmann, an expert on China during the cold war and a globe-trotting professor who helped found the Pacific News Service, a provider of news and commentary about Asia, died on Aug. 20 at his home in San Francisco. He was 84. The cause was complications of Parkinson’s and Alzheimer’s diseases, his wife, Sandy Close, said.

headline1: The Golden Years: Feisty, Fit and Flirty
headline2: The Golden Years: Feisty, Fit and Flirty
snippet: Beneath the titillating promos of “Sunset Daze,” there is a more reassuring portrait of adults who can still act like kids but are at peace with their twilight years.
lead_paragraph: It’s not true that there are no old people on television, but they mostly stand out in ads that veer between extremes. The elderly are either vernally lithe, active and amorous (Cialis) or feeble home-care patients dependent on emergency alert systems and Exelon, an Alzheimer’s patch, to stave off undignified and agonizing deaths.

headline1: Forgetting of Things Past: A Duet Off-Key
headline2: Forgetting Of Things Past: A Duet Off-Key
snippet: In “The Memory Show,” the young composer Zach Redler has written a score that follows the patterns of minds grasping, often in vain, for clarity, conviction and lost time.
lead_paragraph: PITTSFIELD, Mass. — “The Memory Show,” which recently opened at Barrington Stage Company here, is a musical in search of a melody. That is what it intends to be. In shaping a portrait of a mother with Alzheimer’s disease and the angry, impotent daughter who cares for her, the young composer Zach Redler has written a score that follows the patterns of minds grasping, often in vain, for clarity, conviction and lost time.

headline1: Disease Cause Is Pinpointed With Genome
headline2: Disease Cause Is Pinpointed With Genome
snippet: It now appears possible to sequence a patient’s genome at reasonable cost and with sufficient accuracy to be useful.
lead_paragraph: Two research teams have independently decoded the entire genome of patients to find the exact genetic cause of their diseases. The approach may offer a new start in the so far disappointing effort to identify the genetic roots of major killers like heart disease, diabetes and Alzheimer’s.

headline1: 18 Orgies Later, Chinese Swinger Gets Prison Bed
headline2: 18 Orgies Later, China Swinger Gets Prison Bed

lead_paragraph: BEIJING — In public, he was a twice-divorced computer science professor dedicated to his students and to caring for an elderly mother who suffers from Alzheimer’s disease.

headline1: Murky Path in Deciding on Care at the End
headline2: Murky Path In Deciding On Care At the End
snippet: Decisions about aggressive treatment at the end of life are far from clear-cut.
lead_paragraph: Aggressive treatment at the end of life  frantic CPR for a brain-dead accident victim, inserting a feeding tube in a dying Alzheimer’s patient  has become a staple of the health care debate. Critics argue that vast resources are squandered on care that is obviously futile.

headline2: A Squirt Of Insulin May Delay Alzheimer’s

headline2: When Lapses Are Not Just Signs of Aging

headline1: Unfamiliar Path Unfolds at Tennessee
headline2: Unfamiliar Path Unfolds At Tennessee

lead_paragraph: Mickie DeMoss had been away from the Tennessee women’s basketball program for seven years, working as a head coach and an assistant elsewhere, when she gave in to Pat Summitt’s entreaties to come back last year as an assistant. headline1: An Alzheimer’s Mystery Novel
headline2: Dismembered Memory
snippet: This haunting first novel’s deeply unreliable narrator is a former surgeon with Alzheimer’s and the prime suspect in her best friend’s murder.
lead_paragraph: Unreliable narrators come in many shapes. There are madmen, mystics, seducers, naïfs — Nabokov’s Humbert Humbert, the ghost-prone governess in “The Turn of the Screw” and Poe’s self-defeating paranoiac in “The Tell-Tale Heart,” for starters. And then there is Dr. Jennifer White, who narrates Alice LaPlante’s first novel. By the time “Turn of Mind” begins, she is losing her wits to Alzheimer’s disease and is the prime suspect in her best friend’s murder. She is as unreliable as they come.

headline1: Risks: Heart Risks May Hasten Mental Decline
headline2: Risks: Heart Risks May Hasten Mental Decline
snippet: A study showed that people who had diabetes or high blood pressure at the beginning of the study were more likely to have signs of brain deterioration and lower mental function 13 years later.
lead_paragraph: Cardiovascular risk factors in middle age are associated with brain deterioration and a decline in mental function later in life, a new report has found.

headline1: Slowly, Alzheimer’s Erases a Poet’s Gifts and Memories
snippet: Jack Agüeros, who directed El Museo del Barrio for almost a decade, has forgotten that he is the author of four books, a handful of plays, sonnets and satiric psalms about poverty and social inequality.
lead_paragraph: The memory of the New York poet Jack Agüeros is capricious nowadays. He remembers the lyrics of certain Puerto Rican folk songs and the name of his petite, growling dog: Nikki. He does not remember collecting the old radios, locks and cast-iron pieces that once decorated his bright Manhattan apartment on West 14th Street.

headline1: Screening for Alzheimer’s
snippet: Researchers on Tuesday reported progress toward the development of two tests to screen adults for Alzheimer’s disease.
lead_paragraph: Researchers have made further progress on two tests designed to detect Alzheimer’s disease, The Times reported on Tuesday. An advisory committee to the Food and Drug Administration this week will determine whether one of these tests, a brain scan, should be marketed for widespread use. The other screening tool, a blood test, is still in the earliest stages of development.

headline1: Resisting Alzheimer’s
snippet: A neurologist spends decades trying to dodge Alzheimer’s disease — and fails.
lead_paragraph: In Tuesday’s Science Times, the writer Nancy Stearns Bercaw describes her father’s decades-long preoccupation with preventing Alzheimer’s disease, which had killed her grandfather. Alzheimer’s was the reason her father became a neurologist in the first place, she writes: he “knew it was coming.”

headline1: Caring for the Patient With Alzheimer’s
snippet: What are the most important concerns about caregiving and the patient with Alzheimer’s disease?
lead_paragraph: In a recent New York Times article, “Giving Alzheimer’s Patients Their Way, Even Chocolate,” I looked at caregiving for people with Alzheimer’s disease and described how scientists and researchers are studying approaches to caregiving that appear to ease some of the most troubling symptoms, like wandering or agitated and aggressive behavior. Certain approaches to caregiving can make life more pleasant for patients, who, research suggests, continue to feel emotions like joy or sadness even if they have no memory of the experiences that caused those emotions. And they can, in turn, make things easier for caregivers, allowing people to care for relatives with Alzheimer’s at home and delay placing them in nursing homes.

headline1: Ask About Alzheimer’s Disease
snippet: New York Times science reporter Gina Kolata responds to reader questions about Alzheimer’s disease.
lead_paragraph: The two largest studies ever of Alzheimer’s disease have led to the discovery of five new genes that increase risk of the disease, Gina Kolata reports in today’s New York Times. There are now 10 genes that are known to increase the risk of Alzheimer’s in old age.

headline1: Alzheimer’s Test Clears a Hurdle
snippet: On Thursday, an advisory committee to the Food and Drug Administration recommended approval of a new dye that can reveal brain plaques characteristic of Alzheimer’s disease in living patients.
lead_paragraph: An advisory committee to the Food and Drug Administration recommended unanimously Thursday that the agency approve the first test able to diagnose Alzheimer’s disease in the brain of a living person, The Times reports this morning.

headline1: Maternal Link to Alzheimer’s Makes a Gain
headline2: PATTERNS: Maternal Link to Alzheimer’s Makes a Gain
snippet: A new study contributes to growing evidence that the chances of inheriting Alzheimer’s from your mother are higher than from your father.
lead_paragraph: Alzheimer’s disease is more common in people whose mothers had the illness than in those whose fathers had it  and the evidence can be found in the brains of people who are still healthy.

headline1: Inspired by Father, Nantz Takes Role in Alzheimer’s Research
headline2: Nantz Active in Alzheimer’s Research
snippet: The broadcaster, whose father had Alzheimer’s, announced the creation of a center in Houston that will research treatment and care for people with neurological diseases.
lead_paragraph: Jim Nantz had a master plan: his father would retire from his furniture business and join him on the road at N.F.L. games, golf tournaments and college basketball arenas. The elder Nantz, who was also named Jim, would help manage and organize his son’s busy life on the road.

headline1: Vast Gene Study Yields Insights on Alzheimer’s
headline2: Vast Gene Study Yields Insights On Alzheimer’s
snippet: The two largest studies of Alzheimer’s disease led to the discovery of five genes that provide intriguing new clues to why it strikes and how it progresses.
lead_paragraph: The two largest studies of Alzheimer’s disease have led to the discovery of no fewer than five genes that provide intriguing new clues to why the disease strikes and how it progresses.

headline1: F.D.A. Sees Promise in Alzheimer’s Imaging Drug
headline2: Alzheimer’s Test For Live Patients Clears a Hurdle
snippet: A committee voted that the agency approve the first test that can show Alzheimer’s in the brain of a living person.
lead_paragraph: An advisory committee to the Food and Drug Administration recommended unanimously Thursday that the agency approve the first test  a brain scan  that can show the characteristic plaques of Alzheimer’s disease in the brain of a living person. The approval was contingent on radiologists agreeing on what the scans say and doctors being trained in how to read the scans.

headline2: PATTERNS: Treating Vascular Ills May Curb Alzheimer’s

lead_paragraph: Older people suffering from mild memory and cognition problems may be less likely to progress to full-blown Alzheimer’s disease if they receive treatment for medical conditions like diabetes, high blood pressure and cholesterol, a new study has found.

headline1: The Bilingual Advantage
headline2: A Conversation With | Ellen Bialystok
snippet: Among other benefits, the regular use of two languages appears to delay the onset of Alzheimer’s disease symptoms.
lead_paragraph: A cognitive neuroscientist, Ellen Bialystok has spent almost 40 years learning about how bilingualism sharpens the mind. Her good news: Among other benefits, the regular use of two languages appears to delay the onset of Alzheimer’s disease symptoms. Dr. Bialystok, 62, a distinguished research professor of psychology at York University in Toronto, was awarded a $100,000 Killam Prize last year for her contributions to social science. We spoke for two hours in a Washington hotel room in February and again, more recently, by telephone. An edited version of the two conversations follows.

headline1: When Older Doctors Put Patients at Risk
snippet: What happens if an older doctor’s skills begin to slip because of early Alzheimer’s or another illness, putting the patient at risk?
lead_paragraph: A third of the physicians in the United States are over 65, and many continue to work with competence into their 70s and beyond. Yet what happens if a doctor’s cognitive or physical skills begin to slip because of early Alzheimer’s, a subtle stroke or another illness, putting the patient at risk? That’s a question explored by Laurie Tarkan in this week’s Science Times.

headline1: Studying Aging, and Fearing Budget Cuts
headline2: Studying Aging, And Fearing Budget Cuts
snippet: Dr. Richard J. Hodes, the director of the National Institute on Aging, weighs the research his lab is doing in a time of fiscal pressure.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Richard J. Hodes presides over the nation’s prime source of grants for studies of aging at a worrisome time for researchers. Just when the cohort of elderly Americans is surging, many scientists fear that government budget cuts may hamper a broad array of research efforts on Alzheimer’s and other diseases of aging  not to mention the eye-catching recent progress on reversing age-related decline in genetically altered mice.

headline1: Summitt’s New Opponent
headline2: Summitt Opts Not to Give In
snippet: Staying active will give Pat Summitt, the women’s basketball coach at Tennessee, the best chance to stave off decline and give Alzheimer’s a public face.
lead_paragraph: Just after an earthquake rolled through the world of sports on Tuesday, an earthquake rolled through the East Coast. The timing seemed fitting, suggesting perhaps even tectonic plates relied on the idea that Pat Summitt, the Tennessee women’s basketball coach, was indestructible. Having watched her will her way to so many things, lifting not only her own program and women’s basketball to a new level, but also women’s sports. Certainly she wasn’t subject to things like the law of gravity or human illnesses like Alzheimer’s, right?

headline1: Guilty Verdicts Appealed in Brooke Astor Will Case
headline2: Guilty Verdicts Appealed In Brooke Astor Will Case

lead_paragraph: The lawyers for Brooke Astor’s son and for a lawyer who did estate planning for her filed a lengthy appeal to their convictions on Monday.

headline2: BACK THEN: 1990

He first assisted in a suicide in 1990, connecting Janet Adkins, a 54-year-old woman suffering from Alzheimer’s disease, to a device of his own invention. headline1: Etta James Is Terminally Ill
headline2: Etta James Is Terminally Ill
snippet: Etta James, the seminal R&B singer, is terminally ill, according to her doctor, Elaine James (who is not related to Etta James).
lead_paragraph: Etta James, the seminal R&B singer, is terminally ill, according to her doctor, Elaine James  (who is not related to Etta James). Dr. James told The Press-Enterprise in Riverside, Calif., that family members were told two weeks ago that Ms. James’s chronic leukemia could not be cured. “I am Southern and Christian and would just ask for the prayers of her fans and friends,” Dr. James said. “They know she’s been sick, but not how sick.” Etta James, 73, has been among the most celebrated American blues singers for decades, recording enduring hits like “At Last,” “Tell Mama” and “I’d Rather Go Blind.” She was inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in 1993. Her career was also influenced by drug addiction, troubled love relationships and health and legal problems. In 2010 she was hospitalized for a staph infection, and it became public that she was suffering from Alzheimer’s disease, and that she had been treated for dependence on painkillers. Dr. James has cared for Etta James, above, at her home in Riverside since March 2010, and she made the statements last week outside a hearing over control of Ms. James’s $1 million estate. Donato James, her son, has been fighting in court with her husband, Artis Mills, over who will be named the estate’s conservator.

headline1: What We Can Learn From Old Animals
snippet: Isa Leshko, a fine art photographer, set out to capture glimpses of animals in their twilight years — a therapeutic project inspired by caring for her mother with Alzheimer’s disease.
lead_paragraph: It is not hard to argue that we live in a youth-centric culture, one in which young age and beauty are almost synonymous. And that obsession does not end with humans. Puppies and kittens melt hearts; images and videos of baby animals flood the Internet. But rarely does an image of an animal in old age ignite the same interest and adoration.

headline1: An Ailing Killebrew Simply Says Farewell
headline2: An Ailing Killebrew Simply Says Farewell
snippet: Harmon Killebrew issued a modest farewell on Friday in which the slugger of 573 home runs said his battle against esophageal cancer had come to an end.
lead_paragraph: Harmon Killebrew’s modest farewell on Friday — in which the slugger of 573 home runs said his battle against esophageal cancer had come to an end — evoked the goodbyes made by former President Ronald Reagan as he faced Alzheimer’s disease and Charlton Heston as he described symptoms consistent with Alzheimer’s.

headline1: Heavy Doses of DNA Data, With Few Side Effects
headline2: Heavy Doses of DNA Data, With Few Side Effects
snippet: Most people say they’ll pay for genetic tests even if the predictions are sometimes wrong, and most people don’t seem to be traumatized even when they receive bad news.
lead_paragraph: When companies tried selling consumers the results of personal DNA tests, worried doctors and assorted health experts rushed to the public’s rescue. What if the risk assessments were inaccurate or inconsistent? What if people misinterpreted the results and did something foolish? What if they were traumatized by learning they were at high risk for Alzheimer’s or breast cancer or another disease?

headline1: Clive Robbins, Developer of a Method of Music Therapy, Dies at 84
headline2: Clive Robbins, 84, Developer of a Method of Music Therapy
snippet: Mr. Robbins, with Paul Nordoff, designed a brand of music therapy for hard-to-reach children that is now used to help people with autism, stroke and Alzheimer’s disease.
lead_paragraph: Clive Robbins, a developer of an influential brand of music therapy designed to help people with various disabilities meet the physical, mental and social challenges that are facts of everyday life, died on Wednesday at his home in Jersey City. He was 84.

headline1: Casey Ribicoff, Senator’s Widow and a Style Leader, Dies at 88
headline2: Casey Ribicoff, 88, Senator’s Widow and a Style Leader
snippet: Mrs. Ribicoff, the widow of Abraham A. Ribicoff of Connecticut, straddled the worlds of New York politics, fashion and culture.
lead_paragraph: Not long after doctors had determined in 1994 that Ronald Reagan was suffering from Alzheimer’s disease, his wife, Nancy, found an unexpected ally. Casey Ribicoff was coping with the same mental decline in her husband, Abraham A. Ribicoff, the resolutely liberal former senator from Connecticut.

headline1: Another Month, Another Home
snippet: Multiple relocations are surprisingly common and often harmful to the elderly. Poor communication regarding medical needs is often to blame, experts say.
lead_paragraph: For five years, Jim Casparie pleaded with his parents, Robert and Virginia Casparie, to accept more help. His father, then 91, had Alzheimer’s disease, and his mother, 84, had diabetes and poor balance, falling frequently. When they finally agreed to move to an independent living apartment in 2008, Mr. Casparie, 61, an investment banker, thought at last he could stop worrying about their safety.

headline1: Remembering Pete Pihos, Pioneering Tight End
snippet: Pete Pihos was one of the best all-around players in N.F.L. history. He excelled on offense, defense and on special teams for the Philadelphia Eagles’ championship teams of the late 1940s.
lead_paragraph: A few thoughts about Pete Pihos, one of pro football’s first great pass-catching tight ends. After a long battle with Alzheimer’s disease, Pihos died Tuesday in a nursing home in Winston-Salem, N.C., at age 87.

headline1: Sweet and Vicious
headline2: Sweet And Vicious
snippet: Readers respond.
lead_paragraph: Like everyone else on earth, I have a 100 percent chance of dying. The only unknowns are when and how it will happen. I don’t smoke because I’m not interested in dying of a heart attack at 50 or of emphysema at 60. This increases my chance of dying from something else. Gary Taubes makes a strong case that sugar causes some kinds of death (“Is Sugar Toxic?”), but he doesn’t tell me what I get to die of if I give it up. Will my new risk of death be better or worse? If going without sugar means that I get to die of complications from Alzheimer’s at 95, in a nursing home, unable to eat, use the bathroom or recognize anyone around me, then please, let me eat cake.

headline1: Experimental Alzheimer’s Drug Will Get More Study at Eli Lilly
headline2: Experimental Alzheimer’s Drug Will Get More Study at Eli Lilly

headline1: Navigating the Medicare Claims Process
snippet: Readers share stories about Medicare claims denials related to whether they, a relative or a patient were unlikely to improve.
lead_paragraph: In this weekend’s Your Money column, I write about the settlement of a class-action lawsuit over the question of whether and when Medicare should cover treatments for people with chronic or degenerative conditions for which there are no cure.

headline1: Three Drugs to Be Tested to Stave Off Alzheimer’s
headline2: Three Drugs To Be Tested To Stave Off Alzheimer’s
snippet: Three studies are starting early next year with the same goal: finding a way to head off the disease with early intervention.
lead_paragraph: Scientists have selected three different types of Alzheimer’s drugs to be tested in the first large-scale international attempt to prevent the disease in people who are otherwise doomed to get it.

headline1: Is Alzheimer’s Type 3 Diabetes?
snippet: Evidence suggests that Alzheimer’s might be another form of diabetes, and links both to the overconsumption of junk food.
lead_paragraph: Just in case you need another reason to cut back on junk food, it now turns out that Alzheimer’s could well be a form of diet-induced diabetes. That’s the bad news. The good news is that laying off soda, doughnuts, processed meats and fries could allow you to keep your mind intact until your body fails you.

headline1: Farewell to a Mustache Forever Linked to the Mets
headline2: Farewell to an Iconic Strip of Facial Hair
snippet: Surrounded by fans, Keith Hernandez shaved his trademark facial hair in exchange for a $10,000 donation to a Brooklyn day care center for Alzheimer’s patients.
lead_paragraph: Without his mustache, would Clark Gable have been as silkily charming when he told Scarlett O’Hara he frankly did not give a damn? Would Groucho Marx have delivered his one-liners with the same zing?

headline1: Alzheimer’s Drug Misses Goal, but Offers Hint of Potential
headline2: Alzheimer’s Drug From Lilly Misses, but Offers Promise
snippet: The treatment, being tested by Eli Lilly, failed to halt progress of the disease, but there were some signs it could slow cognitive decline in patients with mild cases.
lead_paragraph: An Alzheimer’s drug being tested by Eli Lilly failed in its main goal of halting progress of the disease, the company said Friday, but there were some signs it could slow cognitive decline in patients with mild cases.

headline1: Effects of Delirium Are Found to Linger
snippet: The more researchers learn about delirium, the clearer it is that attention must be paid.
lead_paragraph: The more researchers learn about delirium, the clearer it is that attention must be paid. For years, people thought of it as a transient condition: Patients, especially older ones, grow confused and irrational and sometimes even violent during hospital stays — then in a few days, the delirium passes and people return to themselves.

headline1: Trials for Alzheimer’s Drug Halted After Poor Results
headline2: Trials for Alzheimer’s Drug Halted After Poor Results
snippet: The companies developing the treatment, called bapineuzumab, said it did not improve cognition or daily functioning compared with a placebo.
lead_paragraph: Johnson & Johnson and Pfizer announced on Monday that they were halting development of a closely watched Alzheimer’s drug after two clinical trials failed to show that it was effective in patients with mild to moderate forms of the disease.

headline1: Most New Long-Term Care Claims Are Filed by Women
headline2: Care Policies And Women
snippet: Women filed two-thirds of new long-term care claims last year, an industry report says.
lead_paragraph: While deciding to purchase long-term care insurance is a complex decision, it is one that women, in particular, may want to spend some time considering. Nearly two-thirds of new claims under long-term care policies in 2011 were made by women, according to the latest data from an industry group.

headline2: Alzheimer’s Drug Fails First Big Clinical Trial

lead_paragraph: The most closely watched experimental treatment for Alzheimer’s disease proved ineffective in its first large clinical trial, dealing a blow to the field, to a theory about the cause of the disease, and to the three companies behind the drug.

headline1: A Defense Against Alzheimer’s
snippet: Researchers have found a rare gene mutation that seems to protect against Alzheimer’s disease.
lead_paragraph: The Times reports today that researchers in Iceland have discovered a gene mutation that appears to protect those who inherit it from Alzheimer’s disease and other forms of cognitive decline. Scientists are hailing the discovery as a milestone in the desperate search for effective treatments. Gina Kolata reports:

headline1: Footprints to Cognitive Decline and Alzheimer’s Are Seen in Gait
headline2: Footprints to Cognitive Decline and Alzheimer’s Are Seen in Gait
snippet: Five studies presented this month provide striking evidence that when a person’s walk gets slower or becomes more variable or less controlled, his cognitive function is also suffering.
lead_paragraph: The way people walk appears to speak volumes about the way they think, so much so that changes in an older person’s gait appear to be an early indicator of cognitive impairment, including Alzheimer’s disease.

headline1: Small Trial Hints Drug Can Slow Alzheimer’s
headline2: Small Trial Hints Drug Can Slow Alzheimer’s
snippet: Some Alzheimer’s patients who used the therapy, already approved for immune disorders, showed no worsening of symptoms for three years.
lead_paragraph: A drug already on the market that treats immune disorders may help stabilize patients with Alzheimer’s disease for up to three years, according to the results of a tiny study presented at a conference on Tuesday.

headline1: In Preventing Alzheimer’s, Mutation May Aid Drug Quest
headline2: Rare Mutation May Help Fight On Alzheimer’s
snippet: The discovery of a rare protective genetic mutation provides strong evidence that the buildup of beta amyloid protein in the brain is a driving force in Alzheimer’s disease.
lead_paragraph: A study of a rare gene mutation that protects people against Alzheimer’s disease provides the strongest evidence yet that excessive levels of a normal brain substance, beta amyloid, are a driving force in the disease — bolstering hopes that anti-amyloid drugs already under development might alter the disease’s course or even prevent it.

headline1: A New Front in the Battle Against Alzheimer’s
snippet: Within a decade, there could be a drug that staves off brain destruction and death, some experts say.
lead_paragraph: In the New York Times Magazine on Sunday, Gina Kolata reports on new efforts to discover a treatment for Alzheimer’s disease.

headline1: A New Attack on Alzheimer’s
headline2: A New Attack on Alzheimer’s
snippet: A bold research program will test whether a drug can prevent the onset of Alzheimer’s disease well before any symptoms appear.
lead_paragraph: The Obama administration has announced a bold research program to test whether a drug can prevent the onset of Alzheimer’s disease well before any symptoms appear. It is a long shot, but the payoff could be huge.

headline1: A Drug to Prevent Alzheimer’s
snippet: Government officials announce plans to test a drug to prevent Alzheimer’s disease.
lead_paragraph: The Times reports today that a group of people genetically predisposed to Alzheimer’s disease — but who do not yet have any symptoms — will for the first time be given a drug intended to stop them from developing the condition.

headline1: The Person, Not the Alzheimer’s
snippet: A new book and photo exhibit portray efforts around the world to help Alzheimer’s patients connect with the outside world by focusing on their individual traits and histories.
lead_paragraph: A new book and photo exhibit portray efforts around the world to help Alzheimer’s patients connect with the outside world by focusing on their individual traits and histories.

headline1: Path Is Found for the Spread of Alzheimer’s
headline2: Path Is Found For the Spread Of Alzheimer’s
snippet: The discovery in studies of mice solves a mystery surrounding the disease’s grim march and has immediate implications for developing treatments, researchers said.
lead_paragraph: Alzheimer’s disease seems to spread like an infection from brain cell to brain cell, two new studies in mice have found. But instead of viruses or bacteria, what is being spread is a distorted protein known as tau.

headline1: In Alzheimer’s, a Tangled Protein
snippet: Two new studies suggest that Alzheimer’s disease spreads from cell to cell.
lead_paragraph: Two new studies suggest that Alzheimer’s disease spreads from cell to cell.

headline1: New Drug Trial Seeks to Stop Alzheimer’s Before It Starts
headline2: Drug Trial Aims For Prevention of Alzheimer’s
snippet: A clinical trial of Crenezumab will focus largely on members of a Colombian family who are genetically destined to develop the disease but who do not yet have any symptoms.
lead_paragraph: In a clinical trial that could lead to treatments that prevent Alzheimer’s, people who are genetically guaranteed to develop the disease — but who do not yet have any symptoms — will for the first time be given a drug intended to stop it, federal officials announced Tuesday.

headline1: Finding Joy in Alzheimer’s
snippet: So often, I hear people say they would rather die than get Alzheimer’s. But my grandmother showed me that we are more than the sum of our memories.
lead_paragraph: Seven years ago, when my grandmother JoAnn was first diagnosed with Alzheimer’s, the news sent me into a tailspin of fear and sadness.

headline1: The Alzheimer’s Reading Room
snippet: Bob DeMarco blogs about the day-to-day experiences of caring for his mother with Alzheimer’s in the Alzheimer’s Reading Room.
lead_paragraph: In mid-January, Bob DeMarco, 61, left his 96-year-old mother’s side for the first time in eight years to go to a conference about Alzheimer’s disease just a few hours from the home they share in Delray Beach, Fla. He made elaborate plans for his time away, arranging for his mother, Dotty, who has advanced Alzheimer’s, to stay with nearby friends; getting his first cellphone lest there be an emergency; and bit by bit, day after day, “reminding” her of his coming departure.

headline1: How Alzheimer’s Disease Spreads
snippet: Two new studies provide clues to how Alzheimer’s disease spreads in the brain.
lead_paragraph: The Times reports today on two new studies finding that Alzheimer’s disease seems to spread like an infection from brain cell to brain cell — in mice, at least, and perhaps in humans as well. The finding may help speed the development of new treatments.

headline1: Daily Activity Tied to Lower Alzheimer’s Risk
snippet: Higher levels of daily physical activity in the elderly were associated with a decreased risk of Alzheimer’s disease in a new study.
lead_paragraph: Higher levels of daily physical activity are associated with a decreased risk of Alzheimer’s disease, new research suggests.

headline1: Answers About Alzheimer’s, Part 2
snippet: Dr. P. Murali Doraiswamy of Duke University addresses reader questions about Alzheimer’s disease and other memory problems.
lead_paragraph: Dr. P. Murali Doraiswamy, a psychiatry professor at Duke University Medical Center and an author of “The Alzheimer’s Action Plan,” has been answering readers’ questions about Alzheimer’s disease and memory problems. Part 1 of responses can be found here. Part 2, posted below, addresses diagnostic issues, the role played by genetics, causes and policy issues. His last set of answers, about treatment, patient care and new clinical trials, will appear here on Wednesday. [Update: Part 3 can be read here.]

headline1: How Do You Live Knowing You Might Have an Alzheimer’s Gene?
headline2: Inheriting a Fragile Mind
snippet: One family with a genetic mutation is helping scientists find a cure.
lead_paragraph: It seemed as if it would be a perfectly ordinary occasion, that hot August day in 1959. Three generations of a large Oklahoma family gathered at a studio in nearby Perryton, Tex., to have a photo taken of the elders, 14 siblings ranging in age from 29 to 52. Afterward, everyone went to a nearby park for a picnic.

headline1: More Omega-3s in Diet, Less of an Alzheimer’s Protein
headline2: Vital Signs: Nutrition: More Omega-3, Less of a Suspect Protein
snippet: A study shows consumption of omega-3 fatty acids is associated with lower blood levels of beta-amyloid protein, a possible indication of increased risk for Alzheimer’s disease.
lead_paragraph: A new study has found that consumption of omega-3 fatty acids, plentiful in fish and nuts, is associated with lower blood levels of beta-amyloid protein.

headline1: Together Until the End
snippet: A caregiver shoots his wife and then himself, leaving ethicists to ponder the implications.
lead_paragraph: When a Pennsylvania man who’d spent six years caring for his wife with Alzheimer’s somehow decided in March to kill her and then shoot himself, and their family declared that he’d done so “out of deep devotion and profound love,” I read the news articles with mingled horror and compassion. I’m sure many here shuddered.

headline1: Summitt Stepping Down as Tennessee Coach
headline2: Tennessee’s Summitt Steps Down As Coach
snippet: Pat Summitt, who received a diagnosis of early onset Alzheimer’s last year, will take the title of head coach emeritus, and longtime assistant Holly Warlick will replace her.
lead_paragraph: Less than a year after she received a diagnosis of early onset Alzheimer’s disease, Pat Summitt has stepped down as Tennessee’s women’s basketball coach, ending her remarkable 38-year career in building one of the signature programs in the sport.

headline1: Pat Summitt’s Signature: Success and Dignity
headline2: Pat Summitt’s Signature: Success and Dignity
snippet: In saying goodbye to her remarkable basketball coaching career, Pat Summitt of Tennessee was once again a role model in how to handle a challenge.
lead_paragraph: It was at once a moment expected and inevitable and yet one with no way to prepare. As Tennessee’s women’s basketball season marched on, it became clear Pat Summitt could not sustain her role as head coach much longer as she battled early onset Alzheimer’s and it became one long goodbye party, but one no one could acknowledge. And when the goodbye was finally uttered on Wednesday, with Summitt abdicating the throne she occupied for 38 years, the reality washed over everyone who is in some degree in her debt. And that would be everyone in the sport.

headline1: Drug Dosage Was Approved Despite Warning
headline2: Drug Dosage Was Approved Despite Warning
snippet: The Alzheimer’s drug Aricept 23 was set to lose its patent, but its makers received approval for a higher dosage that extended their exclusivity.
lead_paragraph: Four months before a best-selling Alzheimer’s drug was set to lose its patent protection, its makers received approval for a higher dosage that extended their exclusive right to sell the drug. But the higher dosage caused potentially dangerous side effects and worked only slightly better than the existing drugs, according to an article published Thursday in the British Medical Journal.

headline1: Tale of Love and Illness Ends in Deaths
headline2: Tale of Love and Illness Ends in Deaths
snippet: After six decades of marriage and his wife’s decline, the author of a poignant essay killed himself and her, too.
lead_paragraph: His was a love story, Charles D. Snelling wrote — a tale of a shiftless dreamer and the woman who saved him, of the life they built over six decades and the disease that stood no chance of erasing it. By the end, he said, their time together had become a case study in reciprocity.

headline1: Unflinching View of a Wandering Mind, No Breadcrumb Trail in Sight
headline2: Unflinching View of a Wandering Mind, No Breadcrumb Trail in Sight
snippet: The documentary filmmaker Scott Kirschenbaum follows the daily life on a woman with Alzheimer’s in “You’re Looking at Me Like I Live Here and I Don’t.”
lead_paragraph: Perhaps years from now, after a scientific breakthrough has turned Alzheimer’s disease into a memory as distant as polio wards are to younger Americans today, someone will stumble upon Scott Kirschenbaum’s hard-to-watch documentary, “You’re Looking at Me Like I Live Here and I Don’t,” and be stunned. “I’ve read about Alzheimer’s,” this person will say, “but I had no idea what it was actually like.”

headline2: How to Teach An Old Brain New Tricks
snippet: Some people may be thinking of second careers, while others hope to forestall the mental declines of age.
lead_paragraph: MORE and more retired people are heading back to the nearest classroom — as students and, in some cases, teachers — and they are finding out that school can be lovelier the second time around. headline1: Can a Pill Make People With Down Syndrome Smarter?
snippet: A new study to be published in August examines the role a drug called memantine — normally used in Alzheimer’s patients — can play in improving intellectual ability.
lead_paragraph: Last summer, the magazine published an article by Dan Hurley about Dr. Alberto Costa, a researcher and an associate professor at the University of Colorado, who has a daughter with Down syndrome and who was then conducting a study to see whether a particular drug, memantine, can improve the intellectual abilities of adults with the syndrome. Results of the study are being published in the August issue of the journal Translational Psychiatry.

headline1: Yankees’ Run Allows Girardi No Time to Grieve
snippet: Jerry Girardi, the father of Yankees Manager Joe Girardi, died Saturday in Metamora, Ill., at age 81.
lead_paragraph: Joe Girardi has managed the Yankees in the entire division series after his father, Jerry, who had Alzheimer’s disease, died at age 81.

headline1: Campbell Says Goodbye With Sparkle and Guitar
headline2: Campbell Says Goodbye With Sparkle and Guitar
snippet: Glen Campbell, who has Alzheimer’s disease, performed at Town Hall as part of his “Goodbye Tour.”
lead_paragraph: Last June, Glen Campbell announced that he had Alzheimer’s disease, and on Saturday night he came to Town Hall as part of what was billed as the “Goodbye Tour.” Everyone in the room understood. The faithful, reverent crowd appeared not to mind that for much of the show Mr. Campbell was reading lyrics from prompters that had been set between the monitors at the foot of the stage.

headline1: Chile: Extradition Request Approved in 1973 Case of Americans Killed
headline2: Chile: Extradition Request Approved In 1973 Case of Americans Killed
snippet: The Supreme Court in Chile approved an extradition request on Wednesday against a former American Navy officer indicted in the killings of two United States citizens in the aftermath of the 1973 coup.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court in Chile approved an extradition request on Wednesday against a former American Navy officer indicted in the killings of two United States citizens in the aftermath of the 1973 coup. Retired Capt. Ray E. Davis was commander of the United States Military Group at the embassy in Santiago at the time and was indicted last November, along with a former Chilean intelligence officer, for the killings of Charles Horman, 31, and Frank Teruggi, 24. Judge Jorge Zepeda accused Captain Davis — whose wife said he has Alzheimer’s disease, according to The Associated Press — of providing Chilean intelligence officers information on the two men, who were killed in military custody.

headline1: For Adults and Their Parents, a Difficult Crossroads
headline2: For Adults and Their Parents, a Difficult Crossroads
snippet: “Fred Won’t Move Out” looks at the uncomfortable moment when adult children have to switch roles with their parents.
lead_paragraph: Elliott Gould’s septuagenarian character in “Fred Won’t Move Out” is as blunt as the movie’s title. When he barks, “I’m not going,” he means it. Having lived in the same suburban house for more than 50 years with his wife, Susan (Judith Roberts), who has Alzheimer’s, Fred, who has difficulty walking, refuses to accept the reality that their days of living independently are over.

headline1: After Falling Behind Early, Lady Vols Rally for the Victory
headline2: After Falling Behind Early, Lady Vols Rally for the Victory
snippet: Tennessee’s senior class has not been to a Final Four, and Coach Pat Summitt’s future is uncertain as she battles the early symptoms of Alzheimer’s disease.
lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — A season hung in the balance. So, perhaps, did Pat Summitt’s peerless career. Tennessee appeared listless in the women’s N.C.A.A. tournament on Saturday. Kansas was quicker, more determined. Not once all season had the Lady Vols won a game after trailing at halftime.

headline1: New York Film Festival Unveils Main Slate Selections
headline2: New York Film Festival Names Main Selections
snippet: New works by Noah Baumbach, Brian De Palma, Michael Haneke, Sally Potter and Alan Berliner are among the 32 features that will be presented in the main slate of the New York Film Festival.
lead_paragraph: New works by Noah Baumbach, Brian De Palma, Michael Haneke, Sally Potter and Alan Berliner are among the 32 features that will be presented in the main slate of the New York Film Festival, the Film Society of Lincoln Center said on Thursday. Mr. Haneke’s film “Amour,” which won the Palme d’Or at the Cannes Film Festival, will make its New York debut. The festival will also present the world premiere of Mr. Berliner’s documentary “First Cousin Once Removed,” about the poet Edwin Honig’s slowly succumbing to Alzheimer’s disease. Mr. Baumbach will be represented at the festival by “Frances Ha,” a comedy written with the actress Greta Gerwig and starring Ms. Gerwig as a young woman trying to start a dance career in New York.

No tricks. Extraordinary.”

headline1: 56 Ways of Saying I Don’t Remember
snippet: Alan Berliner explores memory and forgetting in this short experimental documentary about his cousin Edwin Honig — a poet, translator and professor — and his journey through Alzheimer’s disease.
lead_paragraph: Alan Berliner explores memory and forgetting in this short experimental documentary about his cousin Edwin Honig — a poet, translator and professor — and his journey through Alzheimer’s disease.

headline1: ‘56 Ways of Saying I Don’t Remember’
headline2: ‘56 Ways of Saying I Don’t Remember’
snippet: Alan Berliner explores memory and forgetting in this short experimental documentary about his cousin Edwin Honig – a poet, translator and professor — and his journey through Alzheimer’s disease.
lead_paragraph: This Op-Doc is part of a suite of short films collectively titled “Translating Edwin Honig: A Poet’s Alzheimer’s,” completed in 2010. The films form a portrait of the distinguished poet, translator, critic and Brown University professor Edwin Honig — who was my cousin, friend and mentor — and his journey through the depths of Alzheimer’s disease. It is the chronicle of a man who, though he may have lost his memory, his relationship to the past and his command of language, still retained his wit, his sense of humor, his scholarly demeanor and the bearings of a deeply poetic soul.

headline1: Forgetting Grandma
headline2: Forgetting Grandma
snippet: My father told me that my grandmother lived not far from me in San Francisco. This was news: I’d last seen her almost 25 years before.
lead_paragraph: My grandmother has Alzheimer’s disease. But in a lot of ways, she made us forget each other a long time ago.

headline1: Decision Casts Doubt on Brain Scans for Alzheimer’s
snippet: The federal agency overseeing Medicare is reluctant to endorse, or pay for brain scans to diagnose Alzheimer’s disease.
lead_paragraph: For all the hue and cry about detecting the earliest signs of Alzheimer’s disease, the federal Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services has concluded that amyloid brain scans for the purpose of diagnosing Alzheimer’s disease are not ready for prime time.

headline1: The Memory Lady’s Daughter Tries to Fill the Gaps
snippet: A daughter whose mother is 94 cares for the generations before and after her, living their lives and preserving their memories.
lead_paragraph: Reading was my mother’s escape from the Texas farm where she grew up. As a child, she memorized poems and recited them in her school auditorium. Later, she memorized whole books and performed them for women’s clubs. She stood alone onstage in high heels and a large hat while her voice transported her listeners to another world. You couldn’t take your eyes or ears off of her. Our home was a house of books, hundreds of which she knew by memory. Now she’s 94 and her once famous memory is slipping away.

headline1: In Grandmother’s Alzheimer’s, Another Lesson in Family

headline1: Georgia: 21 Charged After Inquiry Finds Alzheimer’s Patients Were Abused
headline2: Georgia: 21 Charged After Inquiry Finds Alzheimer’s Patients Were Abused
snippet: Twenty-one people were charged Tuesday after the Georgia Bureau of Investigation said it found widespread abuse of patients at a specialized care facility northeast of Atlanta.
lead_paragraph: Twenty-one people were charged Tuesday after the Georgia Bureau of Investigation said it found widespread abuse of patients at a specialized care facility northeast of Atlanta. The bureau said its review had found that employees at Alzheimer’s Care of Commerce had struck patients, delayed changing diapers and used bedsheets as restraining devices. The inquiry also uncovered that people with felony convictions were involved in patient care, a violation of state regulations. The authorities filed more than 70 charges against current and former facility employees. The center’s owner, Donna Wright, was among those charged.

headline1: Protein Linked to Development Problems
headline2: Brain Chemistry: Protein Linked to Development Problems
snippet: Scientists investigating Alzheimer’s found that mice lacking the protein SNX27 had the same learning and memory defects as mice with Down syndrome.
lead_paragraph: The French geneticist Jérôme Lejeune discovered more than 50 years ago that Down syndrome is caused by the presence of an extra copy of chromosome 21. But to this day it has remained a mystery why that results in impaired physical and cognitive development. Now researchers at the Sanford-Burnham Medical Research Institute think they have found a clue.

headline1: Waiting for the Forgetting to Begin
snippet: Using a jarred brain as a teaching tool, my dad showed my 8-year-old self how brains with Alzheimer’s disease become smaller. But only after his death — and my mother’s confession about whose brain occupied that jar — did I figure out that my fath...
lead_paragraph: My gray matter might be waning. Then again, it might not be. But I swear that I can feel memories — as I’m making them — slide off a neuron and into a tangle of plaque. I steel myself for those moments to come when I won’t remember what just went into my head.

headline2: Cho Basden, Daniel Mazur

headline1: Theater World Friends Bring Ailing Playwright Closer To Home

Just before 1 p.m. the small throng waved and applauded as Ms. Fornés, 82 and gaunt but seeming to enjoy the attention, was wheeled into the home.

headline1: The Longest Day and Young Chelsea Bridge Club
snippet: On June 21 bridge players are being challenged to compete for at least part of approximately 16 hours from dawn to dusk to raise $100 an hour or more for the Alzheimer’s Association.
lead_paragraph: Bridge marathons are few and far between. Four students played in London for 170 hours in 1969. Three years later four students in Edinburgh broke that record by 10 hours. The Young Chelsea Bridge Club in London has organized several marathons that last exactly 24 hours, but teams of three may enter.

headline1: A Descent Chronicled With Care
headline2: First Cousin Once Removed
snippet: In “First Cousin Once Removed,” Alan Berliner looks at Edwin Honig’s life as Alzheimer’s took its toll.
lead_paragraph: “Recalling who I was, I see somebody else” begins a poem by Fernando Pessoa, quoted in Alan Berliner’s “First Cousin Once Removed.” In Mr. Berliner’s moving and mysterious documentary, the poet and translator Edwin Honig picks his way through his mind and memories in the falling shadow of Alzheimer’s. It’s the latest of Mr. Berliner’s dogged investigations into identity and family, and his strongest work yet, elevated by the presence of another artist in Mr. Honig, playfully insightful and eloquent even as his powers wane.

headline1: Getting It Right: Lore Segal Talks About ‘Half the Kingdom’
snippet: Ms. Segal’s new novel is set at a hospital where Alzheimer’s disease is spreading at a rapid rate.
lead_paragraph: Lore Segal published her first novel in 1964. “Other People’s Houses” was a semi-autobiographical story about a young girl growing up in England after Hitler took control of Austria. When Ms. Segal was 10 years old, she left Vienna for England as part of the Kindertransport program. She moved to New York in 1951. In her new novel, “Half the Kingdom,” older hospital patients are mysteriously contracting Alzheimer’s disease at a rapid rate. In The New York Times Book Review, Patricia T. O’Conner wrote: “Fans of Segal’s fiction should feel right at home in this darkly comic novel.” In a recent e-mail interview, Ms. Segal, 85, discussed what the book says about aging, the recurring characters in her fiction, whether she ever thinks of retiring and more. Below are edited excerpts from the conversation:

headline1: Reaching for Soul’s High Ground
headline2: Reaching for Soul’s High Ground
snippet: Bobby Womack, 69, despite advancing age and what he said was Alzheimer’s disease, was in fine fettle on Friday at City Winery.
lead_paragraph: Classic soul singing is, among countless other things, the art of the interjection. “Whoo!” “Mmmmm.” “Ohhhhhh.” “HahahaHA!” “Owww.” “Yeah, yeah!” “Am I lying?” Can I take my time?” “Listen to me!” “Do you feel it?” Used right, those interjections can be percussion, comedy, respiration, tension, release and more. Bobby Womack, 69, used them all at City Winery on Friday night, wearing a red leather suit, a red hat and red sunglasses as he started a three-night stand.

headline1: Just in Time, a Lebanese Artist’s Work Is Shown at Tate Modern
headline2: Just in Time, a Lebanese Artist's Work Is Shown at Tate Modern
snippet: Saloua Raouda Choucair’s first exhibition in Beirut in 1947 is thought to be the first-ever show of abstract art in the Arab world. Now, as she copes with Alzheimer’s, her works are on display in London.

headline1: On the Frontiers of Brain Research
headline2: On the Frontiers of Brain Research
snippet: President Obama’s pledge of $100 million is a modest but welcome start to helping us understand how the brain works.
lead_paragraph: President Obama officially announced his new brain research initiative on Tuesday, with a pledge to put $100 million in his 2014 budget to support work at three federal agencies. It is a modest but welcome start for an effort that could transform our understanding of how the brain works and help researchers find new ways to treat and prevent brain disorders like epilepsy and Alzheimer’s.

headline1: Breakthrough Replicates Human Brain Cells for Use in Alzheimer’s Research
headline2: Breakthrough Replicates Human Brain Cells for Use in Alzheimer’s Research

headline1: ‘A Marriage to Remember’
snippet: In this short documentary, a filmmaker explores how Alzheimer’s disease has revealed the strength of his parents’ marriage.
lead_paragraph: My mother, Pam White, has had a full life. In her 67 years, she has raised three happy children, enjoyed a rewarding career as a social worker and been a devoted partner to my father, Ed. But, as she puts it, “There’s just one little glitch.” In 2009, at age 61, she was told she had early-onset Alzheimer’s disease.

headline1: Fish as Brain Food
headline2: It’s the Fish, Not the Omega-3

headline1: The Mysteries of My Father’s Mind
headline2: Mysteries of My Father’s Mind
snippet: The one thing that brings him back from the confusion of Alzheimer’s is beauty — the yellow rose bush and the bleeding heart.
lead_paragraph: OMAHA — Mom is doing makeup for the opera and Dad tags along. Beverly Sills has been brought in for the role of Lucia di Lammermoor and she has packed the house. Mom draws wrinkles on a tenor while Ms. Sills is called to the stage. The page is growing urgent. She’ll miss her entrance if she doesn’t show up soon. A crew member blows by and says they found her in the green room, apparently smitten to the point of distraction by a big strapping cowboy, my father. Bill Rotert, Mom would scold, later, on their drive home.

headline1: Roche Reports Mixed Results in Trial of an Alzheimer’s Drug
headline2: Mixed Results for Roche in Alzheimer’s Drug Trial
snippet: While the drug, crenezumab, did not slow progression of the disease over all, at the highest doses it seemed to delay a decline in mental ability in patients with mild Alzheimer’s.
lead_paragraph: Roche, the pharmaceutical company, on Wednesday reported mixed results in its latest trial of an Alzheimer’s drug. It said that while the drug did not slow progression of the disease over all, at the highest doses it did seem to delay a decline in mental ability in patients with mild cases of Alzheimer’s.

headline1: New Clues to Alzheimer’s
headline2: New Clues to Alzheimer's
snippet: Intriguing research may point the way forward on treatment.
lead_paragraph: Two studies of Alzheimer’s disease published in respected scientific journals this month offered glimmers of hope for progress against this devastating neurological disorder. Neither advance is guaranteed to produce important clinical benefits anytime soon, but they may point the way toward new pathways to treat and diagnose a condition that impairs the thinking and memories of its victims and ultimately kills many of them.
